Awesome game. At first thought it was just going to be Papers, Please but in 3D, but there are so so many other aspects to the game which make it more interesting. Also nice to not be limited by time and not be so crunched with money. To add to the great gameplay, the soundtrack is also really good. The computer upgrade menu music absolutely slaps. The only pains I have so far are the night attacks on the checkpoint being a little bit annoying, and if dead people despawn you don't get the items they had. Not that big of a deal.
EDIT: Oh my goodness I forgot there are multiple gamemodes, and I only just finished the campaign. There is an inspector mode which looks to have a lot more content in terms of upgrading and managing your outpost. Sweet!

Surprisingly deep game, storyline involves backing the government or the rebels.  Not just border work, you are often tasked to leave your post to bring prisoners to the labor camp or turn in all the delicious contraband!  Sometimes even investigating murders or screams in the night, or following rebel leaders.  Papers Please is still good and fun.  The only downside I can see is I've heard the game just ends when the story does and you have to start over, but I have not encountered this myself.  Happy to be wrong if I am!

UPDATE: There is now an infinite mode!  I love it!  Start with nearly nothing, and improve the crossing.  It of course lacks the story but that's fine.  I've graduated to a Police General, and still have yet to fully update the border crossing.

Amazing game, it really does have the vibe and even passion of 'Papers Please' which is also an amazing game, the campaign for this game is pretty neat and a bit wild I should say, though granted there is one mission which I find to be a pain and if you so happen know of which one I'm talking about, then I hope you can relate. But other than that the whole idea of looking through passports, documents, and even checking the vehicle itself, although not entirely new is still something pretty cool, and by the time I make this review the game is still being updated and adding in new things to the game, and to that I have to say to the people who made this game that you're all doing fantastic work! Absolutely loving it and I hope you make more games like this in the future!

Day 21 at the border checkpoint

The newest decree of the week was denying entry to any visitors from the Republic of Kagistan with food. Looks like there are concerns about tainted food. I’ve added that to the list of regulations I need to remember

First visitor had a heavy cargo truck with two flat tires, a missing mirror, and was somehow missing both bumpers. I didn’t bother asking how that all happened. Then I denied him entry because his Entry Card had his name misspelled and his passport looked forged. Not sure why he thought pink was an official document color.

Second visitor had all documents in order, except the registration number for his fancy sedan. After I denied him entry, he swore I’ll regret it and he drove off in a huff. He almost ran into the entry guard. 

Third visitor had everything in order and his van was pristine. It had an interesting paint job with flowers all over it. Before giving back his documents, I bought four bottles of pure vodka from him at a low price. He seemed happy to have finally sold them.

Fourth visitor was a smuggler. The tip with a partial registration number finally came in handy. Before I arrested him, I sold him three cigarette packs for a good profit. He was smiling about the trade, before I put the handcuffs on him. While searching his truck, I found stacks of counterfeit money stuffed into two of the tires, inside a seat cushion, and a few under the passenger seat. I had a feeling there were still more. Unfortunately, it was already 3 PM and there were still more visitors to process.

Fifth visitor wasn’t anything too interesting. He had no cargo, an expired passport, and expired entry permit. When he turned around, I noticed his back window was smashed.

I didn’t finish processing the sixth visitor. The alert sounded and I immediately slung my SMG into my arms. My mechanic, front entry guard, prison guard, and cargo officer all took positions with me. Gunfire came from the wood-line just a moment later. The proceeding firefight is still a bit of a blur for me. I think I shot down about a dozen gang members, two of my guards needed medical attention, and in total there were almost twenty dead bodies when the fight ended. 

Maybe I should pay for a better fence, some more armored vests, and rifles. Money hasn’t exactly been piling up though. Even with my side-gig of bartering commodities with visitors.

This game seemed really cool in concept, and do not get me wrong it is forsure interesting! Unfortunately, this game is lacking in a few ways. The game play is very repetitive which goes with the line of work, but I expected a few things that trailers and descriptions led me to believe. There is no way to illegally sell the contraband you gather, making it a little difficult to get excess money, as the police give you next to nothing for turning it in. Also, the game feels like running errands when you actually get to go out and explore. I also expected the fellow guards to do more, and not just stand there while you do everything, which was a letdown. Furthermore, I encountered a few bugs when trying to turn in prisoners, which prevented me from doing so. Most importantly the inspections start out fun, but then too many regulations make it hard to keep track of what is what, and when finding a smuggler, you just want to get it over with as fast as possible in the later game, due to how long the inspections can take at that point. The gunfights are okay at best, and do not happen often enough and when the small ones do they feel underwhelming. If this game added more control over the fellow guards that a commander should have, allowing them to conduct tasks like taking in prisoners, it would be a lot better. Overall, this game is fun in SMALL doses, and it needs fleshed out more. This is a great concept, and the developers have done a decent job, but for the price tag of $30 it absolutely leaves much to be desired! I enjoy this game, but in its current state I would say its only worth $15-$20.

The game is a decent bit of fun starting off, but it gets repetitive pretty quickly. The videos would lead you to believe there's a lot more movement and actions involved, but the game is oddly simplistic in comparison. I've also had an annoying amount of glitches to doors being stuck closed, drivers just walking away during an inspection, and even random CTDs that didn't make any sense. With some patches here and there, I think this could be a pretty great game, but I just found it wanting as it currently sits. 5/10
fun

This game is fun but has a lot issues. The border patrol aspect of the game is fun but repetitive and easy.  Unlike similar games like paper please the complexity of the inspections never increases substantially.  The game will randomly introduce certain rules for your inspection but after a few days the rules are reset and a new set of special rules is added. The complexity of the inspections never builds. In papers please by the end game you are checking for vaccinations, entry documents, passport forgeries, smuggling, and diplomatic papers just to name a few, while many of these tasks exist in Contraband Police you never really have to watch out for more than one special circumstance at time .  There is also no time limit to border inspections, while this may sound like a positive the time limit at the end of each round combined with the mountain of paperwork the inspector must check adds a level of suspense and challenge. I never felt like there was any challenge in the inspections of Contraband Police.

The errand boy aspect of the game is tedious and repetitive.  You are sent all over the border of Arcaistan to stock and resupply the border checkpoint. At first this is fun but after Dropping off the prisoners, buying supplies at vlads, and dropping of seized contraband at the police station 10 times it becomes repetitive and grindy

I will say that the border upgrade aspect of the game is incredibly fun. Being able to hire new guards and upgrade existing is a major plus and almost makes the grind worth it. 

This game has a lot of potential but i wouldn't recommended it at full price. Around $10-15 dollars seems like a fair price for the game in its current state.

Contraband Police is a single-player game where you work as a border control agent in a country called Acaristan.

Different from "Papers, Please", Contraband Police is a 3D game with unique mechanics such as driving cars, shootouts, detailed cargo checks, etc.

There are multiple game modes that you can play, such as campaign, challenge, etc. With the new endless mode added into the game, I think this is my go-to relaxing game as of right now.

I would give Contraband Police a solid 8/10, there are still room for improvements but as of right now the game is really enjoyable and relaxing.

My suggestions for the Crazy Rocks team are to add an interrogation mechanic where users can ask questions, and allow multiple people, such as family and friends, to ride in a single car.

I have a rule when purchasing games, I want at least one hour of enjoyment for every dollar I spent on the game. One dollar per hour of enjoyment. I really do enjoy this game and it's worth the investment, especially since it doesn't have the same BS prices as some triple A games that aren't worth belly button lint. However, there are a few things I hope are added or changed. The mechanics are okay, it doesn't necessarily have the movement or visuals as some other large games but it definitely isn't bad. Sometimes it's a pain in the rear to leave a vehicle. There are times where I am looking in the right direction and attempting to move and my character will just sit there until my mouse moves over the 1 single pixel that prompts my character to leave the vehicle. Additionally, I REALLY wish that when I fail an inspection, it would tell me why it failed so I could learn from those failures. Instead, it just says "that driver should have been refused!" and then you lose money. Like.... Thanks? How???? It seems like there are times where the game just says "nah fam, not today" and it fails you no matter the amount of inspection you do. For example, there's a board that details expected smugglers. In the 6 hours I've played so far, there will be a notice saying "a suspect ran from an inspection and is expected to try and cross the border." and then it will give you 3 digits of their license plate. I arrested one guy that had those three digits in his plate in the correct order, and I was told it was a wrongful arrest and I lost hundreds of dollars. Few hours later, same notice with a different plate number. I let him through since I didn't find any contraband (he ran from an inspection, not a suspected smuggler) I thoroughly checked his vehicle but instead of wrongfully arresting him and losing the hundreds of dollars, I let him through. No contraband and his papers were correct. I wasn't going to make the same mistake for a second time so I let him through and then lost $400 for not arresting him. Like, dude wtf? I lose money if I arrest them based on the notice board but then I'll also lose money if I let them through based on the same kind of information on the board. It shouldn't feel like some RND type of game with that stuff. I shouldn't have to struggle on whether or not to let them through when I've said "yes" and "no" based on the same information two different times and I was wrong both times! Come on. And that goes back to my initial point. Tell me WHY I failed the inspection so I know what to look for next time. Outside of those few gripes, I thoroughly enjoy the game and it's something I can see myself probably putting in a couple hundred hours into. Especially if there will ever be a multiplayer mode. I could easily just screw around with a buddy and have a great time on here.


TL;DR
It's a great game and it's fun but it still needs some ironing out in certain ways. Easily worth buying and I will recommend it to my friends.

Love the game, the only issue I have is during Inspector Mode. While playing Inspector Mode there are criteria for who to deny access, these criteria change every few days. The issue I've come across is sometimes I'd mark them down for Entry Regulations, ex. Someone is under the age of 36 and that means they are denied access, yet the game tells me they shouldn't have been denied. I enjoy the concept of this game and how it's tangentially related to "Papers, Please", but it just overstays its welcome. The gameplay loop is just so repetitive and the rare moments of not inspecting cars for contraband are the worst part of the game. The faux pressure of a timer on every mission is frustrating, and the rare times when the missions aren't just fetch quests they're frustratingly difficult because of the clunky controls. 
Driving anywhere is also a chore with the unresponsive vehicles and CRAZY map layout. Also, no minimap is fine, but it makes traveling difficult. 

I like the game well enough as a time waster and will play it until I'm done with the campaign, but I would not recommend someone purchase it at full price.

I am a fan of the publisher, PlayWay, and have seen this game getting played more and more by certain streamers. I tested it with the demo version and realized quickly this would be a huge time sink for me.

The game design is fun and rewarding when you do it all correctly and the controls and methods to go about this are easily picked up and memorized, allowing the player to sink into a sort of "role-playing" feeling.

The "morality" gameplay is lacking and a bit confusing. You have the option to side with either the government or the rebels. On my first playthrough, siding with the rebels, the mission outcomes for the rebel side seem very off-colored and almost like it is the "bad choice." It's not until the end-of-story presentation panels that you feel like you made a good choice. The story itself is confusing when it comes to where you stand morally, but the core gameplay and what the game was made for (inspecting vehicles and determining entry) make up for the otherwise lackluster campaign.

I have a shelf-standard HP Victus Gaming Laptop with a 12th Gen Intel Core and an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3050. The game runs fairly smoothly on high settings. The only issues I have run into are a possible memory dump about 30-45 minutes into a play session. I recommend turning V-Sync off or lowering your texture memory to clear this up and regain frames.

All in all, play the demo first, as some people seem to have issues launching and playing the game, If it runs fine and you enjoy the mellow and almost assembly line feeling to the game - which I love, American Truck Sim is a favorite of mine - then pick this game up. It's a well-fleshed-out sim that is easy to hop into.

★★★★★ - 5 out of 5 Stars

(EDIT: Changed review to 5 stars because I JUST realized I can turn off the attacks that I hate in the options! That's genius!)

I played the demo long before the game came out, and I liked the demo SO much, I joined their discord to await news on the release date. Having now played the full game, I can definitely say it was worth the wait. 

This game is SO much like Papers Please, which I also loved, but a 3D version where you actually get to find contraband and arrest the bad guys yourself. There's no little potato man in this one, though. He was always my favorite.

I love going over the people's information, figuring out who is a smuggler and using a weapon to split over parts of the car to find contraband - it is REALLY satisfying to find it all. I could do that all day and not get sick of it. 

What I'm not a fan of; the gun fights when the rebels attack the border. I hate those so much, after this last one, I think I might be done playing. I'm also not a huge fan of having to drive around, especially with the driving being so wonky. I actually switch from keyboard and mouse to a controller to do the driving. 

But I love the finding contraband/upgrading the border part so much, I was willing to overlook the parts I hate and give this 4 stars. It's a super fun game and I'm glad it's getting love. Now if I could just customize my endless mode to not include the dang gun fights, I'd play this forever.

This is a magnificent game. It's stimulating, challenging, and requires the most thorough of thinking. The comparisons to Paper Please are warranted, and I loved that game also. But as someone who loved that game, I was also a bit worried about what direction Contraband Police would go. It didn't make it any better that it was yet another Unity game, which is ironic considering Papers Please was updated in the Unity engine. But I think you know what I mean. There's no shortage of janky simulations made in Unity that simply borrow the same assets from every other game. But my expectations of a jank broken game with half assed mechanics was completely unfounded, and honestly, kind of jerky on my part. Okay, not just kind of jerky.. Very jerky. 

Crazy Rock and PlayWay hit out of the park with this niche investigative simulator, and I commend them for it. This game is exhilarating! I love it. I absolutely love it. Criminals can be clever in the way they hide contraband, but it's not even just the contraband you need to watch out. Just like in Papers Please, you need to check their papers for forgeries, incorrect passport numbers, expiration dates, compare vehicle weight, keep an eye out for wanted criminals, and much more, *including* investigations and missions that take place in the game itself away from your border patrol! And many of these missions also lead into what is also my favorite part about this game.. The combat. Combat should not be as fun as it is for a game like this. You'd think it'd be an afterthought, but it's not. It won't be something along the levels of Escape From Tarkov, but it doesn't have to be. It's fun.

Now my absolute favorite inclusion is somewhat of a recent feature, and that is the endless mode! Which is something that the development team didn't even need to add, but they did! They added it, and it's addictive. In the campaign, you're allowed to upgrade your facilities like office, jail, and vehicles, but in endless mode, there's so much more to upgrade!

This game is truly exceptional, offering a captivating experience as you take command of a border crossing rife with criminal activity. However, its brilliance extends far beyond mere border control. Immerse yourself in the intricate world of strategic upgrades, where you have the power to enhance the entire border area. Brace yourself for unexpected challenges as you navigate through ambushes orchestrated by gunmen, while also managing the transportation of prisoners to a mining camp.

But that's not all – the game's depth unfolds as you embark on shopping sprees for weapons and supplies, turning your role into a multifaceted simulation. From confiscating contraband and transporting it to a secure holding warehouse to engaging in diverse activities that keep you on the edge of your seat, this game goes above and beyond expectations, delivering an expansive and immersive gaming experience. TLDR; Enhanced dyslexia and colorblind tester. 

An example of how a good indy game should be. Addictive gameplay loop, that progressively challenges you, various side activities and on top of that a small campaign based on your actions. It recreates the atmosphere of the cold war era and while visually definitely not next-gen, it does give off that old skool games look of the early 2000's with a modern filter on top. 

Love that look of drivers humorously rolling down their windows. And many other quirks in the game. I have not experienced any bugs but beside that one time my cars drivewheels got air while my tail was dug in a small hill, due to my own fault. I had a prisoner inside and couldn't get anywhere. Luckily this game has fast travel and this reset my vehicle and I could continue my mission without restarting. I would not recommend fast travel for anything else than fixing a stuck position, the campaign only last about 16ish hours without fast travel for me. Completing all side-objectives and occasional equipment/contraband/prisoner-runs in the campaign. Do note, I got quite productive with checking cars, there are aids but I would not recommend this game if you have dyslexia or colorblindness. It will turn into a point and clickgame if you use the aids too much and the game's charm is in finding the faults in the details you personally find. The only time I use the aid was to pinpoint the tints of colors. 

The game is not difficult per-se, but you will find yourself struggling if you try to rush things, prioritize your tasks and then take your time. The game luckily won't hold your hand too much but with a bit of logical thinking, structuring and utilizing the game's many manuals and tools you always have a grip on any situation. Practice makes perfect. You can always reload your day.

Some things that are a bit too rough around the edges like combat, can suck out the otherwise fluid gameplay loop. It's still nice to have combat as a break from checking and expanding on the campaign, but it doesn't work smoothly enough to be thrilling. Driving is barebones but the chases are a nice distraction anyway. One thing that was a bit too much were the color tints during checks. Im not colorblind but I would like it if i could compare tints of colors right next to each other. Now my manual opens on the right and the document is on the left. The only time I was able to distinguish colors were when it was a totally different color, but most of the time you have to identify small changes in tint from one end of the screen to the other.    

I recommend not upgrading too much too early, your income is based on your level and while you have the freedom to do anything you want, making things expensive early on will put a lot of pressure on you for not making any faults to survive another day. Slowly upgrade the things that you need the most. You will eventually level up and make more cash.

On a sale this is a ton of fun for the money. I prefer to have a short solid indie experience that delivers a specific niche/mood than an expensive politically safe triple A time sinker with too much fetchquests any time of the day.
It might be buggy and unpolished, but it is quite fun. To the point to where it becomes addicting.

MY ENTIRE GAME GOT ERASED

I was 92 days into inspector mode and then poof everything was gone. My achievements are still visible through steam but when I launch the game it asks me to start a new game and my previous game does not load. I'm very disappointed to say the least and will not be starting a new game.

Things you should know: There are 8 vehicles that may come through. A lot of the smuggle/contraband hiding spots are in the same locations no matter the car/truck. Each model has its own variation but 8 is just not enough. It becomes quite repetitive after just 6 hours. Arrests, chases, smugglers - they don't really vary. It's pretty much the same each time. Also, don't expect much in the way of upgrading the border station. Options are there, and they are helpful, but the place will forever look like a pile of garbage.

Now that said - I did have a good time. I beat the game, and while the story was seemingly an afterthought, the focus truly is on the gameplay, not the writing.

You're provided with a team of police who walk patrol around the property. They serve little to no purpose. The only time they do anything is during raids and they don't seem to aim well enough to ever hit their target. Expect to do ALL of the work when this happens and make sure you have the ammo and weapons to pull it off. 

Days/nights can run really short - this means if you are still inspecting cars/drivers late into the night, you may either get little or no sleep and the next work day will start. This leaves you with no energy to be able to use the assist functions during inspections. While not a huge deal - it does slow things down and makes it easier to miss things like age limits (where math is required) or making sure the color and style of paper match what that particular originating country uses.

It's a fun game and the inspections/review work isn't particularly hard. It has enough variety to keep you entertained for a while but it really needs more content. Even outside the main campaign - it's just more of the same. I do think this game is ripe for DLC expansions/content and I think that would go a long way in helping. That said, with the lack of content - it feels like whatever may come in DLC form should have been baked into the main game.

I wouldn't spend $20 on the game, but $15 is fair. It's a good time if you're into this kind of auditing/inspection simulation genre. I found it more entertaining than "Papers, Please". Having drivers decide to suddenly "f*** off" and run while you are inspecting their cargo off to the side can be fun to have to dizzily spin around and sprint to your police car to start the chase. Just don't kill the driver/smuggler - it will likely cost you a decent amount of cash as a penalty. The game does let you choose to side with the government, party, or the "good" of the people, and the ending will vary a bit depending on what path you choose.

I recommend it, just realize it's base price is $20 and that is mostly for good reason. There just isn't enough content to justify much more. Maybe wait until a DLC package? Rare to find a game like this. Worth your time.

Contraband Police is an interesting game. On one hand, you play as a border police officer, and you have to check each and every person who tries to enter the country. You have to pay attention to every detail in making the final decision (i.e. to let them in or not), which was kind of fun. On the other hand, you also get to roam around the area, and do other stuff, like take prisoners to the jail camp, or help the police fight certain attacks (in which case the game becomes more of a shooter). 
My only complaint is that it would have been better if the player could interact more with the open world and the other NPCs (e.g. if there were more dialogues available, or more side mission types, or more buildings to enter, etc).

Contraband Police introduces a captivating idea rooted in the real stories of bygone eras, providing a unique and enjoyable gaming experience. However, after diligently building border controls and engaging in routine inspections, the gameplay starts to feel somewhat repetitive, leading to moments of boredom. The potential for greatness lies in the hope for future updates that bring not only fresh content but also more challenging scenarios. I'm eager to see the developers expand on this intriguing concept, introducing varied challenges and ensuring that the gameplay remains dynamic and engaging. With a bit of evolution, Contraband Police could transform into a must-play for fans of simulation and strategy games.

Contraband Police is a captivating and innovative game that manages to provide an engaging and realistic gaming experience for police simulation enthusiasts. In a market saturated with similar titles, it stands out due to meticulous details and well-thought-out game mechanics.

One of the remarkable aspects of the game is its high level of realism. The detailed graphics and well-constructed open world provide an authentic feel to the life of a border patrol officer. Additionally, the attention to detail in vehicles, objects, and documents adds an extra layer of authenticity, creating a truly immersive experience.

The game mechanics are well-balanced, offering a combination of strategy, simulation, and action elements. The process of investigating and checking vehicles is a captivating element of the game, and players will quickly discover that making quick and accurate decisions can make the difference between success and failure.

Contraband Police also provides a variety of missions and tasks, keeping players interested throughout the game. From stopping illegal traffic to discovering contraband in vehicles, each task has its challenges and rewards, contributing to the variability and unpredictability of the game.

In addition to the gameplay itself, the developers' efforts to consider community feedback have been notable. Frequent updates and attention to detail demonstrate a commitment to constant improvement of the gaming experience.

In conclusion, Contraband Police is a game that should not be missing from the collection of any police simulation fan. With superb graphics, well-crafted game mechanics, and a high level of realism, this title offers a fun and captivating experience, taking police simulations to the next level.

[h2] this game is very repetitive, BUT: (spoiler free) [/h2]

[b] thats actually something i really, really enjoy about it. [/b] you unlock more things to inspect, more rules to follow, etc as the days go on, so i never felt that it stagnated at all. i was actually surprised at how complicated it eventually gets, lets start with the things i dont like first (and ill tie it all up with a lot more positive stuff at the end):

[b] - the environment, as others have mentioned, is pretty limited. [/b] and even more limited when you realise most of the buildings around are used for story only events, and have nothing intractable or explorable outside of said missions/story events. even just being able to go inside them would be something.

[b] - i wish there was more of a narrative/story, [/b] the game focuses mainly on the simulations and stuff to do with it, so some of the storylines fell a bit short to me. as well as half of the story missions usually consisting of shootouts.

[b] - building ontop of my last point, [/b] i wish the characters in the game had more... character. maybe little stories or something.


[h3] those are really my only things i feel about the game that i would call negative, ill move onto the positives: [/h3]


- [b] i mentioned that the game focuses on the simulation aspect in my negatives, [/b] but i am also going to list it as a positive because the simulation itself is realistic, in depth, and has a lot of parts, tricks, and rules that even after a while of playing i might not even have the hang of yet (which i personally find interesting and engaging). 

[b] - along with the campaign, which is what i am mainly speaking about in this review, [/b] there are two other gamemodes (as of this review) which i havent delved into quite yet myself, but i appreciate having multiple ways to play the game.

[b] - your choices and actions matter, [/b] your post directly relies on you for mostly everything, and which side you choose to side with changes a decent amount of stuff.

[b] - i find the game to be atmospheric [/b] and i enjoy the setting, music, and sound design. its gritty and somewhat solemn at times in a good way.

[b] - the gameplay is satisfying, [/b] you can progress in different ways including levelling up just from correct checks, as well as unlocking better tools, weapons, post upgrades, and new employees/upgrading your already existing ones.

[b] - you can customise a lot of what happens, [/b] you can turn off raids of your base or your car when you're driving around if you do not wish to have them happen, you can make the day(s) longer or shorter, enemy markers, smuggler tips, etc. you can make it a lot harder (or easier!) if you so wish, and i appreciate it even though ive not toyed with those settings too much.

[b] - you do get little bits of story here and there. [/b] mostly from the story missions, but also from letters from passengers, newspapers, and conversations with people as well.

overall a very good, interesting, and engaging game that i recommend heavily as long as you do not mind repetition. props to the developers for paying attention to what people were saying and fixing the bugs! i havent run into any at all yet! ive sunk a decent amount of time into this game already but it feels like the time never passes when im playing it, thats how engaging it is to me :).

The game tries to be 3d "papers please" with extra content but falls flat at the attempts.

Pointless tiny open world with no real reason to explore it. Money stashes are just radom piles scattered around with no clues given how to find them. 
Every day you know you gonna get ambushed by the same 4 bandits in the same locations. 

The checkpoint work never feels overwhelming, just 4 - 6 cars every day. The contraband could be easily spotted by using uv light, no variety in this. You get instantly rewarded or fined by letting the wrong cars pass, as if someone above just tests you. The game story is under told and makes it hard to feel weight of any of your actions and decisions. You never get the taste of how bad the government actually is. Couple hours into the game and you get all it could offer. Everything after that is just repeating over and over again.

Also the review of this game won't be complete without mentioning performance. It's terrible. Game does not look like much yet some locations like the main police station drop fps all the way down to 30.

I originally thumbed it down only because there was a bad bug where you would get stuck in an infinite loading screen, and stated in my original review that I would thumb it up when the devs fixed it. Well, if you've seen my thumbs up, it's because they fixed it; now onto my actual thoughts of the game:

I originally thought this game would be janky and boring, because I thought nothing would top "Papers, Please". But I have been extremely humbled and proven wrong. This game, though it does have its janks, is just as fun and great as "Papers, Please". I love the unintentional environmental storytelling: you are a new officer, trained to check passports and accept or decline newcomers. However, you are given a s**tty outpost that is built no better than the outhouse nearby your trailer home, given little supplies, and uninspired employees that rather being doing anything else because they get paid less than you. But that's not all! You are expected to not only arrest convicts, but take them to labor camps and deliver contrabands to the nearby prison warehouse. You must get your own supplies and pay for your own outpost and upgrade said outpost with your money, while the government bathes in their own treasures. Basically, they expect you to do the job of 6 people-- by yourself! Almost reminds me of another country.

The struggle is real if you are not careful with how you spend your money and manage you daily bills that accumulate as you upgrade your outpost and hire or promote your men.

Did I also forget to mention that you are a first responder? Whenever a compound is in trouble or a convict has escaped, you are responsible. You don't have to accept them-- but you need that money and those upgrades! Their is always something happening.

So shut up and do your job. Glory to Acaristan!

Pretty fun game, especially if you're the kind of person who likes Papers Please. This adds a little extra to the mix with upgrading parts of your border outpost, purchasing/upgrading additional officers to help during the inevitable shootouts (your outpost gets ambushed every so often by gang members. It isn't difficult especially with upgraded personnel, but from what I understand you can disable ambushes in settings), and purchasing different police vehicles to get around the map in during campaign missions. This is one of those games where you sink 3 or 4 hours in without feeling like you've blinked. 

My one and only complaint about this game thus far is that the ambushes while driving are broken. While you're transporting contraband or prisoners, you get ambushed by 4 gang members randomly from time to time. The issue I'm having is that there are times where I hop out and kill the dudes but the game still says I'm being ambushed and have killed 0/4 men. The music never reverts back to normal so I wind up inspecting cars with this tense combat music and it makes it a little more difficult. If the bugged ambushes get fixed, I really have nothing bad to say about this game!

As of right now, I can't recommend this game due to just how much work is still needed to get rid of gamebreaking bugs and glitches.

Restarting from checkpoint after failing or dying leads to an infinite loading screen and the only way to move on is to alt+f4 and then restart the day. 

Ambushes are bugged because enemies glitch through the map and are nowhere to be seen. This is more of a severe annoyance due to constantly being hounded by the combat music everywhere I go. Because there is an active ambush that is impossible to end, I'm unable to see any other objectives or move on to do anything else in peace.  

Also, I'm unable to melee attackers because my character gets into some kind of bugged state where my melee weapon never reaches the enemy despite the weapon being in their faces. (I've had this happen with the knife and the pitchfork already and I'm positive it'll happen with any other melee weapon.) I'm unable to switch weapons. I'm unable to interact with vehicles and the only way to deal with this is to alt+f4 and start the day over because reloading checkpoints is broken due to the infinite loading screen bug. 

I found out that the game loves to corrupt your save files and/or delete them automatically and there's nothing the player can do to prevent this from happening. Because of this, the only way to progress is by constantly restarting the day over and over and pray you don't get hit in the face by another game-breaking issue and you play absolutely flawless every day.

This is just a few of many game-breaking and severe issues this game has and it's mind-boggling how the devs never bothered fixing these problems and it's even more egregious how this game has so many positive reviews with so many game-breaking bugs. Apparently, people think games that are barely functional are masterpieces. I'm more convinced that content creators blow this game up so much and give the wrong impressions. 

Is the game good? No. I can't get through the first day because, I keep encountering countless game-breaking bugs one after another with no end in sight. Can it be good? Yes, if the devs actually get off their rear-ends and fix their game instead of riding the high of "success" and exposure it's been getting lately like every other studio that gets a spot of exposure and cares more about that than their own game does. 

I don't care what others say. The game is broken beyond belief and it's a miracle it even functions. These issues should have been dealt with a very long time ago.

Heyy everyone,

I'm back with another review. 

🚨 Contraband Police 🚓

I'll start with my review first with these words; buy this game without watching a video or reading anything like it. 'Cause most of the players will be like "3D Papers Please" or "Papers Please FPS". But that's not the case. I do respect the Papers Please title them as well.

Contraband Police starts like Papers Please at first we are border police, controlling returning and entering people's ID or passport cards. As the day comes forward, You will realize you are more than that. You will see yourself arresting criminals yourself and putting them behind Labor camps *cough* Ah.. Sorry, you will be putting them behind bars.

You will be in a constant firefight with the revolutionary group and criminals. Which I do find that a bit too much. Because after some time firefights start to bore you out. Like in the last 7 in-game days. I was in my Border Office till the end.







Some say DEVs are responsive to their community but I haven't got that chance even tho I did report a couple of visual and audio bugs. ( They never returned to me)

Also YES. The game is affected by your choices. For me, it was "Long Live The Party and Government". ✊

Until next time. Be safe everyone. ❤

Pretty fun way to waste some time. It is an interactive seek and find game and makes you look at little details. However I have noticed I am getting penalized for "missing" broken windows when there are no clearly broken windows. I think there are still some bugs to work out with respect to what the code says the vehicle defects are and what skins are showing up. Also not a fan of wasting a ton of my "day" chasing a runner and get paid peanuts for capturing them. In the time it takes me to chase down the runner I could have 2 other vehicles through the check point at 2.5 times the income. Please increase the bounty for catching a fleeing vehicle.
Do what you love and you will never work a day in your life. great game! Seasons Beatings!

This is why I prefer indies to AAA games. They are able to experiment in ways that AAA games have to play it safe to maximize profits and get a return on their investment. While it's true that CP is heavily inspired by Papers, Please, they do their own thing with the basics of running a border crossing in a fictional communist state. There are upgrades, a small variety of weapons, vehicles you get to drive, and a small town to explore. 

I played through the campaign, which didn't overstay its welcome, and I feel that I've had enough of CP but there are other modes to play if I get the itch again. Overall, the game is great and all of the positive praise in other reviews is earned, but I'm going to offer some criticisms for the sake of balance. (Too many reviewers on Steam are all or nothing. Either the game is awesome or it's terrible, but the reality is that even the best games have room for improvement.)

I really didn't enjoy the side missions that much. They felt a little tacked on and detracted from the outpost, which is where I had the most fun. The firearms did not feel accurate and I really wish the sniper rifle had a short scope but that may have made it OP. The car driving was not as tight as I would like, but with the gun and car mechanics, I couldn't really expect GTA-like tightness with a small dev team that was focused on getting the checkpoint game right, which they absolutely did. The aesthetics were bland, but I really don't expect first-person 3D indies to have mindblowing aesthetics. That stuff is expensive and time consuming to do.

I really hope CP sold well and we see a sequel with a bigger budget because this game rules and I can only see them improving on the formula in the future.

[h1] Time to take your car apart piece by piece for that one piece of contraband I know your hiding somewhere... [/h1]

[b] The Positive's [/b]
+ You Control Your Own Border Post
+ Decent Story Line 
+ Multiple Endings 

[b] The Negative's [/b]
- None Honestly 

[b] The Aspect Of The Game [/b]
[i] You are a new boarder officer in training put in charge of a boarder post on the "Karikatka" region. It is your job to rise through the ranks of your post by checking documents, escorting criminals to a work camp, or responding to emergency calls command. You may either stand with your country ruling party or the rebellion the choice is yours really. [/i]

[b] My Two Cent Review [/b]
[i] Ever since the game Papers Please came out I have been in love with document checking games and this game is no exception to that. While it may have that unity feeling of a bunch of free assets all mixed together it's actually a pretty fun game. You take on the shoes as a new boarder inspector in charge of the boarder post. As time progress of course you will be giving new directives to follow and your job will get progressively harder. On your free time you can use your money given to by the state or your trading affairs and either upgrade the boarder outpost, the boarder vehicles, boarder guards or your weapons and tools. During my play through there were plenty of story events that will let you either support the rebellion or the government party. I decided to support the government [spoiler] considering they saved my life from a rebellion criminal deal gone wrong [/spoiler] but that's just me. There were also several parts where you would tail someone or get into a gun fight with criminals which was also pretty fun as well. [/i]

[b] The Value Of The Game [/b]
[i] Twenty bucks is a fair price for the game after all I got 10 hours of enjoyment from it. While it isn't an amazing game it does do it's job well. [/i]

[h1] Final Score 75/100 Ranking C Tier [/h1]

I can't recommend this at the moment. It's got way too many problems that stand in the way of enjoying it.

Initially there is a good amount of checks that need to be made, but quickly you get completely overwhelmed with all manner of nonsense checks and it's far too easy to overlook something. It wouldn't be so bad if I could save the game whenever I wanted, but I can't. The game has no save function, only autosaving once per day.

Spending 10 minutes carefully checking off a bunch of stuff only for the person to drive off and then you get docked ~100 money for missing that they had a broken side mirror doesn't make me want to be more careful next time it makes me want to reload, and that means restarting the whole day as you can't save.

There are side quests, but I've not done any of them because the opportunity to take them seems to be literal seconds, and they occur right in the middle of a workday, sometimes right in the middle of when you're performing a check. Why? As a result I've rejected all of them.

Driving is buggy, my van has ended up hitting *something* and coming to a dead stop on multiple occasions. Plus any car chases or anything you do can lead you to the far side of the map, and then you've got a damn timer to get back to the border before you fail the day for some reason. TIMERS SUCK.

The checks themselves are often buggy. There's a game mechanic where you can click the name/date/whatever and have the game match it. Often when I've done that and the inspection report is clean I've marked the documents and approved, the person has driven off, then it's come up saying the name and date were invalid and I'm docked money. wtf? Again, this would cause me to reload an earlier save, but I can't.

Checking for illegal goods is buggy. There's supposed to be a marker on locations that indicate contraband, but often there isn't. So you'll do all the myriad of checks, find everything's all good, and wave the person off. Whoops you've just lost more money because there was contraband here there and everywhere, in all those places you checked and found nothing. AGAIN - this would make me reload an earlier save, WHICH I CAN'T.

There are a bunch of issues like this, most of which could be worked around by being able to save the game whenever I damn well please. I have no idea why these developers continue to make games with no ability to save the game. It's a basic function that should be in your game, and if it's a design choice, it's a stupid choice.

Finally, people are saying that the game is way too short. A game like this should provide 60+ hours gameplay at least, and apparently people are completing it in 11-15 hours. I wouldn't know though as I've not been able to force myself past 5 hours.

What a beautiful game , 
- Doesn't have a huge map. 
- Doesn't have lots of varieties of vehicles.
- Limited engagement withing the entirety of the map.
But I have to say, campaign missions reminded me of GTA IV as vague as that  may sound. Of course limited in fire fights and overall density of the game. But rather a pure , simple but challenging connection of the actual game ( Border Vehicle Inspection ) . 
Now here is the real issue with the game but it's not really an issue more of an identity crisis. 
As I said main part of the game is Border Vehicle Inspection . That part is very intricate and nicely designed I might add. It's perfectly set where you still scratch your head sometimes and even have that moment where you realize you messed up soon as you sent them on their merry way into the country.
The way the rest of the game works is basically as an extension , such as when they make a run or to turn prisoners in from jail. The dilemma here is , it's almost like there's two worlds , the Inspection Station and the rest of the map. You can't really do a lot without finishing your job at the station first , but then sometimes you gotta choose if you wanna arrest someone or go after a dispatch call in the map.
Having more things to do is good , extending on outside of the actual game to make it feel more realistic is also good , but the theme with games nowadays is to make it seamless between each part of the game. I think they can definitely improve on making the game feel a bit more complete as a whole .
In conclusion , 
The game is already a 9/10 in my book. Best $15 I have spent on a game in years. Feel like the value is definitely there.
Looks great , few bugs , doesn't feel like a failed game being released half way into production in best hopes. Can we also appreciate the fact that driving is halfway decent ( rare from indie companies nowadays ) . No it's not realistic but it's not the worst part of the game like so many others. Overall there's some things to improve upon like any game. I hope devs will show love in that aspect , but they also got so many things right that they could have messed up. 
I will update once i finish the game.

[h1]More love from the developer is not possible.[/h1]

[h2]A clear recommendation for me.[/h2] 
Give the boys your money!


Previous rating, which was taken apart by the developers through updates:

It is good with low replay value.
Making a decision about this game is proving to be quite challenging.
Don't get me wrong, the game itself is good and I definitely had a lot of fun playing it. However, there are certain mechanics and a lack of content that make it less than replayable. To better explain my thoughts, let me start with the playtime. It took me a total of 11 hours to complete the campaign. During that time, I made sure to transport prisoners, hand over illicit goods to the police, and buy "tools" from Vlad. These tools, like knives, pitchforks, and axes, come in handy when trying to find smugglers' hiding places. Vlad also sells tools that pack a bit more punch, which are especially useful when you're being attacked for the umpteenth time by the same group of people who relentlessly shoot at your car and just to get some headshots from you.

The main issue I have with this game is its lack of replay value. It's just not there, which is a real shame because the potential for it is definitely present. The planned infinity mode or one where you can expand your base further, which should have been implemented long ago would be perfect. I sorely miss these features. Additionally, I feel like the decisions you make throughout the game have little to no impact on the overall story. The base could also benefit from more improvements and the map could be designed with more attention to detail. 

Ultimately, it's the little things that bring the game down.

One of the most satisfying & immersive job sims I have ever played. Even with the level of detail required for the inspections, it's still a very relaxing experience. 

The game play loop is very engaging & addicting. The campaign was far more layered and entertaining than I anticipated. Had me hooked all the way through. NG+ was a nice touch as well. I really appreciate the endless Inspector Mode - I will continue to play that off & on for a very long time. Without it the replay value would seriously suffer.

I will say for someone going for achievements, it becomes very frustrating. Certain achievements just straight up don't unlock, even if the requirements are met. Specifically the achievements tied to events. Some of them I've earned five times over by now & they're still locked. I also don't appreciate the inability to manually save, as well as the scarce save points in general. Also, occasionally the game will incorrectly tell you that you missed something during an inspection when you didn't. Sometimes it will say you missed something like a missing bumper or broken window when you for sure didn't.

Overall, it has its bugs. The achievement bug is the only reason I won't 100% this game which is super annoying. But still, it's way more polished than I thought it'd be. Role playing is a blast, whether you take it seriously or not. PlayWay makes some gems, as well as some duds. This one is a gem. One of, if not their best sim yet.

A fun sim-work game. It does what it says on the tin and adds a little story that is cohesive and adds meaning to the game. Endless mode is fun as well and allows you to focus on whatever you want to do. 

Check the papers, clear them or reject them, anlyze each car in minute detail to try for a perfect inspection, go on missions, get ambushed, fight back, arrest criminals and collect contraband. It's all up to you.

There's still  a couple of bugs, but nothing that destroys the game (you might have to restart a day here and there if it locks up). The biggest issue is returning to the base when an road-ambush was still ongoing. This locked my game every time. So make sure you kill or escape it completely and lose the notification before heading in for the night.

The action side of the game itself is not too challenging and most of time you won't have to worry about dying or failing often, but that's OK.

In typical simulator-game fashion, the achievements are a GRIND to 100%, but they are all obtainable through natural play. They can be a bit janky in a couple of places. 
--Get all the roadblocks done on your first time through a save file 
--On the  contraband drop (endless mode) get all the crates BEFORE the bandits show up for Pacifist, if they spawn the achievement won't pop even if you don't attack them
--Patient zero is an RNG event inside an RNG event, it will show up but it might take longer than you think it would, Easily the most tedious achievement. 
--David vs. Goliath is probably the most fun to try and get. It was nice to be able to just reload the day and go back to the mission start to retry it--if you had to wait for a natural occurrence to get this one, the success rate would be even lower than it already is.

Contraband Police starts off really well. It has an interesting premise and it changes the formula enough so it is not a 100% copy of Papers, Please. Gameplay is not perfect but it is solid enough to do its job and the game design keeps it fresh by making it harder as you progress. Besides checking papers, you'll be driving around a small-ish map doing errands, buying ammo and tools, and working your way through procedural side quests every now and then. Most of the items on my checklist when I review a game are alright here, so I wouldn't say that there's anything particularly bad with this game. But also, there isn't anything particularly amazing.

For the first few hours, I was really liking Contraband Police, but the more I played, the more I started to get annoyed by it. I'm sure I don't have much until I finish it, but I've had enough. I literally have no interest in even watching a youtube video to see how it ends. This game falls in the category of "chill time passers", so if that's what you're looking for, this is your game. I personally don't like games to chill but rather than to immerse myself in experiences that will add value to me. And this game did it until it didn't. That's why I'm not finishing it and the reason I'm giving it a negative review.

Surpassed my expectations, I would liken it to Papers Please but with more bells and whistles.  While the main fun and focus is inspecting vehicles and documents (which is done very well, I would suggest not using the in-game auto-inspection mechanic as this makes game play too simple imo); You are not confined solely to the border post as you transfer contraband/prisoners, have shootouts, go out for tools and weapons etc.  

You might also have to chase a smuggler or defend your outpost from attacks, all the while upgrading the outpost with more/better guards and facilities.  There is also a story and in game you are given freedom to accept bribes or allow people to cross even if the paperwork isn't in order for whatever reason.

Overall, while some aspects such as the gunplay and upgrades feel a bit tacked on, it breaks up the loop of checking papers/inspecting vehicles rather nicely.  The game is also jank but not in an endearing way (Brigand Oaxaca, Xenus 2 etc) but in a cheap way, however for the sheer effort put into it and for the price ( I got it for 15 on sale) it is well worth it.  It is a simulator that actually tries and it easily could have been so much less in terms of content and certain aspects of detail.  

If you like puzzles, simulators or games that try to break the mold a bit, give this a try.

Overall great and immersive game, would absolutely recommend. Story is short, about 15 hours, and a little easy. However, you can play it multiple times taking different sides. There is also endless mode, and more content coming.

[spoiler]
A few thoughts to the developers:

First, shootouts are too easy. I feel I can stand there and never die, just pop headshot by headshot. The big red markers make these interactions point-and-click without any strategy, and they also break the immersion of no HUD. First time, I was out of ammo, but manged to knife 4 guys without too much resistance, and I think that shouldn't be possible. Being attacked on the road is just a nuisance, not a challenge. Especially late-game with good rifles and health, I can just stand in the middle of the road and click below the red markers, and that's it.

Second, there's too much driving back and forth. Granted, I normally drove my contraband and prisoners whenever there were 2+, not realizing I might as well wait for more, but it still seems excessive. Being able to deliver prisoners and contraband at both locations could alleviate this.

Third, spotting smugglers is a little too easy. They always leave that UV mark, and if there is a hint like partial registration number, once you see it it's almost always going to be a smuggler. Also, it feels unlikely that the authorities know something about every single smuggler. How about adding some extra smugglers, which don't give you penalty if not found, but a significant boost if found? Like an unknown smuggler.

Finally, I would like more stuff to spend money on. The later half of the game I was hovering 10.000-15.000, but the upgrades didn't feel too meaningful. Maybe more cars, or even smaller stuff like automatic car weighing, improved bulletin boards, or cosmetic upgrades, or even just having multiple outside parking spaces.
[/spoiler]

An excellent game in the right price, a "paper's please" style game transferred to first person where you take control of the border crossing of a fictional country in Eastern Europe. A game that can be played in story mode but also sandbox where you have to make decisions small (affecting the border) and bigger (affecting the story). Definitely recommended, I loved what they did with the character's spoken language it's much better when it's not English, Being able to upgrade your crew, living quarters and equipment and making periodic supply runs and errant after shift was a good touch as well, but I wish you had more time for that, maybe day lasting more than night?
Born from the concept of "Papers, please" and expanded from it, more diversity on mechanics and a bit more action. If that kind of game is your thing, just go for it.

It's fun and a good border guard simulator. But it screws up when it stops trying to be that. Gun play is pretty mid and fighting enemies just feels the same every time. Getting ambushed 2 or 3 times EVERY SINGLE TIME I LEAVE THE BORDER makes it more of a hassle. There's no point to upgrade anything as it just increases your expenses for barely improved guards. 

And every time I'm asked to leave the border for something it gets ridiculous. I'm probably a third of the way in and the game is having me solve a poorly translated murder mystery. It's confusing and a lot of the words don't seem to be translated to English right. I want to play a border guard simulator, not solve your 3rd rate murder mystery. 

Worth it half off maybe, if you have a larger than average tolerance for repetition of bad mechanics.

If you enjoyed Papers, please this game is a step up from that. No longer are you confined to a clunky 2-d screen, it's fully immersive in this one! The monotony of the day to day grind is broken up by random raids and side quests that give the game even more depth.

This game is surprisingly good. The gameplay is smooth and the atmosphere feels very authentic. It is a different theme but I can compare it with the Gas Station simulator in terms of authenticity. 

The game consists in checking out various travelers for correct or incorrect documents and applying different laws and regulations that may change from time to time due to the government's decisions. You also have various tasks to identify different smugglers based on minimal information which isn't as easy as you may think. You get money for every perfect check and you loose money for every invalid check.  
You can upgrade different things in the boarder station like the life meter of employees, the cars you use and weapons. Yes, you will need to fire the guns from time to time when the station gets attacked by smugglers or political factions or in different missions where you come face to face with the bad guys.

The game has campaign mode and infinite mode but multiplayer will be added later as it shows in the game starting menu. I recommend this game. You really have to be careful which one you let pass and which one you arrest. it is not so easy to make this decisions in some cases.

I went into this thinking it would be like Papers Please but open world but after 12 hours and 76% progress (according to the menu) I can't bring myself to play it anymore. It's fun for the first few hours but it gets REALLY boring around half way through.
Here are the main issues I have with the game:
1. It's too easy. This goes for both the actual gameplay itself and the enemies you can encounter. I did 112 inspections throughout my play though and only failed 3 of them. At least one of those I remember occurring because I forgot what the chapter entry regulations were. Regardless of that though, 3 fails out of 112 is way too easy. In Papers Please I'd struggle to get through the day with less than two citations which made the game a lot more intense. The issue is not just that it's easy but also the lack of consequences and risks of failing. The day is defaulted to over half an hour and you only need to inspect 5-6 cars a day so there's no sense of danger. I also never felt at risk around enemies since they have terrible damage, accuracy and they also stand still most of the time. If you're carrying prisoners to the labor camp then you'll likely get ambushed by... 4 people. The amount of ambushers never changes throughout the game so by the end I was deciding whether to get out and melee them all to death or just straight up ignore them. It's also pretty amusing how they just spawn in out of nowhere on the middle of the road when you're driving.

2. Atmosphere and 'Story'. Despite the fact this game has a Dystopian setting, it really doesn't feel foreboding. Infact I'd say it feels more like a summer vacation in the forest as the only POI that actually involves something dystopian is the labor camp. There's no named characters that travel through your checkpoint which have any impact on gameplay with the exception of some angry and pretty cringy notes left in your mailbox that look like ragemail a 12 year old might send to you. 

3. Repetition and Gameplay. Like I mentioned earlier, it's fun for the first few hours however the gameplay remains unchanged for the next 10 which turns it from an enjoyable point and click game to a slog. Papers Please worked because it was short... and because it didn't have all of the other issues this game has. Whilst you're wading through the slop of repetitive npcs that say the same couple of voicelines and react the exact same when they're denied/accepted, you'll occasionally be requested to help in a mission. These missions consist of going somewhere on the map, killing a few bad guys and finding some guy in distress or digging up a bit of contraband. Actual Far Cry tier missions. This is in addition to the boring gameplay, clunky gunplay and overall ease of the game itself. There were two missions that stood out, one for the better and one for the worse. The good one being where you're brought to a crime scene and you need to interrogate a list of suspects to figure out who is the murderer. It's a good premise but it was executed rather poorly. For example if you choose the wrong person as the suspect, the real murderer will kill you instantly out of nowhere. I don't think I need to explain why this is stupid but I may as well anyway. By killing you, the murderer instantly tells everyone in the area that one of the two people YOU chose to let free is the actual perpetrator, giving himself away immediately. It also would make no sense for him to kill you as your blunder is the sole reason he's able to escape from any form of punishment. Had this been executed properly, I think that the game shouldn't have told you that you messed up and the real murderer would return later in the game to attack the camp with a group of actually threatening terrorists, or just have him scripted to silently kill off some of your generic npc friends that you had no emotional connection to because they were as bland as the average passerby.

4. Characters. Like I've already mentioned countless times, there are no real antagonist/allies or really any characters that are actually interesting. Every NPC acts the exact same and the 'bad guys' who ambush you are potentially the most generic adaptation of villians I've ever seen in a game. 

Now that I've gone over the main issues that I had in the top of my head, here are some of the things that I think would have made the game a lot better.

1. Ambushes: Instead of 4 enemies spawning 10 meters away who are about as dangerous as the AI drivers you encounter every so often, they should have made actual ambushes. For example, placing something on the road, which isn't easy to notice, that would damage your vehicle to an extent where you cant just drive away. Upon doing this, you'd be attacked by a significant number of actual enemies that know how to shoot a weapon. You would have to make use of the cover of your vehicle to take them down before they overwhelm you.

2. Gunplay: The only thing that desperately needs improving is the sound design because it's absolutely abysmal. It would also be pretty nice if the shotgun didn't take up your entire screen.

3. Atmosphere: I think the game would be more immersive if it felt like you were trapped in a miserable landscape instead of a stock desktop background. Polluted terrain, rampant disease, lack of cleanliness and harsh npc superiors.

4. Gameplay: Make it so you HAVE to get through all the vehicles on time or you're punished severely, we can't have lazy employees at this job. The punishments could, and I think should, have significant gameplay effects. Either add more vehicles per day, or preferably make the day shorter. I think you should also perform your job through at least part of the night where raids and vehicles ready to ambush you could spawn. I never bothered nor needed to use the perception tool when viewing passports so that could be reworked into another skill.

5. Enemies: It would be nice if enemies were actually dangerous. I don't think simply increasing the damage fixes it either as they have terrible coordination. Make it so they work as a group instead of a bunch of individuals who didn't know what they were doing 5 minutes earlier. For example, some throw grenades whilst others cover and they approach you whilst fighting instead of standing around in the open shooting once every few hours.

TLDR: It's fun for a few hours but becomes incredibly boring due to many issues. Was it worth the price? Personally, no.

Title: "Contraband Police: A Riveting Dive into the Shadows of Smuggling"

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Contraband Police takes you on a thrilling ride through the clandestine world of border control, smuggling, and corruption. Developed by Crazy Rocks Studios, this indie game offers a unique blend of simulation and strategy that sets it apart in the vast landscape of Steam titles.

From the moment you don the uniform of a border patrol officer, the game immerses you in the gritty reality of a checkpoint officer's life. Your task is simple on the surface: inspect vehicles, verify documents, and ensure the safety of your nation. However, as you delve deeper into Contraband Police, the complexities and moral dilemmas begin to unfold.

The game's visuals may not be cutting-edge, but they effectively convey the atmosphere of a bleak, post-Soviet setting. The attention to detail in the environments, from rusty vehicles to dilapidated buildings, adds a layer of authenticity that enhances the overall experience. The haunting soundtrack further complements the mood, creating an atmosphere of tension and uncertainty.

Contraband Police shines in its gameplay mechanics. The inspection process is surprisingly intricate, requiring careful scrutiny of documents, vehicle compartments, and even the occupants. Each decision carries consequences, as turning a blind eye to illegal items may lead to personal gain but risks the safety of your nation. Balancing the ethical tightrope is a constant challenge, making every playthrough a unique experience.

The game's narrative unfolds through a series of events and choices, shaping the trajectory of your career and the fate of those around you. The branching storylines add replay value, encouraging multiple playthroughs to explore different outcomes. The writing is compelling, offering a nuanced exploration of morality, corruption, and the impact of your choices on the world around you.

While Contraband Police excels in many aspects, it is not without its flaws. Some players may find the learning curve steep, especially in the early stages, and the lack of a comprehensive tutorial might leave newcomers feeling a bit overwhelmed. Additionally, a few bugs and glitches may hinder the experience, though the developers have shown dedication to addressing these issues through regular updates.

In conclusion, Contraband Police is a captivating addition to the simulation genre, offering a thought-provoking exploration of the moral gray areas surrounding border control. Its unique blend of strategy, simulation, and narrative depth make it a standout title for those seeking an immersive and challenging gaming experience. While not without its quirks, Contraband Police is a noteworthy indie gem that deserves a spot in the library of anyone fascinated by the complexities of law enforcement and moral decision-making.

In "Contraband Police" you play as a boarder guard, and you're tasked with not only vetting potential visitors, but also transporting prisoners to labour camps, contraband to the police depot, defending the boarder post from attack, paying your employees (as you are the one in charge), paying the daily rent and other costs of a boarder post, stopping any runners, and doing any other tasks that is required of you.

Oh and by the way, most semi-modern computers can run "Contraband Police" at a satisfying framerate, though do try the demo first if you arent sure.

Wow, 6 years I've heard of and anticipated this game. It's finally here, I'm not completely finished with the 30 days yet, probably a little over half way, but I can say they hit the spot with the inspection aspect. It's very much like Paper's Please, but way more satisfying, getting to look through people's cars, luggage, documents. It's all very well done.

HOWEVER, there is a few downsides, and the downsides are quite substantial despite the foundation of this game being great. The absolute biggest gripe I have, is a lack of an endless mode. Not only did it not come with release, but it sounds like it'll be added as a separate mode through the main menu, possibly ONLY the inspection element. Honestly, it's nice that the game breaks up the pace with needing to sell contraband, get tools, and bring prisoners to a labor camp when your prison gets full. I really just wanted the "endless mode" to come with the story, as most sims tend to do, use a story as a sort-of tutorial, and then leave you forever on your own. THAT is what I want above everything else. I'm expected to enjoy going back to the very beginning where I have nothing, it's on super easy mode when it comes to the inspection as you only have like 3 things to look for. What is that?? Genuinely think the endless aspect should've come with launch. This alone nearly makes this review a downvote.

The ambushes are also one people are complaining about, they do become annoying with the frequency. I don't think they're necessarily hard, just annoying. The combat is entertaining and challenging without being stupid; however, no headshots? You HAVE to shoot dead center mass, a bullet to the head just goes straight through. Makes for some annoying times when I can only see their head, but have no ways of shooting them. 

Overall, this game is well-done. It has some big flaws, but with some updates (that hopefully don't take as long as it took to make this game) it should go from good to superb. I really just hope the endless mode is implemented well; without it, this game's replay value is lacking.

EDIT: After very long silence from the developers besides just saying, "There will be an endless mode". There really wasn't much communication as to what it entailed, how it would work, when it was coming... However, now that it's released, it is everything that I needed to push this game into the "absolutely worth it" category. Paper's Please 3D, but with emphasis on contraband. The "inspection" mode was implemented very well. For what is currently included, despite the developer hiatus, this game deserves a thumbs up!

While I would say that this is a great game to kill time with as is I can not recommend it at full price because I feel there are some ultimately menial things that detract from the game play as well as some bugs.
Don't be surprised if you find instances where what you actually find does not match what the report claims to be true, for example a vehicle is missing two fenders but after you turn it in it claims it was only missing one, or it claims there was more contraband where you already picked it up from and none was left.

*General AI :
- AI coming to the checkpoint and driving on the map have a tendency to not use their lights even when it is dark enough they should.

* Checkpoint Runners :
- The subjects who jump back into their truck the moment you hop out after finding contraband and flee while you can take no action to stop them from doing so other than to kill them and get the murder flag prompt is annoying. (At this point the moment they move for the truck I run to the gate and shoot them through the windshield the moment the alarm siren starts to go off as they are free game at that point.)
- The subjects who just simply never stop and simply bash through the gate are even worse. There should be a tire spike or bollard system to stop these at one of the upgrade stages for the secondary gate.

* Contraband Hiding Places :
- Contraband has a tendency to be hidden in the same places on vehicles every time even though the vehicle has other places that it could be hidden (lack of randomization), as well as not making use of potential hiding places in several of the vehicles.
- Spare tires should be removable like cargo to make inspections easier.
- Vehicle doors could have removable interior panels allowing items to be concealed within them instead of a single solid object.
- Grazduk A&B : hide contraband between the cargo box and spare tire behind the cab?
- Grazduk : hide contraband in the gap between the frame and the mounts for the cargo box and spare tire behind the cab?
- Ilich 57 : Hide contraband between the frame and cargo carrier, this could be secured by tape?
- Zagr 53 : hide contraband in the medical kit under the passenger side dashboard?

* Paper Inspections :
- Having the NPC stand outside the car on the scale removes them from the weight calculation skewing the number (bug?)
- Add VINs to vehicles and a list that can be retrieved from the office in the morning of stolen vehicles VINs to look out for, or even just to verify the vehicle's VIN matches the registration.
- Once you realize the subjects name is wrong on one document it doesn't matter if you notice it is wrong on multiple forms as it is only a singular check point on the report. (Obviously this applies to other fields as well but I am using the name as an example.)  I feel that a multiple column checklist with Icons or abbreviations for each of the documents actually making you check each one rather than just finding the one name error and writing the rest off would be more immersive and rewarding.

* Tools :
- Tool durability is an example of just because you could doesn't mean you should, it is purely an annoyance.

* Ambushes & Checkpoint Attacks :
- Ambushes happen way to frequently when you have them turned on, like multiple times in one trip. (thank you for the off option, but they really should just be scaled back.)

* Checkpoint Personnel :
- The guy responsible for reloading cargo (Maximov)  wandering around gets old very quickly. If I have cargo unloaded he should be right there and waiting for me to tell him to reload it, he is supposed to be an 'assistant', not wandering around to take five hundred smoke breaks.
- These guys could be more useful if they reacted and did anything to help stop the idiot smashing through our checkpoint. For example the mechanic could hop in and ride with you to chase them and drive the subjects vehicle back to finish the inspection, or they could fire at the vehicle smashing through the checkpoint.
