Contraband Police - A Fresh Take on a Familiar Concept

Contraband Police is a new entrant in the gaming scene that puts an intriguing twist on the well-known concept of border control gaming, taking inspiration from "Papers, Please." While it carries some echoes of the cult classic, Contraband Police attempts to break new ground by transitioning from the 2D world of paperwork and stamps to a fully immersive 3D environment with a story-driven narrative. The game also introduces some novel features, such as daily quests in its endless mode, that add variety and challenge to the gameplay.

The transition to a 3D world is undoubtedly one of the game's highlights. Contraband Police immerses you in a detailed border crossing, where you must scrutinize vehicles, inspect cargo, and interact with people, making the experience much more interactive and immersive. The move from a flat 2D world to a 3D environment is a natural progression, allowing players to feel like they're genuinely at a border checkpoint.

However, where Contraband Police falls a bit short is in its storytelling and the emotional connection between the player and the characters. In "Papers, Please," there was a constant moral dilemma as you faced desperate people trying to enter the country. The game would only penalize you if you made too many mistakes, which allowed for more empathy towards the characters. In contrast, Contraband Police's approach of deducting money right away lacks the same emotional impact. Perhaps implementing a similar system to "Papers, Please," with warnings or citations before financial penalties, would enhance the emotional depth of the game.

Additionally, one aspect where "Papers, Please" outshines Contraband Police is in its reintroduction of memorable characters. "Papers, Please" featured characters like Gorgi, whose humorous and memorable interactions with the player provided levity in an otherwise tense atmosphere. Contraband Police could benefit from incorporating more character-driven moments to create a stronger bond between players and the individuals seeking entry into the country.

Another area that needs improvement in Contraband Police is the behavior of NPCs. Currently, they seem to serve little purpose as they merely stand around until a border attack occurs. Enhancing the role and interactivity of NPCs could make the game world feel more dynamic and lively.

I love this game, I really do, but I don't think it's quite there yet. You should definitely still give it a try but I feel like this game needs a touch more time to roast in the oven that is game development.

[h1]Just like a real border guard experience[/h1]
Like "Papers, Please" in 3D and with guns. This is the gist of it, but because it is easy and lazy to just compare a game to some other popular game and it is not only that, I will say a bit more. [i]Edit a bit later: I had more to say down there, but after writing what felt like the script to a 40 minute video I decided to keep my old TL:DR as my main review.[/i]

[b]This game forces you to check papers, manage (more like upgrade) and defend your borderpost, and follow along on a story about revolution. It is a bit like an arcady simulation game of the job as a borderpost guard in a fictional (presumably) soviet state. Combining action from the FPS genre and meticulous detail checking (more or less for each detail) from border guard simulation is pretty fun and a new spin. Definitely recommending this game, escpecially after it receives the two other modes besides the campaign.[/b]

Cheap indie simulators are usually the type of games that make me wanna quit gaming. They always have interesting ideas on paper but are made half-arsed. This one, however, is genuinely a pleasant surprise.

As other reviews have said, this is basically Papers Please in 3D with real graphics (pretty good ones actually), cars, guns, shops and inventories, etc. You manage a border control post that can be upgraded to make your work easier and more efficient. Your main task is to check vehicles going through the border, looking at their IDs, permits, checking their cargos, vehicle conditions, making sure they adhere to all the entry policies that change as the story progresses - and of course, as the name suggests, a big part of your job is to search suspicious vehicles for contraband like illegal weapons, cigarettes, drugs, counterfeit money and so on. They can be hidden anywhere in the car or in the cargoes, and you need to use specific tools to crack them open. You get rewarded by performing accurate checks and penalized if you fail to turn back cars with problematic paperwork or arrest smugglers trying to bringing in contraband. There are also side quests that you do outside of the border post like clearing a gang point or rescuing a fellow police officer, etc. The money you earned can be used to upgrade your border control station, buy new police cars, buy guns, and more tools. So, basically that's the game loop. Overall it's designed fairly well I would say, very well paced, and keeps you wanna to continue playing. There is also a main story, which is bull$hit and really serves no purpose other than giving your some backgrounds and providing some excuses for the game to progress. To me, the biggest draw of this game is just the simple task of performing border control. It's the same game mechanic that makes Papers Please such an interesting game. There is something satisfying and soothing about methodically going through the paperwork, checking the cargoes and vehicle, and then applying the "Approved" or "Denied" stamp. Very immersive, indeed.

You also have radiant events like drivers forcing their ways, people trying to bribe you, midnight bandits attack, etc. Gun play is also not bad for a game like this. You can nitpick about how the game becomes a little repetitive towards the end, but for the price it asks for, this is an easy recommend.

Great simulation game. Get progressively more challenging. You are in your own little open world, not just a post. You get into basic gunfights and some sneak missions. You can pick the Governments side or the Terrorist side.

This game is a lot of fun. I spent almost 40 hours completing the campaign and inspector modes (unlocked everything). Good value for money. The game is primarily about inspection so don't expect a premier shooter experience. The graphics are not flashy but there is enough detail that I didn't really care. I had the odd crash but it did not affect my experience.

Positives:
- Lots of hiding spaces for contraband - check everywhere!
- Car chases where you have to P.I.T. cars off the road to stop them.
- Shootouts (no scopes which can be a little painful)
- Lots to upgrade in Inspector mode.
- There is a large variety of checks to conduct with enough variables on the daily intel board to keep you on your toes.

Rather than talk about any negatives, I'll mention some suggestions that I think will improve the experience:
- During car chases have an option for AI to deploy a stinger/roadblock up ahead for a cost.
- Add a basic 2x scope to the long rifle and red dot to the automatic rifle.
- Reduce handling on evading vehicles if a tyre has been shot out/is flat.
- Increase the speed (vary the handling) of the other vehicles (I found that I just bought the fastest vehicle early on as there was no use for the slow ones).
- Either have a second page of inventory (purchasable upgrade) or add a separate inventory space for weapons and tools.
- Save game option - at this time the game only saves once each morning when you wake up.
- The daily mission to sell contraband needs a bigger reward or less contraband requirements. As it stands it isn't worth the hassle to wait until you have the right amount. Its more convenient just to hand over to the guard.
- Some clarity on when accepting a bribe will be detected or not detected. Sometimes I could get away with it, sometimes not. Is this a random risk?
- The final upgrade to your sleeping quarters should max out your perception most times. I find with the final upgrade to roads, i was spending longer on the line and my perception would barely touch the final bar after sleep.

Overall, a great game for the price. I look forward to seeing what updates are implemented and where the game can go.

The game is very fun and it sure does have all the soviet vibe in it. It does not hide atrocities and mistakes of a communist country like the Soviet Union in the 80s, but at the same time it does an amazing job of demonstrating the life of honest police officers fighting rebels who are more often than not supported and financed enemy neighbours and whose methods tend to be worse and more subversive than those of the government they oppose. The game have a unique style and act almost as more investigative papers please. It does not have the philosophical and criticism that papers please often provide with its emotional impact, but it does have a small storyline which is also very interesting and very fun to play through as an introduction to the much beloved "endless mode". I really recommend the game for people who enjoy a full on 70's / 80's Soviet aesthetic doing the work of a police border patrol inspector and commander whose action and dedcisions sometimes impact the country more than people realise.

Addicting gameplay of probing through cars, while deciding in your head to be the good guy or bad guy.
Do you let the driver in to complete his late transport run, or shoot his door off its hinge and drag him out for a righteous beating?

Truly one of the games of all time.

This game impressed me a lot! Definitely an improvement to Papers, Please with a higher budget. I think the design aspect where you need to inspect the cars for defects (starts a little later into the campaign) was a brilliant move that gets you to pay attention to details that would otherwise go entirely unnoticed, very fitting for this sort of puzzle game!

There's a certain side quest event (which I will not spoil here; it was such a pleasant surprise) that brings you to the Drunken Bear Inn for the first time - which just blew me away!

The game's not perfect yet. I especially think it could do with much more dialogue and memorable characters, but I got a lot more than I was expecting out of this game!

E.g. you could implement an information system, where you spent  money to unlock more hints for smugglers, have a reputation system with the Barkeeper, Vlad and maybe the Contraband buyers. Right now you just have a bigger set to upgrade compared to the campaign, but after around about 30 days you should be maxed out there too. 

All in all I would give this game 4/5 stars, it is a really fun game worth the money, while there are still a few things which could be improved or expanded on. Another positive note: I haven't encountered a single bug, only some rare pathing issues here and there.

Contraband Police throws players into the demanding role of a border inspector, tasked with uncovering contraband and maintaining order. Here's what sets this game apart:

🛃 Immersive Border Inspection - Attention to Detail 🧐🚛
The game excels in its attention to detail, providing an immersive experience in border patrol. You'll thoroughly inspect vehicles, documents, and cargo to uncover illegal goods.

📝 Story Mode - A Glimpse into the Border Inspector's Life 📦🔍
Contraband Police introduces a story mode that delves into the life of a border inspector. The narrative adds depth and context to your actions.

🚗 Diverse Vehicles - A Variety of Challenges 🏎️🚚
The diverse range of vehicles you inspect ensures that each encounter is unique. From cars to trucks, you'll encounter a variety of challenges.

🏭 Realistic Contraband - Challenging Puzzles to Solve 💼🕵️
The game presents realistic contraband items, turning inspections into challenging puzzles to solve. It's a true test of your observational skills.

Contraband Police is an immersive and challenging border patrol simulator that demands attention to detail. The addition of a story mode enriches the experience, and the variety of vehicles and contraband items ensure that every inspection is different. If you're up for the challenge and enjoy testing your powers of observation, this game is well worth your time. 🧐📝🔍🛃🚛📦🚗💼🏎️🕵️🚚🏭🎮

Contraband Police, while promising in concept, leaves players with a mixed experience. Set in a detailed open world, you step into the shoes of a border control officer, inspecting vehicles for contraband. The game's attention to realism is commendable, from inspecting documents to searching vehicles meticulously. However, the gameplay often feels repetitive, lacking variety and depth. The interface can be clunky, hampering the overall experience. While the game captures the tension of the job, its potential is undercut by monotonous tasks and technical shortcomings, making it a 5/10. Its a good choice for players seeking a truly engaging simulation experience.

Contraband Police is a game that offers a distinctive and intense immersion into the world of border security and law enforcement. With its focus on realism and the challenges of inspecting vehicles and identifying contraband, this title provides a unique experience that's both thrilling and educational.

The core premise of Contraband Police revolves around your role as a border control officer, inspecting vehicles, identifying illicit items, and making decisions that can impact the safety and security of your fictional nation. The game's realism is evident from the get-go, with a vast array of vehicles to inspect and a variety of tools at your disposal to assist in your work.

The tension and excitement that come with each inspection cannot be understated. The sense of urgency when identifying potential contraband and making quick decisions keeps you engaged, even if you're facing the same task repeatedly. The feeling of discovery when you uncover hidden items or catch a suspect in a lie is immensely satisfying.

The game's graphics and audio add to the overall immersion. The environment is suitably gritty and realistic, creating a convincing portrayal of a border checkpoint. The sound design, from the engine hum of vehicles to the detailed inspection sounds, adds to the atmosphere.

However, it's important to note that Contraband Police's realism can also be a double-edged sword. The game's complexity and the need to follow correct procedures might overwhelm some players, especially those new to the genre or looking for more casual gameplay.

Additionally, the pacing can be slow, and the gameplay loop may feel repetitive to some players. If you're not captivated by the detailed inspection process and the constant scrutiny of documents and cargo, you may find the game less enjoyable.

In conclusion, Contraband Police is a game that stands out for its dedication to realism and its focus on the intricacies of border control and law enforcement. It offers a thrilling and educational experience, immersing players in the daily tasks and challenges faced by those in this profession. While it may not cater to everyone's gaming preferences due to its complexity and potentially repetitive gameplay, it's a fascinating opportunity to explore the world of border security and contraband detection. If you're interested in the subject matter and are looking for a unique and immersive simulation, Contraband Police is well worth a closer look. It's an engaging experience that may just leave you feeling like a real officer on the thin blue line.
I especially enjoy the new endless mode. The possibility to switch some features on and off mid game, let you tailor your game experience to what you like most for your current mood. Great!

Game is exactly as advertised. Fight random terrorist attacks and ambushes, arrest smugglers (or anyone for that matter) or enemies of the state. Detailed checks of cars will net you a nice bonus, or you can just turn someone away at the slightest discrepancy in the paperwork and still get paid for doing the bare minimum. Sell illegal contraband on the side to drivers for more cash, sell your confiscated drugs (and prisoners, slave labor FTW) for MORE cash, and enjoy a true "open world" feel.

You can replay this a ton without feeling bored, can be as righteous or corrupt as you want to, and is just plain fun. I'm currently working on the rest of the achievements for this game, which is a rarity for me!

I'd be happy to provide a review for "Contraband Police," a video game released in 2021. Please note that my information is based on knowledge available up to September 2021, so there may have been updates or changes to the game since then.

Title: "Contraband Police: A Gritty Dive into Border Enforcement"

Rating: ★★★☆☆ (3/5)

"Contraband Police" offers a unique and gritty simulation experience, taking players into the challenging and morally complex world of border enforcement. While it has its strong points, the game does come with some notable drawbacks that affect the overall gameplay.

Immersion in Law Enforcement: The game excels in immersing players in the role of a border police officer. The attention to detail in recreating the everyday tasks and responsibilities of a border patrol agent is commendable. The developer's dedication to realism is evident in the game's mechanics, such as inspecting vehicles, interrogating travelers, and searching for contraband.

Moral Dilemmas: "Contraband Police" effectively explores the moral dilemmas faced by border officers. You'll be forced to make decisions that can have significant consequences, and the game doesn't shy away from presenting complex choices. This adds a layer of depth and authenticity to the gameplay.

Challenging Gameplay: The game can be quite challenging, especially for players who enjoy a realistic and demanding experience. Keeping a close eye on details, managing your resources, and making judgment calls can be intense and rewarding.

Limited Scope: Unfortunately, "Contraband Police" suffers from a somewhat limited scope. The gameplay can become repetitive as you repeat similar tasks over and over. There's also a lack of variety in the types of vehicles, travelers, and contraband you encounter, which can make the experience feel monotonous after a while.

Technical Issues: As of my last update in September 2021, "Contraband Police" had its share of technical issues, including occasional bugs and performance problems. It's worth checking if these issues have been addressed through updates.

Niche Appeal: The game's focus on realism and its niche theme might limit its appeal to a specific audience. If you're looking for a fast-paced action game, "Contraband Police" may not be your cup of tea.

In conclusion, "Contraband Police" is a simulation game that successfully immerses players in the world of border enforcement and poses intriguing moral dilemmas. However, its limited scope and potential technical issues may deter some players. If you're a fan of simulation games and enjoy a challenging, realistic experience, "Contraband Police" is worth considering, but it may not be for everyone.

Update 10/16/23: New review of the Endless Mode is in progress, I will be wiping this one and be writing a new one after completely reevaluating the game.

Update 3/25/23: The devs are making steady progress with the weekly patches which look very promising, they have released 3 so far that address SOME of the concerns, I will keep an eye on further patches and will be personally waiting a little bit longer to try the game again (most likely when the "Free Mode" releases).

They took the Papers Please concept and ran with it, adding management systems and a semi-open world as well as it being a 3D game of course.

Let me just summarize the good. 
The game adds enough to the idea of Papers Please to still be original and refreshing like having vehicles to check as well as cargo in those vehicles, the border post upgrades are also nice and give you a sense of progression if only slight.

The core gameplay loop is very addicting as someone who loved Papers Please, at first I hated the management tasks you had to do but it grew on me when I looked at the game as less of a Papers Please clone and more of it's own thing.

Now the annoyances.
The Ambushes (Just disable them), I never found a need to participate in them, I just drove right past them and did not care, I wasn't punished for it and I never felt like I needed to just stop everything I was doing to get out of my car and deal with them, maybe make them mandatory like a tree is down in the road (already an rng mechanic) ya know... like an actual ambush.. or just get rid of them entirely cause they were just an inconvenience.

The Tools, I guess since everything else was managementified they had to make the tools break over time so you have to buy new ones whenever yours breaks you better hope you have a spare in your storage when one of them breaks or else you aren't getting that sweet contraband and you will miss out on some money.

SEMI-Open World, the main missions obviously are mandatory to beat the game but they don't let you choose when you can do them and they randomly show up.. like in the middle of an inspection (at least they give you 5 minutes to accept the mission so you can finish your current inspection). If someone drives through the checkpoint or flees from an inspection once you catch them they give you 5 minutes to get back to your post and you feel rushed to gather all the contraband out of the criminal's vehicle and that's if you decide to grab that contraband for the extra money, now I do think that the 5 minute time limit is okay to do anything around the map, you definitely feel rushed when there is that time limit on the screen.

Finally the major cons.
Trading.. I found it to be completely useless once you are in mid-game as it doesn't make you enough money to be even worth your time plus depending on how many items you buy to trade it takes up inventory/storage space that could be used to store extra tools.

The Money Balance, I never felt like I was struggling for money to be honest (like how you feel in Papers Please), the lowest I got was -$47 at the very start, also by the end of the game like the last week I was so loaded I had no idea what to do with the money, once you get all the upgrades for the border post there's nothing really major to spend your money on so you just have too much of it, I was calling transports and supplies just because I could.

The Gunplay, half the time my shots never landed cause the iron sights are so off so that was very annoying (I'd like to mention I have an ultrawide monitor and maybe the ultrawide support is bugged to make the iron sights be slightly off? I'm not entirely sure, I hope the devs look into that), also I never felt like I needed to use a different gun (I tried all the guns the iron sights were still off) because the pistol one shots pretty much every enemy if you shoot them in the head, the shotgun felt so terribly weak that I was using my one shot pistol over it (the pistol is the starting gun btw out of 4 others), overall just felt kinda rough but it isn't really focused on that much even though i'd say maybe 30% of the game is shooting.

The Raids (Just disable them), I felt no need to kill any of the bandits and use up ammunition when more of them were going to spawn anyway, I would let my comrades kill them until the timer went down to 0, they would stop spawning then I would assist so I would not waste ammo on people that are basically infinitely respawning, it didn't help that the further you got in the story the raid timers got longer and longer. It also sucks that it just completely voids your current inspection you are doing, the person just drives away once a raid has started, so you could spend a whole 10 minutes on an inspection for it to mean nothing.

The Story, I never really was following it and was really just uninterested, it was hard to keep track of certain characters in the story, the only things I looked at were the current events of the chapter and the associated newspaper and the little side story letters (basically the same story telling bits from Papers Please) the whole rebel leader's story lines and main missions were just meh.

The performance, I saved this for last as it might just be a me issue as my computer is definitely getting somewhat dated (cpu and gpu from 2017), I was playing on medium (low looks horrid and didn't really improve performance for me) during main loop of gameplay it was okay for me around 50-60, but the big gunfights (raids and main missions) TANKED down to 15-20 really close to unplayable for me, I've been doing fine on this build for a while now, to put it in perspective cyberpunk on release never dropped that low for me.. that's pretty rough.

While this review mainly highlighted the problems I still think the price point of $20 is fair, but... the problems are there and considering this game is "Full Release" and not Early Access it's quite odd, I don't see why they didn't go Early Access cause it still needs polish in my opinion like major rework of mechanics type of polish. I think the campaign is worth A playthrough, especially if you loved Papers Please like me but the main selling point will probably be the Freeplay Mode when that comes out (they said they are working on it). 

So for right now.. just wait.

SUMMARY: 
Contraband Police offers a decent visual experience that's pretty good but not groundbreaking. Gameplay is solid and enjoyable. The audio quality is good, suitable for a mature audience. PC requirements are standard, and the game strikes a balance between challenge and frustration. The story is well-constructed, and game time is substantial. Pricing is fair, and the game is free of major bugs. Overall, it's a commendable 7/10 gaming experience, providing well-rounded enjoyment for players.

Great idea and somewhat fun inspection RP, but the game still feels like a beta and is far from ready.

Inspection: You just shine a UV light at the different parts of the vehicle and if you see a dragon sign on any part than there is contraband there, if not, then its clear.... /slowclap.  that could have been much better, could have had small clues and irregularities that force you to think instead of a super clear "dragon sign". a bit lacking there.

Driving: 
A complete chore as the mechanics are very outdated and just clunky and not fun, yet you're forced to do it very often. 
Roads are narrow and uninteresting, turning on sirens causes everyone around you to hit trees, rocks or anything around them like a 20 year old AI, there are unnecessary road ambushes very very often that takes me to the second point of Shooting.

Shooting: 
Feels like a 20 year old shooter once combat starts, pretty bad aiming and weapon handling, all the enemies just stand in the same position and keep firing at you non-stop until you take them out (they also know exactly where you sre even if youre behind cover, wallhackers !), bodies disappear very quickly before you had a chance to search them for items so after a shooting you just run like a maniac to quickly search everything before they despawn. If shooting isnt the main issue of a document inspection game, why do you make it happen so often? road ambushes and inspection point attacks are just a chore that you just want to finish it and move on.  if it happens so often, should have made shooting more dated, at least it would be a fun part of the game.

Menus are terrible and barely anything from menu options is explained.

Could have been an awesome game with a bit more attention to detailed and some QOL options. but as it is now i cannot recommend it.

Awesome experience regardless.

People compare this to Papers Please, but this is a more complex game.

There are 3 parts to it, the document (and vehicle) verification, first person driving, and first person shooting. The driving and shooting parts are fun but tend to get old pretty quickly. I felt like I wanted to get back to just verifying vehicles documents are vehicles and cargo and turning away smugglers. It is not all bad because the game heavily pushes you in the direction of actually being there rather than having the story told to you, and it does feel like that when you are driving prisoners to the labor camp and half way there you are ambushed by people you have to either shoot to kill, drive over to kill, or run away from.

There is some progression as well with the kind of home you have (which is supposed to refill "perception" but mine never ran low, even with the garbage caravan shelter I had) which lets you automatically mark mismatches on the documents to your report instead of having to manually mark them, and the prison guards and the base guards and the guns and tools you get. This mostly isn't very interesting, but adds to the realism of having to look after you and your guards in what is a very low key quiet border crossing that has its share of dangers.

I will add that I did replay papers please shortly before I bought this and that probably added to me feeling like I just wanted the simplicity of just matching papers and confirming things were as they should be.

[b]My review to Contraband Police[/b]

[b]Welcome to the great nation of Acaristan![/b] In a communist country, as a player you take on the role of an officer trainee at a remote border post in the mountainous region of Karikatka. Your tasks include controlling vehicles and people who intend to enter the Acarist People's Republic. Shady characters and smugglers try to cheat their way through the border control, which you should prevent, of course. There will also be car chases. You can upgrade and improve your police car, your colleagues and your accommodation. And many many more. Many hours of play are guaranteed, try it now! I love this game!

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]
+ 84 Steam-achievements
+ Full controller support
+ Campaign and Endless mode available

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]
- No Steam Trading Cards
- Sometimes a bit complicated as to what is required/looking for
- No Points Shop Items available

[h1]I definitely recommend this game![/h1]
[h2]Glory to Acaristan[/h2]
Now That's a Good Game!

I recommend this game, [strike] but there are a few things to be aware of. First and foremost, [b]it is a story based game with a playtime of roughly 10-12 hours per play through. I feel that this was not really advertised and may have affected my purchasing decision if I knew prior. Second, [b]there is no new game plus or endless option. Once you play through the game once, you will start from zero again, completing the tutorial along with it. [/strike] Overall, I enjoy the game, the mechanics are great, aside from the AI enemies being a little too easy to defeat. The save function can also only be operated by resting, so this requires some forethought before starting a day as they are between 25 and 45 minutes.

Edit: I now fully recommend this game as an endless option has now been added. I have no complaints about wither the story or endless modes now. Also, the tutorial can now be skipped, at least on endless mode. The developers really go above and beyond on this game and continue supporting it even after release.

First off, let me say what I think about this game:

It's well worth the price, and the graphics are medium quality. There's some controls and movements that don't feel smooth, but that's expected for a freshly released game. I saw a review talking about hitboxes causing them to crash into nothing, and from driving on the road and on the side of the road, I have so far not hit a single invisible barrier. My grievance with this game isn't about world exploration or the ambushes, either, like some other reviews(Only at first are the ambushes rough, as they can destroy your vehicle easily unless you upgrade it. After that, you can easily just drive by them, and if you're lucky they don't even get the chance to shoot). My issues stem from easily avoidable bugs that could've been detected if playtesters intentionally looked for them. I can list a few, and then afterwards I'll explain what I do enjoy about this game.

The two main grievances have to do with the ambushes on the border that happen from time to time. Both are game-breaking and can force you to be pushed back to either a checkpoint, or to the start of the day. If you happen to be using the telephone for time-specific ambushes that aren't triggered by sleeping, it teleports you out into the battlefield where you cannot move, as for some reason you receive a new pair of arms that removes your legs, supposedly. You can't move, but you can shoot, which makes it not entirely guaranteed for you to die, but it is pretty guaranteed especially if an enemy throws a grenade. Another I came across was with the cars driving up during the ambush. At some point, before they exit or during the animations they make while exiting, I shot at them, which showed it did damage. However, their health bar did not deplete. Once they exited and drew their guns, they were invulnerable to everything. It forced a reset from me because there was literally nothing I could do to stop them. Again, if this was playtested thoroughly, these wouldn't be present. Sure, on release any game can excusably have bugs and game-breaking issues that weren't discovered during playtesting, but with how some of these you're guaranteed to experience at least once in your playthroughs, that's where I say it's doubtful that no one during testing came across any of these, whether looking for bugs or not. 

With those issues aside, I'll get on to the things I like about this game. First off, before you install the game, from how it looks and how well the game runs, it's surprising how small the game's storage requires compared to other games of similar quality. The quality of gameplay is comparable to Ubisoft games on here, excluding the cutscenes. There's some times where the frames drop below 60, but it's not very noticeable, and I'm on the default settings of the game. For default settings, I'd say it's debatable whether your frames should ever drop noticeably, but I think it depends on the minimum requirements more than your current specs.

This game is heavily inspired by Papers, Please: A fictional Slavic communist republic has a border crossing that the player works at, and based on criteria you are informed on for that day and for what you're taught in the previous days, you determine whether that individual is allowed to cross. Just like Papers, Please, there's people who attempt to forcefully cross the border, and there's attacks you have to fend off. The documents, the photo, the multiple regions that are constantly having issues with each other, the rebellion in your region, it all remains quite clear. I dare say this is the closest game to Papers, Please that's 3D. 

The process for finding smuggled items is quite simple, as is the display for it. The items you uncover from parts of the vehicle or from cargo isn't accurate to what's displayed inside it all the time. However, sometimes it's easy to miss these. Like the trainer says to you in the first few days, people can get inventive with their methods of trying to smuggle things. These methods feel realistic, too, as while they are forced to have a snake mark only visible in UV light wherever they hide smuggled items, they can blend in very well dependent on what it is. You'll often overlook some of these, and I applaud that. One thing I might add that I hope gets changed is the single jump sound that you hear each time. It's the same with no pitch change, so it feels like I'm playing Quake in a Slavic countryside.

For those who don't want to read all of this, I'll summarize and say things in my own words in a short few sentences: You are a demi-god who can choose to either fight crime or to fight the government. When you are ambushed by enemies, or when you attack those who oppose you, they have no idea how powerful the force that they've interrupted currently is. With your superior aim, vitality, and detection, you strike fear into your enemies in their last moments of life, making them question their life choices and wish that they didn't take this path. Also there's bugs so I can't currently recommend it.

Very satisfying game play. Clearly inspired directly by Papers, Please (a game that I cherish), it still manages to stand on its own with new areas of game play. Where Papers, Please is smaller scale and more focused on the morality of having direct and virtually-unmonitored control over the physical movement of people, Contraband Police is focused more on the procedure of border inspections and day-to-day operations. While slightly repetitive in some circumstances, managing the logistics is quite entertaining, with just the right amount of action hidden within at first mundane interactions. 

Overall, I would recommend, especially considering the additional content that has been added. Endless mode is a welcome addition.

Papers Please started this interest with border patrol, and Contraband Police took it a step further. For an Early Access game it has a decent amount of content for the player to enjoy. I'm optimistic about this game and hope the devs continue with this great start. I would certainly recommend trying the demo at the very least. 

The premise of Contraband Police is the player takes the role of a border guard in a communist / soviet-esque setting. The players success (and ability to continue playing the game) will depend on their ability and efficiency as a border guard. The better you are - the more money. The worse you are, the chances you might go broke due to upkeep. The [b]gameplay[/b] is very basic and straightforward. The player interacts regularly with items and people to check for any discrepancies. It starts simple with passport pictures, expired documents, and potentially some smuggling but as the game progresses the checks become a lot more difficult. In a way, it makes you think how much has to go through someones head when doing security. As situations in Karikatka unfold and new developments happen, the demands around the checks will change. Fortunately, the game does have some manual click-to-check functions for players to do checks quicker. It will cost the player a little focus each time it is used (which will enforce the need to rest). 

There are tools the player can buy in the world to improve their border guard ability. Sometimes this may be weapons, it may be tools, or upgrade to the player's border stop. (be it personnel or buildings). It is an open world map where players can interact with a few places, drop contraband or prisoners off. A van is given to the player to start, but if player's don't feel like contraband and prisoners all the time they may call for a transport (which will cost a pretty penny)! The premise is the player allows cars or trucks to go through and can ask the driver for documents or to step out of the car. If necessary, the player can make arrests and find contraband around and in the vehicle. Players may account for cargo and take it out of the vehicle to further inspect if anything else is hidden. While this is happening, random events will occur that will demand the player's attention. My suggestion is to do these missions as they pay a pretty penny. Don't worry about the border though, it doesn't seem like the drivers have any choice but to wait :). I don't know if this was on purpose, but it is appreciated when things go haywire and gangsters start raiding the border and the player needs to defend (hopefully with more than just a pipe). There are other missions that help  with the development of the story and it feels like the missions are decently well rounded. 

The [b]visuals and graphics[/b] are pretty good. They aren't extremely detailed, however the game does a good job immersing the player into the environment. The level design seems pretty well organised to me and well laid out. There are cut-scenes in the game in addition to small animations that NPCs will engage in. Visual upgrades to the border base are also noticeable as well as the personnel. The [b]audio and music[/b] are well done. I think more needs to be added to this domain, but again, for an Early Access game I think a decent amount was included. The player can play music while driving around in the police truck. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this game on sale. If it seems interesting to you even if its not on sale, I'd say go for it. I really enjoyed my play through and can only hope the devs continue to add to the game as much as possible. Fingers crossed down the line there is some sort of endless mode and hopefully workshop items/missions. 

TO THE DEVS:
-Endless mode would be highly recommended and I think appreciated
-Any plans for workshop items / missions down the road? I'm sure the community would love to help out
-The steering is a little weird and stiff... not sure if it was meant like that. The animation for the turning also isn't the most accurate... small detail :)
-Perhaps a sort of flash/easy mode for those new to the game. I played Papers Please so picking this up wasn't an issue, but noticed some other gamers were overwhelmed - even with a solid tutorial. Maybe an option in the gameplay menu?
-Well done with the environment, actually impressed with how much there is even in Early Access. Continue working on the world and adding events, items, things, NPCs whatever to it.
-Give player an ability to see future ambushes maybe with a radar down the road? 
-AI partners do not feel useless and actually provide cover / do something during gunfights. Enemy AI also feels well balanced. 
-What about stopping regular traffic? Why not add more to the game in terms of exploring by allowing the player to do random stops INSIDE the country? Perhaps on endless mode, may be too much for campaign.

While I do absolutely love the game, there are a few things I'd like to point out: 

1. It is very difficult to see broken windows (sometimes its impossible, even during daytime) ...maybe make a blue outline for all the windows so they are easier to see? Or perhaps maybe just make them shattered/"spider-webbed" so its easier to identify it.

2. Sometimes it can be confusing to determine exactly what the entry regulations are. For example, one of the regulations is when someone has more than 3 problems with their car they should be denied entry. Well... what if someone has *exactly* 3 problems with their vehicle? Can they be approved, or not? (I'm pretty sure I've declined them *and* listed it as an entry regulation- which passed me on the inspection, other times it fails me... I need to go back and play again to make 100% sure).

3. Trying to get a perfect score on the inspections during later stages of the game is very time consuming/ tedious... I wouldn't mind if we had another 5-10 minutes for each in game day.

4. Getting attacked during an inspection... God, I hate that part of the game so much. Its not because "Ah! Oh my god, we're getting shot at! leave us alone!" No...I hate it because of all the times I have a good inspection (I admit, they're not perfect), but the times where I spend what feels like an eternity trying to catch all the mistakes, and right as I'm about to approve or deny entry to someone, an attack happens, either that or I'll spend more than a few minutes inspecting a car only to realize just as I'm about to approve or deny them- it actually turns out they're a smuggler. Before I can approve/ deny/ find contraband and arrest someone... We get attacked. Next thing I know the driver gets scared and drives off. Yeah... So much for getting my moneys worth after inspecting someone. It is realistic, I admit... but its super annoying.

5. Having a time limit to return to the border. Again, yes, it's realistic... but annoying when I just chased down a smuggler. (For those who don't know, you can still search the car for contraband), I recommend looking for all of it first *before* arresting the driver so you don't have to worry about the time limit.

6. Contraband in animals... yes, really. I think the game was intended to have it be so that if there is contraband in an "animal," its actually supposed to be fake/not move at all. this only happens if the animal is unloaded. If you unload an animal and its moving, its real. If you unload an animal, but its not moving, it's fake.

I do love the story! I wont spoil anything, but I love details like if you deny entry to someone because... legally speaking, you have to, it turns out people are actually being deadly serious when they beg you about letting them in because if you don't, they will lose their job/ house/ family/ friends/ etc. not only do the send you threatening letters in the mail next to the newspaper, they likely are the ones who cause you to be attacked. (This would make my complaint about attacks invalid to those who weren't paying attention) However, for those of you who weren't paying attention, what I'm saying is how I actually *like* being attacked at random, because its realistic for you to receive retaliation/ karma for ruining someones live(s), plus if you're fast enough, you can loot bodies, but it does suck to lose a car you were inspecting.

Overall, I give 4.5 out of 5 because of the imperfections/ bugs/ glitches I mentioned earlier, but its still very close to being perfect, maybe give yourselves a few months or a year to improve, and this game will be a perfect 5 stars!

This game comes in with a unique-ish concept and spends most of it's time as a low quality shooter.

Not enough border guarding. There is no real pressure to churn through new arrivals. It's very simple to do a thorough inspection on all 4-5 men in single passenger vehicles. Pay is based on perfect reviews, not numbers of processed. So very easy to shine your UV light on everything and just tick all the boxes.

I do like the idea of the game, and it has really good potential. Taking a break from the border to drive prisoners to the labour camp and have a gun fight on the way is really cool. But..

The story is a very weak, I have no motivation to care about the rebellion or side with the smugglers. Even the people pleading to get through to visit their dying mother. It all lacks a bit of heart and narrative. 

NPC guards are just shells waiting around for a raid. Raids go on for too long, I found myself later in the game just crouching behind a box, waiting for my guards to shoot the generic bad guy raid, (from the same direction as every other raid) for another 3 mins and afkd to get a drink. Again, low quality shooty bang bang. 

I'd love it if guards could react to border events. So when I'm running to the police car, shooting my AK at a fleeing subject, heart thumping in my chest. And my guard says "Hello commander" in a flat neutral tone as I rush past. And I die a little inside.

Bought this game on a whim because a streamer I watch was playing it and I couldn't recommend this more. If you are a fan of Papers, Please I think you would find this game just as fun. 

It can throw a lot at you, but none of it feels unfair, they build into it slowly and help you along the way instead of dropping you in the deep end.

Game isn't that long (I think there's around 8 chapters and I'm on chapter 4) but don't let that deter you, there's three game modes currently, they are working on an endless mode making sure the game has more than just a story mode.

There's some weird jank that can happen, but nothing bad and it's most of the time hilarious. 

Overall, don't pass this up if you're thinking about it.

Initially, I had some concerns when I looked at the requirements for the game. I was worried that it might not be well optimized and that it would be better to wait a bit longer before getting it. However, the game's visuals were impressive, and I noticed a lot of interaction from the developers. So, I decided to take the leap and purchase it right away.

To my surprise, the game turned out to be fantastic. I haven't encountered any issues so far—no bugs, no performance issues. While I do own a higher-end PC, some simulator games tend to be demanding, but this one runs and plays smoothly.

The gameplay itself might be considered repetitive by some. However, if you're like me and enjoy games like Gas Station Simulator, you'll find this game to be a real treat. It offers all of that and more, with the promise of additional updates in the pipeline.

I derive immense enjoyment from manning my station, pursuing criminals, and making judgment calls on whether to let certain individuals off the hook. The camaraderie with my team adds to the immersion; having them perform tasks without requiring constant management is a great touch.

This game lives up to its promises. If the concept excites you, don't hesitate to grab it now—before it becomes even better and more expensive. For those who might consider it just another addition to the Simulator genre, rest assured that this one stands out as a prime example and has a bright future ahead. If you're only going to have one simulator game in your library, this should be the one.

The basic game play reminds me a lot of Papers Please, however without the pressure of having to get as many people through as possible within a time limit. It's a lot of fun and I like how it gradually gets more complex and bureaucratic while the game progresses. Searching vehicles is nice and straightforward without being obvious - you have to work to find some of the contraband - although one gripe I do have is the durability of some of the tools could be improved. When a $100 knife only gets through a couple of vehicles worth of seats and tyres it can get frustrating. The base-building aspect of upgrading your border post and hiring more guards is good, although it can take most of the game to get enough cash to be able to complete all of the upgrades!

Where the game really wins is the story that occurs alongside the day job paperwork simulator, with a mix of driving, FPS action, and puzzle solving. I found this super engaging and it really helped to keep the game from becoming repetitive. I managed to finish it in 15 hours, which is a little short, however the numerous decision points mean that you can go back and play the story again and try different branches each time to see if you get a different result. 

I would love to see the game continue after the end of the story, allowing you to continue working at the border with perhaps some random events to deal with (like escaping smugglers, criminal gangs etc.) and some of the other game modes that are hinted at. Some more black market trading too, perhaps the ability to sell contraband for extra cash. That may have been present (it's certainly mentioned) but I could not find anyone to whom I could sell it.

Definitely recommended, not only to people who enjoyed Papers Please but also to everyone who enjoys an interesting and innovative game.

I really like the game. It has the right balance between "work" and action, like Story-Quests, shootouts or prison/contraband transport, so that you don´t just check papers and cargo the whole game without ignorng the main focus on said papers.
The graphics and mechanics are also very good for a simulator like this and the few things that could be better in my oppinion will most likely be added in later updates anyway, like more upgradeble buildings at your station or more NPC interactions outside Quests.

I personally only have two small problems with the game. For one, and this could just be skill-issue, there should be like a tow option on the police vehicles. I had a few occasions where I pushed a fugetive off the road and he ended in a spot where I couldn´t reach the door to arrest him, like up a hill, front first or spun on the side.
The second would be the AI of the civillians. They do make way, if you activate the siren, but if you are ambushed and jump out the car without activating the siren first, the civillians will drive up the street undaunted and just plow through the firefight. I died multiple times in a shootout because a civillian thought "I don´t care that they are shooting each other down this road" and drive right into me. I think this problem could easily be avoided by just making them stop near gun fire/hostiles or even make them turn their car and flee the scenen.
It would also be an intresting feature if your allignment with the goverment/the rebels would have more impact on the the gameplay, like gradually reducing the amount of ambushes/base attacks if you allign with the rebels or like better pay or benefits if you allign with the goverment, e.g. regular suppy shipments or cheaper prison transports

This game is so bare bones for being a fully-released title, I thought for sure it was an early access game. However, what I found was so incredibly addicting through its routine gameplay. I love the basic framework, but there are many things that still need improvement. 

I think this game would improve immeasurably if the devs focused more on the base building aspect of upgrading your own border control post and less on the repetitive driving around. Why are we the one to drive every prisoner and piece of contraband when you play as the commander of the post? I sincerely hope they add some kind of mechanic to control what your guards do, like making deliveries for you or posting up at a specific spot to better stop rogue smugglers. Having more than one vehicle makes this seem like a no-brainer, but I guess only you get to use the cars. Speaking of which, what is the point of arming your guards if none of them can stop any old person in a hatchback that decides to drive straight through? The guards seriously need to do SOMETHING in camp other than repel invaders. Being a one-man army just nullifies the point of having any other guards with you.

That leads me to another gripe of mine: the random road ambushes. I actually ended up turning this setting off (thankfully that is an option), but the random ambushes add very little flavor to the gameplay. These events actively turn me off to engaging with them because they reward almost nothing and just take up your time. The random events need to be reworked significantly, but thankfully you can turn them all off for now.

 I am excited to see the addition of the endless mode, as I think it is just what this game needs to take a step in the right direction. I think this game needs an overall clearer vision for what it wants to be. Hopefully, he devs can take this solid framework and polish it into a true gem.

Contraband Police is essentially Papers Please, but with the addition of gunfights, car chases, prisoner transport, base upgrades and of course it's all in glorious 3D graphics (which aren't bad btw).

I can safely say that if you enjoyed Papers Please, you will enjoy this game as well. It also has a story, which progresses as the days go by. The Devs are working on an endless mode too though, I do believe.

For me, this is much more of an immersive experience. Papers Please is much more casual. This one really tries to put you in the shoes of an actual border guard working for a communist state in the 1980's. It's for this reason I enjoy it so much.

takes concepts from games like papers please and adapts it fairly well into the simulation genre. while it somewhat waters down the core mechanics and doesn't really do much with the story, the gameplay of searching cars for minor details or contraband is very engaging. it did start to feel like it was overstaying its welcome but that was likely because i completed the game in one sitting. overall a game that is definitely worth playing if it looks interesting to you, but if it doesn't hook you immediately you probably won't like it.

Welcome to what i hope will at least be a semi helpful review to you my friend which i will break up into individual segments, starting with price, story, game play, and additional content. So my friends let us begin.
Price/Value
Contraband police is a fairly priced game especially considering today's economy for games and for what your getting you really can't complain, the game is priced around $30 in my region or something similar where ever your from. I got the game on when it came out, so i got a 12% discount, which was nice but i would still have happily paid full price. I usually like to wait for a sale before i purchase a game but whatever sale I've seen for this game has been really small, so in my opinion it's not worth waiting and i do believe $30 is a reasonable price for what your getting.
Game play
The core of any game especially CP is how does the game run. In simple terms great, i've never had any really issues regarding it's performance the worst that's happened to me is the AI drivers acting stupid but that's really it. The mechanics of checking papers are very nicely done and are slowly introduced to you as you progress through the game, ranging from simple name checks, vehicle weights, forgeries, and additional sub documents to name a few. The checking system overall works well although it can be tedious as you progress through the game 6 different documents all covering your screen but it does make sense. There's a simple ranking system you get papers right your promoted you unlock new stuff and increased rewards. If you get papers wrong your fined depending on your rank and point in the story, but it does not affect your rank. . Only real gripe with it is sometimes there's no direct cross-reference so you'll have to pick it up and manually check it but it happens rarely (assuming you don't get fatigued). The key mechanic to make sure you can't perfectly check everything from day 1 is the fatigue meter which can be improved as you upgrade your residence, this does feel a bit inconsistent in how it upgrades, as i feel the jump in the last upgrade is quite big, but only my personal thoughts. You can upgrade some elements of the outpost, being the prison, storage, residence, your collection of vehicles and the vehicles themselves, bit pricey but it's so you have something to work towards. The random missions you get are fun enough but are somewhat infrequent at least for me so don't expect call-outs to frequently. Attacks on out-posts have varying frequency, but add a nice element of surprise. Moving on to the contraband checking it works well, although some areas such as the engine can be a pain to check with elements being hidden extremely well. You'll get the odd runner which you have to chase, which is a nice change of pace but again at least for me infrequent. The shooting is really solid for  the game. The biggest compliant i would have is how expensive everything is especially the weapons, with the sniper (last weapon) costing you up to 5 days of work depending on how well you check although by the point you unlock it you should have some cash lying around. Finally for gameplay the bribes are the worse as they are completely RNG based so there's no way to increase your chances of getting away or getting caught and the punishment for it $800 dollars of your cash, which depending where you at in the game can cost around 1 day to 4 days of your pay. Overall the game play is great just some minor issues, and a lot of it is being addressed in the endless mode update.
Story
Look this part going to short, the story is about your average communist government trying to control every aspect of life and the rebels trying to fight back with you caught in the middle, there are a few story missions which are done well enough but are far between as they're spread over the 30 days, each gives you a choice whether to side for the government or rebels leading to different endings, so that's up to the player. The story missions are done well and are varied to provide a good experience, but as said before are far between. There are different chapters which change regulations for the outpost which again add nice variety and work well with "beggars" which are appear here and their basically begging you to let them in despite their faulty paperwork, regardless of entering or rejecting them there's a unique letter for each. No real consequences other than not seeing said letter, if you let them in you get the standard penalty for screwing up, but you may get a reward from said "beggar". The story is not the vocal point of the game it's there just to add another layer, it's not particularly complex, but it is fun and enjoyable. 
Overall thoughts
If you enjoy sim's you'll love this one with a nice unique twist rarely seen, and if you loved papers please you'll also love this more complex and open version of it, if you hate either of these than you'll hate this game as it can get repetitive like any simulator . The game is updated frequently (as of writing) and we are looking forward to our next big update the endless mode, which rids of the limit days in the story and goes on well forever with more features. If you're still hesitant to pay $30 for just story then wait until endless comes out. Overall if i had to give the game a rating it'd be a solid 8/10. I hope this review helped and i thank you for reading it my friends.

There have been a slew of sarcastic simulator games as of recent years and its all from the same studio. Homeless sim or pawn shot sim, police brutality sim or prison sim. there are many more and they are all the same. Lazy quick asset flip "games" with the same tone. Some are cleaner than others and some are not. This one had me going because its like papers please. Except its not it kind of reminds me of a playstation 2 game or like early stalker. 

Its got what everyone hates in games 

-Follow missions with incredibly sensitive line of sight issues
-Car chases with super floaty physics and impossible to stop cars
-Papers please investigations that never tell you what you did wrong so that you can learn 
-A tutorial that doesn't really explain the games mechanics
-Upgrade trees and employees that tell you nothing of what your upgrading or for what purpose

After 2.7 hours i feel as tho i have had my fill and im refunding the game and may grab it again if its not just abandoned by the dev team like they do to all the other IPs they make.

As a developer, juggling many tasks, Confluence and JIRA, checklists, etc, this game has helped me memorize things easier. It starts slowly by adding one condition to people crossing the border. 15 hours later, you're checking for name on multiple documents, passport numbers and forgery, vehicle registration and type, cargo with limitations on items, vaccinations, and a vast number of many other conditions.

And all you want is a 100% rating on the next person crossing the border.

Absolutely star studded, fantastic game, but needs improvements. The idea of this game is amazing, games like this keep me busy forever. The audio needs improvements, as do most games in this category. The lighting can also be buggy at times, especially on the largest police unit. The campaign is great, it changes and gives unique scenarios constantly. I think there should be more communication between the AI and player though, the only words exchanged often are just asking for documents. I think there also needs to be more cars trying to cross, and different difficulties to push on time. I love idea of upgrading your outpost, but I wish there was more to expand on, like being able to upgrade your house much more, and upgrade the walls for when you get attacked. I also think that there should be addable things like sniper towers or inspection stations, where you can have multiple vehicles being checked simultaneously. Being able to cross check things with perception is great, but needs to be improved upon. Overall this game is highly worth it and I am sure there is more to come.

It's Papers, Please meets STALKER, sorta. Imagine the inspection mechanics of Papers Please and the gunplay of STALKER and this is what you get. I played through once so far and enjoyed myself quite a bit. I would say it's worth the $20 at the time of writing. A few little niggles here and there. 

1. I noticed about halfway through, then couldn't not notice: there are literally no women in the game at all. I don't particularly care, I'm not the SJW type but its very weird and once I noticed it I couldn't stop noticing. My guess is they didn't have a female character model but it's not that hard to make. 
2. Late game, the economy is pretty much a moot point. I found myself arresting people for fun or because they annoyed me and not caring about the financial penalty because I had so much money. 
3. The story tells you what happens to every character...except you! Screw everyone else, what happened to me? The guy who single handedly stopped the revolution? 
4. The other border guards are totally useless. They claim to help in attacks but I swear on my life those bastards either have stormtrooper aim or were shooting blanks. They didn't hit shit. 
5. Grenades don't kill enemies if they blow up the car, yet will kill civilians in their car. Kinda annoying. 

All in all, I greatly enjoyed it for what it was. A nice little paper inspection game where, if you get bored or pissed off, you can go on a power trip and arrest someone for having a mustache or because you dislike the color of their car or because it's Tuesday and you can.

TL;DR: The game is functional but not flashy, varied and fun, and only mildly irritating at times, and well worth picking up for the price, even more so on sale.

I have not yet finished the story, so will focus on the gameplay and premise instead.

You are a nameless replacement Border Patrol Officer for the glorious communist republic of Acaristan, sent to command the checkpoint at Karikatka in the Spring of 1981. You must inspect Newcomers' documents, vehicles and cargo, and remain vigilant against smugglers and enforce the laws of the land. The laws vary as the game progresses, with lax restrictions during the tutorial phase, up to cargo embargoes and an outbreak of disease, a rip on Covid19 which made me laugh, and there are ever increasing documents to inspect and restrictions on who can come in, their vehicle and its condition etc.

The comparison to Papers Please is obvious, and while I've never played it, I know of it, and the border manning phase is very similar with the moral choices to be made at your personal expense or enforce the law to the letter at the expense of the populace. You can also choose to side with the rebels, but I have not done that as of yet so cannot comment.

The gameplay is fun, interesting enough to engage and varied. Whilst manning the border, you will arrest smugglers (or accept their bribes), collect contraband and will need to transport the prisoners and contraband to locations in the map.

The phone in the office will occasionally give you a mission outside of the post, and without spoilers these are also fun and varied for the most part.

The Border Checkpoint will come under attack either from the rebels or the local criminal syndicate, and you and your men must defend the checkpoint for a period of time then finish off the enemy. There are the usual array of pistol, shotgun, smg, rifle and sniper rifle to choose from. The gunplay is not spectacular, but it is funcitonal. Hitboxes are a tad janky but for the most part they work. If you are a fan of FPS games then the shooting here will not impress, but you'll find it functional enough to not be frustrating to engage in. The same is said for the driving, searching etc. The mechanics are there, they are functional but not flashy. I have not been frustrated, merely mildly annoyed on occasion.

There are also goodies spread across the map to find, and once you have processed all incoming visitors, you are free to explore the map, find the hidden collectibles, shop for weapons, tools and ammunition, and take your prisoners to the camp and deliver contraband to the base. Some days take up more time than others, so sometimes you will not have time to do everything. You can upgrade your men, base, living quarters and vehicles with money. The more you catch and the more right calls you make, the more you will earn.

Unfortunately the ingame audio language is not English, or if it can be I couldn't figure out how to change it, and the English subtitles are not perfect translations but I've not had any trouble reading the subtitles or understanding instructions, which is good considering the devs are Polish and likely not native or overly fluent English speakers.

For the price I'd say it's good value, reasonably priced at £16.75 when I bought it yesterday, and great value if it goes on sale.

In summary, the game is functional but not flashy, varied and fun, and only mildly irritating at times, and well worth picking up for the price, even more so on sale.

I recently completed this game for the first time, and found it to be a lot of fun. However, as the game progressed, I felt annoyed that I kept getting pulled away from being able to check vehicles and capture smugglers in favor of completing mundane tasks. I still greatly enjoyed this game, but would like endless mode, and a more fleshed out checkpoint (larger size, different events isolated to the checkpoint, increase in vehicles, increase in smugglers, etc.). The gameplay is absolutely addicting when you are busting smugglers, but the tasks took some fun out of the game for me personally.

Well worth the $20. I missed the Papers, Please hey day, but this is a modern update with far more interactivity and systems to manage. As far as time pressure goes, it's there, but not as bad as Papers, Please, which was scraping by for the sake of your family in a brutal regime. Things are (at least from what I've experienced so far) lighter in tone, as you are looking after your comrades.

There are areas of improvement (aren't there always?), like the story being boilerplate "The ills of an Authoritarian Communist state" (the binary faction choices could be expanded into something more nuanced) and how difficult it can be to assess vehicle conditions (a broken window or missing bumper can sometimes be hard to pick up). Gunplay is serviceable but not the main draw. Overall, if this is your first entry into this style of Post-Dad game, you'll enjoy it, as it injects bureaucracy with some adrenaline, even if the combat is simple.

Think the gameplay loop of a Stardew Valley or Harvest Moon: you have a day job to manage, and then limited time based to do other tasks, based on how efficient you were during the day job.

I hear there is an Endless mode coming, so that should be interesting. The fact the game launched (or currently has after a patch) missing two of three gameplay modes does raise an eyebrow.

Just a solid title for its scope and budget. This is worth supporting.

Game is a solid 9.3/10. 
It is an infinitely better version of Papers, Please except this has actual engaging gameplay. 
The story is interesting and fun to watch develop, the inspection of cars is fun and didn't get boring or repetitive (to me at least.)
The only thing I wish that was a little different was less of a focus on the shooting parts of the game and a little more depth on the vehicle inspections. Possibly adding ways to have your border guards be able to pre-inspect some of the vehicles to verify issues with cosmetics or notice anything weird going on with the driver. Or possibly adding a second inspection lane, maybe even automate some of the process via your employees.
The game is fine as is, I just felt those would be nice additions.
By the end of the campaign I think I'd killed liked 400 people or something which I felt detracted a bit from the realism of the game but like I said it wasn't a big issue. 

I'd absolutely recommend buying this game, don't even wait for a sale.

Hi, this is my review of Contraband Police. I have recorded over 37 hours in this game so far, but with the arrival of endless mode I will start playing it again fully.  The contraband police is probably not for everyone.  Not everyone will enjoy this, but if someone gets the hang of it, they will have a lot of fun.  I was personally interested in the work of a border guard, so for me this was a simulator that I couldn't help but buy.  The game only has a main career so far.  A career as such is somehow not long enough.  even if you really enjoy the game and do everything in as much detail as possible, you will finish the campaign within a few days. But as I wrote above, the authors are working on endless mode and that should solve this problem.  A little about the campaign.  You play as the main border guard who checks passing cars and trucks.  At the beginning of the control, they are quite simple and the player is introduced to what his job will be.  These first days I really recommend reading everything and trying to understand everything otherwise you will have a problem in the later parts.  As your days at the border go by, you will constantly complain about your work.  You'll have to check more and more and watch out for more things with each check.  You will have to be more careful about contraband.  Sometimes faced with a difficult decision.  You will have to fend off border attacks from time to time.  Sometimes in the middle of the working day they may call you with a voluntary mission that I recommend doing.  They are interesting and above all they will give you quite a lot of money that will come in handy.  Speaking of money, you won't have much money in this game.  It can be said that you will have more money towards the end of the game.  Until then, you will still have something to put them into (better cells, better equipment for workers, better cars...).  The whole game is in the Eastern style.  There is nothing better than riding a Zhiguli and listening to fast Eastern style music while you go to stop at a small house by the road where Comrade will sell you a Kalashnikov.  Overall, players from slav countries will definitely enjoy it more.  The campaign has its own story.  The story is written quite well, I would say, but I won't describe it more because I don't want to give any big spoilers.  I tried to write this entire review as spoiler-free as possible.  I definitely recommend giving this game a try!  A very good addition to the simulators.  I apologize for any mistakes.  I'm writing this through a translator.

Superb game. As a fan of Papers Please, I am thoroughly enjoying this one. Unpopular opinion but I preferred playing with a controller, with occasional use of the keyboard for inventory management. I felt like I had much better control than with the keyboard. Preference of course. I highly recommend this game, no hesitation. 

I only have one point of feedback for the Devs - when a newcomer arrives to the checkpoint and tells their story about why they want to cross the border, it would be great if their goodbyes were voiced accordingly and congruent to their story. For instance, when a guy comes to the checkpoint crying hysterically about needing to see his wife who is admitted to the hospital, and you approve his entry, and he responds with what is effectively "Cheerio!", it breaks the immersion lol. Other than that, fantastic game and keep up the great work!

Anyone who's ever played and enjoyed Papers please wanted a game likes this. It's basically that, just in first person and with a shooting/driving component. It's so much fun...and like probably most people...I don't know why LOL. You're literally doing a job and being hated for it. But yeah, it's a great concept and it took me about 23h to finish the main campaign. 

The games only has one major problem. The performance is absolute garbage. The game looks like it was made 10 years ago (except maybe the lighting), but you will not be able to keep it over 60 without a 30 series card. It's not a fast paced game that requires super high fps, but it's still no excuse, so just be aware of that. 

Overall it was great fun and I hope to see a performance patch and maybe more game-modes...possibly a CP 2 one day as well. Great job devs.

After 15 hours, I have beat the game. Here's a full review:

After seeing it on tiktok I thought it was just a more hands on version of "papers, please" however this game has a lot more to it. Just when you start to think the game is getting monotonous you have more smugglers, another part of the car/paperwork you have to check for, more entry regulations; or maybe you're needed to investigate a murder, takedown a syndicate crime boss, or just digging up graves for hidden contraband. 

However, its not flawless with some minor bugs. When the border is being attacked sometimes it'll say one enemy remaining when there's none and your soldiers will just keep shooting at rocks, the police patrol car outta be impossible to drive, and other minor bugs. Nothing game-breaking as of yet thankfully.

Eitherway, this game has a lot of moving parts with gang shootouts, a storymode that lets YOU choose your side, an upgrade system, in-game bartering, and much more. Defininetly worth the purchase, and can't wait to see the new updates and the devs seem very involved in the community.

TLDR: Amazing game worth the price, minor bugs, the devs seem active and can't wait for future updates.
It's a good game, I recommend. Can't wait for further updates :D

Hello comrades welcome to the border in this game you take control of low level border officer, and work your way up to a high acting border commander, the game offers a lot more than you would think. Obviously, the main focus of the game is the border control aspect. Vehicles will come in, and you have to inspect them Some of these people will either have a wrong paperwork or is a smuggler where you either arrest them or deny them access the game can be very tricky in the later aspects of the game with more rules and regulations but it’s way more interactive and has unique opportunities such as one of the days will have a man that claims to be part of the press that wants entry into the state to investigate missing children in a cave, however, does not have the right paperwork. If you deny him, he will send you a letter saying that the children are as good as dead now and that they are gone. However, if you allow him access, he will send you a thank you letter for helping him occasionally as well sometimes, instead of having the vehicle stop and be inspected, they will simply ram the gate in a police chase ensue where you have to get into your own vehicle and stop them either by pulling them over and aiming a gun in their face or just shooting them in the face the game offers a wide selection of items such as multiple different weapons and equipment that will help with investigations and so much more to be added. There was a whole story involving corruption or freedom where you need to pick a side, not knowing truly who is the better option the only thing in my opinion that holds this game back at the moment of writing this review is, there is no endless mode as soon as you finish the story you’re back to the beginning however, they are adding an endless mode very soon, this was an incredibly surprisingly fun and interesting game solid 8 out of 10 for me
