In the reality, the game turned out to be bullshit. It's very constrained and literally, there is nothing to do:
- U cant sell contraband on the black market
- There is no real value in 'tycon part' of a game. Its veeeery limited and there is no real use in all upgrades
- There is no value in stealing others cars (u cant save em, u cant sell em, u cant repair em)
- There is no value in transporting criminals. Easier just kill em on the border

So u need to buy a strong gun(u can after 1.5h) and check papers and that's all the game. 

All other mechanics have no value and become boring after 1h. For example: The game has a mechanic to arrest contrabandists and then put em in jail. But in reality putting criminals to prison have like 0 value because u get just a few bucks for this and u need to spend a lot of boring time transporting em on a very sloooow car thru a very boring map and the exactly same route again and again. And u actually ending up just killing em on the border not wasting time with em. There is no way u can take money from them for the rescue or there is no way u can sell em contraband. The mechanic is just artificial waste of your time. 
Or another example - finding contraband. At first, I thought there will be like moral choice - I can bring contraband to the police or sell it to the black market or take money from criminals to cover em... guess what - there is no choice. U have to waste time on finding contraband and transporting it, like with criminals, to the police station again and again and again and get paid like 100$ for this(u will earn more just 'checking the papers'). I ended up not wasting my time on searching for contraband - because there is no value in this. Yeah, the most efficient way is just 'check papers' and not waste time on contraband. Just find the symbol on the criminal car, shot the criminal, and ask the worker to clean the area. Thats it. Literally, nothing to do with all that mechanics.

The game becomes super boring after 3h. I played longer in the hope to see the black market or a way to mess up with other gangs or other possibilities but there is no interesting mechanics. An unfinished indie game with potential but which wasn't really released

Really struggling to see whether or not I should recommend this. My reasons are below.

First off, if you know and like "Papers, Please" , you'll like this. You play as a border guard, also checking documents, but also you check vehicles. Rules and laws keep changing so you have to keep being focused as the gameplay changes. I love this, and as a person who has always (strangely) been really interested in playing a game where you are a border / checkpoint guard, I really enjoyed every aspect of this.

There are some things that I liked less and stuff I think should be / have been improved on, like for example:
- you get like 5 cars daily to check, and they all come simultaneously at the start, it's not like you get a car in the morning, wait a bit and two more show up. You know, a little randomness of when the cars arrive, I think this would be more dynamic and realistic.
- random events should be added. There are tons of scenarios that I can think of straight away that can really peak gameplay in a game like this; attacks from newcomers (shoot out from the vehicle as you ask for their documents), terrorist attacks (VBIED), more ethical decisions (family of your character come as newcomers) etc
- Checkpoint management, as for now, we can only upgrade our house, prison and warehouse. But what about all of the trash scattered around the checkpoint? That weird cabin you cannot enter? Gun emplacements? Watch towers? Search lights? Etc Etc.
- Assign tasks to other guards. I was kind of hoping you would do checks on vehicles together. Instead, you have 7 guards wandering around, doing nothing. It would be cool if you could assign a guy to check the vehicle cargo for example, as you go over personal documents.

Other stuff I truly hated:
- Roadside ambushes. This happened WAY too often, not just way too often, I happened literally everytime I went out. Not just once, most of the time I got ambushed two to three times, which is genuinely annoying. They always kill the prisoners in the back instead of me, they ruin the vehicle, and just give me the idea that I am in no mood to go outside the checkpoint anymore. But, I can hear you say; "you can turn it off", well, I have a point about that too:
- Optional random events. I find this really weird, to be able to turn off stuff like roadside ambushes. I feel like this is part of the game, and part of the experience. It feels like a really weird choice to have it on either off or on. I feel like the game should rather focus on tweaking it, and making it less toxic than having the option to turn it off completely.
- Lastly, the ending. What an ending... I was enjoying the game, doing checks at the border. I had fun plans to upgrade everything to the max soon, but then I got the final mission, did it, and the game gave me the credits and deleted my save file. What..? I know there is an endless mode coming (I think, I hope), but why deny me from at least spawning back, allowing me to spend all the money I had tried hard to save, and buying everything? Also basically denying me to unlock other achievements? I literally have to start the campaign all over again to do this. That is a genuine weird thing. And something I want to turn this review into a not recommended game.

But, while I enjoyed the rest, I wont let the ending ruin the rest of what I enjoyed.

I dont think this is an great game or even close to the masterpiece Papers, Please, but its mostly fun, the problem is that it does not know what it wants to be...

The comparison to PP is a must because the game is heavily inspired by it, but it doesnt fully grasp what made PP an incredible hit.

First the good, upgrades although minimal are good, the inspections and other mechanics on the actual checkpoint are fun and the game flows mostly well. The base gameplay of checking documents and denying or approving travelers is nowhere near as crisp and satisfying as in PP but it works well enough to keep you chugging along and wanting more from that.

The best part for me is finding the contraband in the car, which should be the main focus of the game, I like finding the packets of contraband and the interaction with the suspect. I dont like the mechanic of the UV only serpent mark that you need to find with the UV lamp to find most contrabands, I think its a lazy addition and you could rely on visually seeing the packages or focus more on the tips you get that state that a certain car with a color or plate will come by with contraband.

Now the mostly bad which made me not recommend the game, this game wants to cover so much, right now Ive played only 4 hours and in that span, the game has tried to be:

Document Checking Simultator
Contraband Inspection Simulator
FPS
Base Builder/Upgrader and Personnel Manager
Driving/Chase Simulator
Stealth Mission
Murder Mystery Mission

And that is just in these 4 hours, and its not a problem that it tries to do so much per se, but that it does not excel at any of those 7, the first two I mentioned are decent enough, the FPS aspect is incredibly basic and janky, the base upgrades are minimal, the driving is SO BORING, if I have to chase a runaway far I'll be so bored on the way back to the base.

For the last two I have to talk about the "story campaign" This to me is by far the worst aspect of the game. You get introduced to it on a scripted mission and then you get calls at the office that you must answer in 5 mins and then run off to complete said mission quickly, so if you were entertained on the inspections you better forget about it, because you'll have to hop on the boring car and drive to the other side of the map to do either a horribly executed Stealth mission or a boring and minimal murder mystery mission (those are the only two I've done so far).

The game also takes inspiration from PP in that it gives you the option to work with the goverment or the rebels but it does it in the most uninspired way possible. They give you a huge prompt on the screen on certain choices that says GOVERNMENT or REBELS and its so meh, instead of like in PP where you can sometimes help one side or the other and have to make big choices that will have consequences in the several endings, here I really, really dont care about the characters they present and have absolutely no issue just going full government.

This game would be amazing if it spent more time polishing its base mechanics of document review and contraband search and leave most of the other genres alone. We dont need a stealth mission or a MM mission on this kind of game. Most of the time when im doing those or fighting waves of random NPCs with bad gunplay Im thinking man I wish I was inspecting cars or documents right now... If you want to implement story, do it organically like PP did.

If you're autistic, play this. I guarantee you'll have fun.
Hours of detail-oriented perfectionist work, combined with car chases, gunplay, detective work, and thwarting narcotics smuggling, not to mention a literal civil war/revolution in which you can make choices to tip the scales of fate. There wasn't a moment playing this game that I wasn't having a blast.

Some notes to the developer, excluding minor bugs;
-Enemies are bullet sponges, it doesn't really make sense. I understand that a human can actually take a bullet and keep going, but if I hit a man with 5 shots from a submachine gun, regardless of whether I hit a headshot he should at the very least be on the floor. Maybe a gutshot sends a person to the ground, where they have a random chance to either stay on the ground and be able to be arrested, or to pick up their gun and continue firing until dead
-Loved using the siren to force travelers to pull over out of my way, but in the third person vehicle camera it blinds me literally 1/2 of the time, ESPECIALLY at night.
-I think there should be a hidden shack where you could sell your contraband to a Red Fist member, or maybe just some random smuggler. They'd pay you more than the police station, but selling confiscated contraband too often would draw the eyes of the government. This makes a lot of sense in the game world, especially if the player is choosing to side with the Red Fist.
-Maybe a refused traveler doesn't like your decision, and decides to attack you over it. I find this idea very interesting, but I guess I'd understand if it was never included, as either your fellow officers would be uselessly standing around or shoot him dead before he could hit you at all. Even so, I think it'd be an interesting and humanizing occurrence. Especially if something happens like "The father of children alone in Acaristan wants to enter the country to find his kids, but because of entry regulations you are forced to refuse him. He steps out of his car to attack you in his rage, but is immediately gunned down" THAT would be potent.
-I understand that the police force of a (possibly) soviet nation would probably never even consider hiring female officers, but I think it would make the game's world feel a lot more real if the occasional female traveler was present.

All in all, the only reason I typed these suggestions at all was because I had so much fun playing this game that it dragged me deep enough to think about it this much. A big thanks to the Dev(s), and I hope to see more from you soon. <3

While the graphics aren't exactly AAA quality....the gameplay itself is fairly entertaining.  I was pleasantly surprised when I started playing to find that this game isn't just sitting at a border crossing and inspecting vehicles.  While that is a fair bit of this game, the developers found ways to keep this interesting, with changing regulations to keep you on your toes.

There is a fair bit of driving around the map, and it was fairly cool at first exploring different areas, taking prisoners to the labor camp, dropping off contraband etc.  Most places aren't interesting enough to visit a couple of times outside of the necessity of going to various facilities.  There are some random events that require you to 'take out' groups of enemies which helps keeps you on your toes.

One major plus for me is character progression and visual representation of your progress in the campaign.  Your character gains rank which gives you more $ on inspections and other things, and you can unlock more powerful guns as you work your way up the ladder.  You can use the money to upgrade your officers gear, or various facilities around your checkpoint.  Each upgrade has a visual change that is immediate upon purchase.  Just one thing that helps me see that I am actually progressing.

Honestly, I would get this game if you were looking for something fairly laid back, and if the game is on sale.  While the game pleasantly surprised me with its content, I was not blown away and willing to pay more than I did for it.

As per other reviewer:

Awesome game! However no endless mode yet. They first said that it would come out in May, then they changed it to June. It is now July and no update or any news about it whatsoever. Will change review to positive when endless mode is out.

New patch suddenly gets you stuck in a vehicle, whether searching it, or driving and trying to exit. Sincerely hope the devs address this as soon as possible because it went from an OK game to unplayable.

The game is seriously lacking polish. I don't know if it wasn't proofread or just poorly translated, but some of the written instructions contradict what the game actually wants you to do. Some of the time when you fail for "entry regulations" it's not at all obvious what the problem was. 

It's a cool idea that actually doesn't resemble Papers Please as much as I thought it would, being more about the inspections than the paperwork, but still needs a bit more work before I'd recommend it. Also a minor gripe, but where Papers Please had numerous factions you could choose to side with and you were incentivised to move quickly, this game has pretty much two sides: government or rebel, and it doesn't really focus on speed. Now granted, the fact that it differs from Papers Please is still a good thing, but I think the speed pressure of Paper's Please was one of its best features, turning time into a resource you had to choose where to spend.

Pretty solid game for the $20 I shelled out for it. Biggest gripes really are the gunplay could be much better and I didn't appreciate bodies disappearing before I could loot them. Story was interesting enough, inspection mechanics were well thought out with only a few little hiccups, and the challenge level was pretty appropriate. If you enjoy these types of games, I'd definitely recommend it.

I really loved this game. Clearly inspired by Papers Please but certainly not just a 3d remake. The closest thing to any criticism I could make of this game is that I wish it were longer.

Everything about this game can be described as thus; simple but effective.

The graphics are pretty on par for an indie title.  Nothing to write home about, but they're clean.
The driving mechanics aren't all that fancy, but you're driving in a 1980's post Soviet country so it feels right.
Gunplay is surprisingly solid, which is good considering you get into a LOT of shootouts.

As for the main mechanics of the game; checking for contraband?  It's pretty easy (so far) and straightforward to get into. You look for the smuggler icon and start wailing away on it.  Before long you'll be a grizzled border patrol agent doing your part to keep your country safe.   Or y'know, you could take bribes, sell contraband on the side and have your own little блат operation running.  Either way you'll have the money to upgrade your outpost and buy better gear, weapons, and vehicles.  I won't get into the story so much, but it looks like you'll also have some choices to make there too.

Overall this game is weirdly addictive and lots of fun.  Looking forward to when they implement a sandbox mode in addition to the campaign.

Pros: The concept is great, controls don't really feel clunky, driving feels great & smooth (esp in 3rd person), and I love having the choice of what path to take in the story. Big props to the devs!

Cons: Firing weapons often feels inaccurate (I'll have the sights directly on someone's head right in front of me and still miss somehow), at times checking cars and IDs can become a little tedious and repetitive (especially when it comes to remove heaps of cargo from the vehicles). Overall, it's a fun mix of a chill simulation game & a cool FPS. Just needs some stuff to keep me coming back for more.

I just finished the game, and this is my opinion, which might help the dev team and other players who are undecided about buying it.

Firstly, I must say that I really enjoyed it, so I'll give it a positive review. I played through the whole game without getting bored or anything like that.

Although it's quite repetitive, and you mostly do the same tasks, it managed to hold my interest. The fact that the torch doesn't reveal everything, and you need to keep an eye out for hidden stuff, is a plus that prevents the game from feeling too mechanical.

There's a significant variety among all the newcomers. As far as I can recall, I didn't see the same face twice. However, I have to mention that there are no women in the entire game. Everybody is male, which made it a bit monotonous for me (I'm not getting into issues of sexism or inclusivity; I'm simply saying that seeing only guys all the time got a bit boring).

Overall, I quite enjoyed playing it.

On the downside, I would like to point out that I didn't find anything in the story that made me go against the government. In games like Papers, Please or The Beholder, the dark side of the government is more obvious. However, in this game, I couldn't see a reason to be against it.

Similarly, there are a few moments where you can choose to help people and let them pass. I did it, and apart from a thank-you letter, there wasn't much difference if I hadn't let them go. I suppose it's just the personal satisfaction of helping people.

To be honest, I had the feeling that there's no real story. Things happen, but that's it. They ask you to go here and there, fix a situation, but I didn't feel like there's a proper underlying story.

Sometimes, when I caught someone with contraband, they offered me a bribe. I accepted it once, but the money wasn't even the same as the penalty I received for letting them pass, so I didn't do it anymore. I earned more money by following the rules (the bonus for catching a criminal, sending them to prison, confiscating the contraband and promotion is greater than what they offer you).

Another thing is that the guards in the zone are a bit useless. I mean, they help when you get attacked in the control point, but they do nothing when a newcomer tries to escape. Also, you can't take one or two guards with you as cover when you go out and get ambushed, which happens constantly. I think they could be more useful.

It would be hard for me not to recommend.  There have been a few games that have tried to replicate what Papers, Please did but I think they missed the point.  The point shouldn't be to *replicate* what Lucas Pope did, instead be inspired by it.  And here we have "Contraband Police," one of the worst titles I've seen in a long time.  But don't let that particular aspect fool you, this is a very competent and thoroughly well-designed game.  It's not quite an immersive sim, and it has a story to tell.  Gameplay consists of checking paperwork, yes, but also a lot of investigation.  What condition is the car in?  Does it's tonnage match?  Is it registered to the right person?  The game makes full use of it's 3d nature having you comb inside and out, checking cargo, opening suitcases.  There's just as much to visually inspect as there is paperwork to compare.  And then you realize all of it is interactive because smugglers can and will hide contraband literally anywhere and everywhere.  That's the baseline, ph neutral.  And if the game had *just* been that I'd still be giving it a big fat thumbs up for just how well it executes on this premise.

Yet, in swoops a larger game.  Getting into gunfights, investigating crime scenes, delivering prisoners and contraband, purchasing tools and supplies, upgrading your people and station.  And all of this, while not *quite* as detailed or involved as the core loop, are still delightful.  You might get ambushed while delivering a prisoner.  Someone might try to buy illegal contraband.  You can even do some light trading with the drivers before you deny their entry.  This is where the game shows it's thoughtfulness: none of this stuff is just there to fill out time.  It all works together to build this world of chores you inhabit .  Will you side with the government for the paycheck?  Or the rebels?  It's not a terribly deep game, but it puts details into all the places that really matter and it shines for it.

There's an endless mode on the horizon and we'll see how that plays.  Personally I think the story mode is very well done, it can be planned and give the player a specific experience, but I can see how a more procedural endless mode to play with the mechanics is desired.  I bring this up simply because I think the game is worth it *now*, and frankly I'd be just as happy seeing a sequel announced.  This game was an unexpected treat and I'm looking forward to spending more time with it.

This game might look kind of janky, but its actually a super solid game. The core game play loop is very satisfying and fun, especially when you get a perfect check. You can then invest your money in upgrading your border post too and it adds an extra element of fun for you to watch your border post gain new staff and bigger buildings. The shooting is pretty decent, especially for a game that does not have too much shooting in it. The only complaint I have is that the driving isn't great, and I have found myself having to drive quite a bit. Besides that, I have not experienced too many bugs. When I have, they were never game breaking or annoying.  If you are into simulation games, I can't recommend this one enough.

"Papers, please" meets "Mount&Blade", set in alternative 80's version of a Warsaw Pact country.
Great concept and great realization. It's an amazing twist on "Papers, please" formula, where monotony of checking documents is broken by cargo inspections, shootouts with criminals and car chases. The game is fairly short, took me around 16 hours to complete the story mode, but upcoming sandbox mode promises a lot of replayability. Game mechanics are surprisingly good. Everything is simple and to the point. Special mention: authentic models of old Soviet cars and weapons, it was really blast from the past.
Overall, very fun and complete game even in its Early Access state, and it's only going to get better as the new content will be added.

7/10 Great concept, satisfactory execution.

A positive review is merited simply for creating such a unique game, generally well-polished and bug free. There are, however, several issues that make this game merely "good" rather than truly "great."

The worst part of this game is the FPS portions: your base is periodically attacked by hordes of enemies. The very first attack already has you killing so many super-weak enemies that it feels like you're playing Space Invaders, and it only get worse from there. By the final battle, you're facing nearly 100 enemies in a single wave. yet it's so easy to kill them that it's a yawn-inducing chore.

Another major gripe I have with the game is that though a single mis-matched name or passport number can be reason to deny entry, the game gives you bonus points for finding multiple violations per car. This makes no sense. Nor does it make any sense that after each inspection, your supervisor announces whether or not you made the right call: if he's so utterly omniscient, why are you even there?

Furthermore, the overwhelming majority of people you check will have some error in their documents which requires you to deny them entry. This also makes no sense. My guess is that the game wants you to find all the various reasons to deny entry per vehicle checked, but I would have preferred a more realistic experience: one in which the vast majority of documents have no violations what-so-ever, and your job is to find the occasional criminal hiding among the crowd. As it currently stands, 9 out of 10 vehicles have to be turned away, and law-abiding citizens are the exceptions.

All that said, it's still a fairly enjoyable game simply because of its uniqueness. The story, though nothing super special, is generally enjoyable, and strangely enough, the driving mechanics are really good for a game that isn't really about driving: the FOV is spot-on for realism and comfort, and the handling (assuming you are using a controller) feels better than many a driving-only game I've played.

All in all, worth the price.

Let's put down the facts, they're charging $20 for a game, and you're getting $25 worth of content. There's nothing crazy about it, but you're getting a full game that currently is good for 2 play throughs. It takes heavily from Papers Please, but still keeps things fresh by including the cars being searched, rather than a straight copy-paste. 

With games like this it can get a bit worrying that things will drag on, but I felt it stayed pretty fresh throughout. Every day you have about 4-5 people you check. After that, though, then you get 'free time' to go around the island and search for secrets to get you some extra money. Along with that Every once in a while you have bonus objective to complete, which could range from transporting smuggling prisoners you captured to defending your outpost during an insurgent raid. 

This is a game that isn't insane on anything, but offers a good experience with a short quality story. And that's what a $20 game should offer, rather than poor half baked ideas like a lot of other games offer.

Ok so I just finished the game and I would like to review it. 

1. I beat the game as a Revolutionary which gave me the Blood Fist ending.
2. I was a three stripe rank but I am not sure how much more I could have been promoted.

Pros
- Characterization was well done
- Game is a lot of fun if you don't like Ukrainians
- The whole Soviet Block feeling is totally there.
- Police corruption 
- Killing border jumpers (extra fun)
- Missions are fun
- Night raids on your base rock
- Decor of Mother Russia is top notch
- weapons are realistic
- The ability to beat civilians with crowbars, shovels, pipes (but not too many times because they are fargile)
- destroying vehicles and property if you are into that (most american are)
- Build up enough cash and just murder legit people for a full day of work as they pull up with passport ( $500 buck a head fine eh)

Cons
- Driving needs work
- Can only take one bribe (Not soviet enough)
- Lots of timers on things but healthy timers (I am not a timer person)
- tools break too damn easy (I like to beat my victims senselessly after killing them)
- heads don't break open if you beat them rigorously (need to show brain splatter)
- No Russian Brothel (Whats a soviet block without a brothel)
- Not much snow, hmm
- Can't drink the vodka and get drunk on duty (That's a soviet innate trait)
- Driving again
-  The trailer video shows people getting knocked out at border. Can't knock them out only kill them if they run. Only murder them if they run.
- Your Save Game file deletes itself after the credits. Little upsetting. 

So yeah I would recommend after he posts endless mode.

Some points for why the game is worth it:

The story is interesting and fun like a 3D game of Papers Please and some choices you make can lead to death.
The game mechanics are controllable but a little wonky making for some fun car driving.
The economy of the game can be really felt from start to mid but in late game money is not a problem.
The combat is not hard but you can die from getting cocky or not finding cover. (I killed around 400 Terrorists in whole play through and died about 10 times)
The border checkpoint gets more complicated overtime and is consistent with new paper requirements like Papers Please. 
The contraband scenarios are like a car mechanic mode where you use many tools to hit and bang everything.

Contraband Police has a great atmosphere and a nice mix of mental and gameplay challenges.  One minute you are crawling through someone's backseat ripping it apart with a knife looking for contraband and the next you are jumping out of your patrol car and blasting would-be assassins away when transporting prisoners.  It captures that eastern-block early 80's cold war feel and you have plenty to do.  I wish it was even longer but what is here is fun and worth the price of admission.

Trying to get perfect inspections is not as easy as you might think, especially after a few weeks when you have a laundry list of things to check into.  Take extra care when inspecting vehicles for damage!  

You can be a government jackboot or help the rebels who are trying to take down the establishment.  Plenty here to sink your teeth into, and I didn't expect to like this kind of game as much as I have.  Highly recommended.

I don't review a lot of games, and honestly my selection on what I choose to play though fully is garbage. The campaign can be done in less than 8hrs if you don't screw up and are a fast learner. 

Tips - 

- You need to pay attention to mission dialogue, because sometimes you have no idea what's going on. 

- Once you get the AK don't spend $ on anything else. It has almost no recoil and almost always 2 shots if you're a good shot. 

Leveling up stuff  is "kinda" worth it -

- Leveling up the prison is recommended. Lets you hold 8 prisoners which is the max capacity for the largest truck. 

- Leveling up the storage room isn't really worth it. The largest truck only holds 25 units, and I think that's the capacity for the first tier... Not afraid of being corrected. If you have it upgraded all the way, there's no point in hoarding stuff then selling all at once, because you can't..... Even if you pay $500 to have the police transport show up you're still making two trips on your own. 

- Leveling up the shed you sleep in IS recommended though. Increases health allowing you to stay alive in fights/ driving around and increases perception allowing you to blow through border stops faster. 

- Leveling up you guards and hiring more IS recommended. Helps you get through ambushes easier and they don't die as fast. 

- I did not upgrade the vehicles, because I didn't see a point in increasing their speed when they all handle like trash. 

All in all, good way to blow time and I had fun. Just don't expect good AAA stuff when the game is $20.

So, Contraband Police. Someone was clearly inspired by Papers Please. No seriously think about it, your a Boarder Guard, in a Communist country, upkeep to worry about, and [spoiler]you have the option to go against the government.[spoiler/]
So Whats the game like? Well, its Papers Please, but MORE. The game is a more "realistic" approach to being a Border Guard, in fact your the Border Guard Commander. In addition to checked peoples Documents for Discrepancies, Finding Contraband (ill get to that in a minute), taking bribes (if you so choose), you got a whole check point to worry about and world to explore. Instead of feeding your family and paying rent, your paying out of pocket for the Maintenance of your Checkpoint and paying all your Comrades at the checkpoint. So how do you pay the bills you ask? Well by doing your Job, taking Bribes, Trading with people coming though your checkpoint (its Legal), Transporting Prisoners to the Labor Camp and Dropping off contraband at the Police Base, winning Ambushes, Defending the Checkpoint, and Doing missions.

Now, it should be said its not as simple as "Allow or Deny" like Papers please, if you want to get paid IN FULL from each Inspection you have to be THROUGH! i'm not kidding, a Perfect inspection pays you way more then a simple "allow or deny". CONTRABAND, Oh boy this is time consuming, Smugglers will hide Contraband in their Cargo and even in their Vehicles, and YOU have full authority to disassemble, destroy and search all of it in order to find whatever they may be hiding. (and as above it PAYS to be through, so feel free to take the whole dame car apart if you feel its necessary) And you have several tools at your Disposal to do it (knife, axe, blunt, shovel, pitchfork), They will eventually brake (losing durability with each HIT) and you will have to buy new ones.

Once your DONE with all the Newcomers and you got some time to spare, you can transport anyone you have arrested to labor camp and bring any Contraband you find to the police base for extra cash. If you have the spare cash and can pay the daily UPKEEP, maybe invest some of that extra cash in upgrading the Checkpoint (such as upgrading personal or getting more personal, or upgrading your quarters or the storeroom or the Jail, maybe buy a new vehicle) or getting yourself more Weapons and Tools.

Did I say Weapons? Yup, we got COMBAT and MISSIONS! No worries its pretty simple, shoot bad guys (headshots do help), take cover, try not to DIE. You will get ambushed while driving around the open world (sometimes right as you leave the checkpoint area, and no your comrades will not come to help you, funny enough the people driving around will gladly run over the bad guys), or the Checkpoint itself will be assaulted (all you have to do is survive for a time, then kill any remaining enemies. Your Comrades WILL help defend the checkpoint at least). Also sometimes you will get "intervention missions", these are optional missions that pay well for your trouble. You do have several guns to pick from as well, and will unlock more as you Rise In Rank.

If you have ever played "Papers, Please," and loved it, you shall very likely enjoy Contraband Police. 

It does make a nice exercise for your brain's ability to quickly process attention to detail. It does add more of a world with a bit more life than "Papers, Please." For those of you that have not played "Papers, Please": This is a neat bureaucracy simulator which Contraband Police expands upon nicely. To get an idea of how much you may or may not enjoy this game, I'd encourage watching some videos of gameplay. Look out for something you can do such as get in a firefight, drive around, find contraband in a vehicle and arrest its operator, take the arrested smuggler to the labor camp, turn in the contraband to a police warehouse, be a corrupt officer or be loyal and by the book. You can choose to be loyal to the government or be loyal to the underground bugaloo that aims to tear down and replace the communist regime.

Other notable things: If graphics are your main focus of what you must enjoy and appreciate from a game, this one might not be for you. That said, the gameplay experience itself makes up for this. I just so happen to value good overall content, mechanics, and even a well-thought-out story can be appreciated above graphics quality in a game. If that sounds like you as well, then you might also enjoy this title yourself.

As of the time of this comment, I just read the announcement about their start on building the Endless Mode or Free Mode and I very much look forward to that becoming available in the future!

Controller support is currently not available at this time, so I hope that isn't a deal-breaker for any of you. [EDIT: Controller support was just announced and updated for the game, so you can ignore that last bit.]

In case the devs and project directors ever read this: Ever thought of making a co-operative experience in a game like this one? Expands the possibilities. I hope this one gains enough traction and popularity to financially support that endeavor.

I have been simply enjoying the gameplay experience overall and wanted to bring some attention to a game that has tapped into the lost arts of what provides good quality to games.

Contraband Police surrounds a fictitious 1980's communist totalitarian state of Acaristan and you play an unnamed commander of an entry point to your beloved mother country. Your daily tasks include vehicle searches and ID checks and finding contraband that may be smuggled. In the campaign, the occasional mission or incident pops up where you have to find someone or something and gunfire usually ensues. This leads to the game's low point with lackluster combat and poor movement mechanics, but the surrounding game is still a blast.

It sounds boring, and it should be, as you get a sense of the doldrums and repetition of life as a border guard. Developer Crazy Rocks did an excellent job of capturing the spirit of the less-than-dynamic true life of law enforcement that surrounds routine, paperwork, and mundane tasks. What they also nailed was vehicle searches. I found the cramped vehicle interiors where your camera is limited in movement and you have to shift about in the car to look under or between something to be spot on. There are many nooks and crannies for smugglers to hide their booty and it's aggravatingly easy to miss something. Likewise, just going over the paperwork with your subject, you can easily miss a name misspelling or a registration number being off by one character. As the game progresses you feel yourself getting sharper and catching minute details more readily. There is a perception check function you can use when you're getting tired or having trouble deciphering a long name. It has limited uses but it's great in a pinch.

Then the alarm sounds and the rebels attacking your great state come flowing from the hills and you have to defend your tiny outpost. You can upgrade your checkpoint with better guards and equip them, which helps later in the game as the rebels attack in greater numbers. The combat is disappointingly basic, however, and I mean it's a half-step above Space Invaders from 1978. Bad guys will try to run to cover, even flank you, but when they take a shot they stand perfectly still for several seconds. Their aim is atrocious and I've walked through crossfire at point blank range unscathed several times. I'm past the halfway point and haven't upgraded from my pistol because I'm nailing headshots with it from across the map due to the sights being static and the target holding perfectly still.

The investigations missions are also a bit disappointing. There's a murder at a tavern and you're supposed to question everyone and determine the killer. The alibis don't add or subtract from anyone's guilt and the "crime scene" is pointless. In the end you randomly pick among six people or go to YouTube to find the answer as simple logic is lacking entirely. Add to this muddy graphics and stiff character movements and it's easy to lay some hate on this game, but you shouldn't.

It's not perfect but the actual checkpoint itself is a rewarding 3D puzzle of seek and find that has a hard time getting old. Every vehicle is different, every driver responding in different ways, and the occasional pursuit breaking out turns the game into COPS: Russia very quickly. I'm enjoying the game and I will continue to repress the rebels and ensure the safety and prosperity for my beloved nation. Come, comrades, join us, for the good of Acaristan!

I did find myself getting a bit frustrated with the ever-expanding list of things to check sometimes, but once I found my groove, it wasn't as much of an annoyance.

I would like to give a very constructive criticism; First of all, the reason why I recommend the game is that the first few hours of the game are quite enjoyable and you really have fun in the process. In my opinion, it can be tried on a discounts just for this sudden enjoyment.

But the game is starting to get extremely boring with little interaction and activities and repetitive days.

They tried to create a small world, and  it's a nice idea to take prisoners to camp or go somewhere to sell contraband, but it was a terrible way they implemented this. 
Vehicle mechanics are absolutely terrible, such a mechanic like this should'nt exist in 2023. The roads are always the same and curvy becomes boring to drive after 2 minutes since you watch literally the same environment.

Our main duty, the border guard, starts to repeat strangely after a point because we always do the same things and we don't have a proper target to improve. 

I really liked the details such as trying to interspersed with a story, murder solving, etc. It breaks the chain of being a border guard and feels like a change of atmosphere, but the story missions are too slow.

Random events that will fill every day can enrich the game. The only random event is getting ambushed by 4 raiders.  New interaction events that can be added will enrich the game. Increasing the typology of vehicle mechanics and roads/landscape and environment will positively affect the atmosphere.
At this point, you see that I played the game for 6 hours, and I played the last 1-2 hours by forcing myself. The final decision is up to you, I wrote down all the troubles I encountered here :)

Title: Contraband Police: A Promising Concept Hindered by Execution

Rating: ★★☆☆☆

Contraband Police, developed by Crazy Rocks Studios, is a game that aims to simulate the intense and dangerous world of border patrol and law enforcement. While the concept holds great potential, the execution falls short, resulting in a disappointing and lackluster gaming experience.

The game puts you in the role of a border patrol officer tasked with detecting and apprehending smugglers, uncovering contraband, and maintaining law and order. The premise is intriguing, and the idea of immersing players in the challenging and morally complex world of border control is commendable. However, the game's execution leaves much to be desired.

One of the major shortcomings of Contraband Police is its lackluster gameplay mechanics. The core gameplay loop revolves around stopping vehicles, inspecting them, and searching for hidden contraband. Unfortunately, the mechanics are clunky and often feel unintuitive. Interacting with objects and vehicles can be frustrating, with poor hit detection and imprecise controls hindering the overall experience. The limited variety of tasks and repetitive nature of the gameplay quickly become tedious, lacking the depth and variety needed to keep players engaged.

Additionally, the game suffers from a lack of polish and optimization. The graphics are subpar, with dated visuals that fail to create a visually appealing or immersive environment. The open-world setting feels barren and lifeless, lacking the vibrancy and attention to detail that could have made it more engaging. Furthermore, technical issues such as bugs, glitches, and occasional crashes further hinder the gameplay experience, detracting from any enjoyment that could be derived from the game.

Another significant letdown is the game's lack of compelling storytelling or meaningful progression. There is a lack of a cohesive narrative that could have provided context and purpose to the player's actions. The absence of a clear progression system or meaningful rewards diminishes any sense of accomplishment or motivation to continue playing.

While Contraband Police attempts to create a realistic portrayal of law enforcement, it falls short in its implementation. The game fails to capture the complexity and moral dilemmas inherent in such a profession. The interactions with suspects and the decision-making process lack depth and fail to provide meaningful consequences for the player's choices.

On a positive note, the game does offer a multiplayer mode, allowing players to collaborate or compete with others in enforcing the law. This mode adds a slight layer of variety and can offer some enjoyment when playing with friends. However, it does little to salvage the overall shortcomings of the game.

In conclusion, Contraband Police falls short of its potential due to clunky gameplay mechanics, technical issues, lack of polish, and a failure to deliver a compelling and immersive experience. While the concept is intriguing, the execution ultimately hinders any enjoyment that could be derived from the game. If you're looking for a realistic law enforcement experience, there are better alternatives available in the gaming market.

Great

Solid game with inspiration from "Papers Please." 

First the bad:

The overall story is pretty meh with little to draw you in. The money mechanic is really only a threat if you overspend. 

The combat is interesting while feeling out of place - why is a checkpoint inspector mowing down wave after wave of smugglers/rebels? I mean, the occasional shoot out makes sense but ambushed almost every time you run around?

Also, if there is a giant police HQ, why are you fighting these folks?

And, of course, there is a somewhat out of place stealth mission. 

The good:

This game scratches that itch "Paper's please" excelled at. You'll need to check paper work across multiple documents requiring cross references and seal verification and verifying a manifest isn't off by more than an item or a vehicle weight exceeds it's certification. 

Then, when you get a smuggler, the fun of tearing apart a vehicle and looking for smuggler stamps. There is nothing like thinking you've found every bit of contraband but then checking one last time in the engine bay only to see a pouch of contraband hidden away. 

The mundanes of transporting prisoners and contraband is fun and is coupled with an out of paying for it to be done for you if you are not interested. A blackmarket would have been nice to resell things for more than the paltry amount you get from Police HQ. 

The dev would do better focusing on the already polished inspection mechanics coupled with base building(such as a switch that deploys spikes to stop a vehicle from escaping) with the rare shoot out. More character models(women, etc.) 

There is an "endless" mode in the works I think will solve some of the issues with the campaign and the dev has shown willingness to keep building this game. With enough work, a $5-$10 campaign expansion that greatly improves mechanics would work for both the developer and fans.

Some red flags to consider when shopping for "simulator" titles like this: 

1. When you click on the developer's name it redirects to the entire PlayWay S.A. catalog. It's common practice with PlayWay to obfuscate what games a developer worked on before their current one, especially when the current one is likely to gain traction with content creators (like this one, which is going to sell itself on "a 3D Papers, Please.")

2. Gunplay. Sim titles like this are a hodgepodge of mechanics and ideas, usually thrown together to pad for time. First-person shooter segments are never the strong point of a simulator title and this one leans into them quite frequently. Having spent a little time with it: the guns *could* be worse but they're in no way fluid or fun. Just bog-standard, and the only real UI to facilitate shooting is a weird red dot hovering over enemies, which feels like the result of a developer realizing all the earth tones in the map and character designs means you can't actually SEE the enemies that well. The solution: a cartoon dot that you just have to aim under to get headshots every time. 

3. Too many concepts. Contraband Police could be a solid game with just the border crossing and the idea of upgrading your outpost to be more effective. Gas Station Simulator showed you can have a really jankily-built game still have a sense of progression just by hiring AI and assigning them to do your least-favorite tasks. 

Frankly, I'd much rather not have to leave the outpost and partake of the lackluster driving sequences to travel to locations I don't particularly care for. Even the shootouts where the border post gets attacked could be interesting IF the whole point was I can upgrade my post to the point it's self-reliant. Sure, I can give my guys better guns and armor but at the end of the day, I still have to throw contraband and prisoners in a van and go run chores early-game. 

From reviews I'm seeing here, I know my dream of having a Gas Station Simulator-esque border crossing where I level up my NPCs to do menial tasks automatically (perhaps even add multiple inspection lanes and let an NPC do inspections for me with the understanding they have to flag me if any real inspection is needed) are not to be. The upgrades are purely to make things stronger when random attacks happen. 

It's aggressively okay, but I worry I'll be back to this review in a few hours of gameplay with the same story most popular simulator titles have: after the first few hours they KNOW a streamer will broadcast, it drops off. Maybe it won't. For now: buy with caution.

Generally speaking, I genuinely do think this is a game worth picking up, especially if you enjoy job games. 

The core gameplay loop is quite addicting, something about meticulously checking through a list as you pick your way through someone's vehicle is very rewarding.

I will say that the story is kind of forgettable, its a political commentary that doesn't really bring anything new or profound to the table, just the kind of thing we've seen represented in media for about a century now. 

I also find that the game does drag you away from your work to do "main missions" that aren't really all that enjoyable, they ironically feel like more of a chore than the vehicle checks do.

Also, you will get attacked on the road and at the checkpoint RELENTLESSLY, expect to get into 1 or 2 shootouts a day. The novelty of bandits wore off by the 4th day imo.

[h1] THIS IS NOT A REVIEW TELLING PEOPLE TO NOT BUY THE GAME. THIS IS JUST WHAT I THINK OF THE GAME AND WHY I DIDN'T LIKE IT [/h1]

I like the idea of the game. It's basically (like everyone else says) an FPS version of Papers Please. The idea in the beginning is really nice with a border control you can upgrade, a quite nice scenery and decent game play. The problem starts coming in later in the game where the inspections are just repeated. And with the introduction of the new mechanics like that you NEED to write down when a vehicle has a damage just feels boring. The side missions is IMO sometimes more fun than the real game-idea since I find the inspection just too repetitive and in the end I was just trying to get done as quickly as possible so I could finish the game. Maybe the game just wasn't for me, so of course not everyone is going to agree on what I just said.

I also think (like some other people said) that there should had been more focus on the border control area. Where buying more guards & upgraded them actually helped. Just getting attacked all of a sudden didn't really feel so fun in the end (and I doubt the guards did anything at all) and when I had to drive after people that escaped the control I just wanted to quit playing. It really feels like I could run the whole border control by myself, which is not realistic at all.

For example: 
 - The guard in the entrance of the control should be able to do stuff, maybe already give a heads up that 'the next car is looking suspicious' or something. 
 - The guard at the exit should be able to activate like spikes or be ready with a gun to take out the person trying to flee. 
 - The 'mechanic' should be able to drive prisoners or contraband instead of having to pay for it. 
[b] There was a lot of potential here so I'm quite disappointed with the result. [/b]

In the end, I think you should definitely play the game if you feel like border inspection is something for you! But with the too repetitive game play, the unnecessary border upgrades (which really makes earning money quite not important other than buying the AK and new tools), and the pretty bad gun-play, The game wasn't really for me.

[i] Maybe I'll come back in the future when the game has recieved a few new updates and maybe changes in the game play, but for now having played one ending is more than enough for me. [/i]

Details:
My initial thought was this game is like [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/239030/Papers_Please/][b]Papers, Please[/b][/url] but in 3D (for which [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/unqlfife/recommended/239030][i]my review is here[/i][/url]. It's brief but why a wall of text when not needed?).
From one respect it's legit, as the game mechanics is similar, as well as the era, plot, etc... But this game is different, as well as offers more on many levels - so it's not fair saying this title is a "clone", it's more "inspired by".
The player is not "locked" to the border booth: There's chasing, shootout, carrying prisoners and items, investigating (a bit sloppy, but still, it's something), upgrading the border crossing, guards, vehicles, etc. and it looks like a story is building out and I'm just a couple of hours into it.


There are a few negatives, but I'd say it's more constructive criticism from my side in hope devs read (even positive) reviews and might mind these points. Once again, don't let these scare you away from buying the game, these are more improvement ideas than actual problems:
[list]
[*]Lighting is a bit puzzling, there's a lot to fix there... One needs a flashlight in broad daylight at shady places
[*]Broken windows are very hard to see, would be great if window tint was changed
[*]Holding RMB to aim is last century, it should toggle (or at least offer an option for that)
[*]Cannot load "last checkpoint" only on fatal failure, this is a bit cheap
[*]Smuggle areas marked with a snake is cheap and makes the job far too easy: It would be better if one had to inspect instead, depending on element type (e.g. knock the bumper / wheel / tank / etc, push and hit the seating, open and search bags, etc). This way it would be much more interesting to find smuggled goods. Could be a minus if a part was taken apart with no smuggled goods in it (i.e. one was just destroying everything). As of now, it's just a visual confirmation where the contraband is, with a very little chance of missing it, not fun
[*]Cant' start the engine with the hotkey when sitting in the car... really annoying (I also don't like there's no indexing and horn and stuff but no big deal, it would just be fun)
[*]Attackers (ambushes) come too often; from what I've seen it was more frequent, but still... I'd also consider making these less annoying, e.g. mark the map ahead of time (secret services did a great job or something), so the player might decide to take a different road - but if not, I miss roadblocks. What kind of ambush doesn't try to block the road?
[*]Also, I'm not very inspired to diss them for just a handful of dollars. There should be a better/bigger reward
[*]I've no idea why there's a "pull" option for dead people instead of a single-key-press-quick-looting something
[*]I also don't like corpses tend not to have anything on them, but some ammo (cash, a grenade, a knife or a crowbar, whatever, really. Some variety)
[*]Adding to that, would be nice if Vlad bought stuff from the player too, not just sold things. For example, contrabands (ehehehehe - maybe it will be a thing some time in the game and I'm just not there?)
[*]Initially it was confusing what happens when I ask for a tool shipment. By the 3rd try I catched the text written out, so I understood the dude will come over as a mobile shop in the night, but it was not obvious at all
[*]Would be better if had to mark the checklist: green OK, red NOK, no mark: forgotten / skipped
[*]For saved Perception (i.e. manual verification of vehicles), there should be a bonus when going to sleep, e.g. making some extra money (folding boxes half the night as a side job or something)
[*]Color codes: Red should be trouble only, there should be different colors for other stuff, e.g. daily costs could be blue (I'm always like "Jesus what did I do wrong again?!" with a mini heart attack, when it was just a totally normal payment)
[*]On decisions, it's siding government or rebels... Well, no? If one was sent out by the gov. to catch someone, not doing so is at least suspicious. I think there's no way to change this but for the next game, designer(s) should mind the possible reasons behind decisions, not the choice itself - it's a decade old mistake designers make, really annoying, especially if I'm left no option but to choose "A" if I think for the long run... (Where it is the most "painful" to me was [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/unqlfife/recommended/1222140/][b]Detroit: Become Human[/b][/url], a great and wonderful game (10000% recommended to play), with some bad mistakes
[*]I checked the name [spoiler]Volk Jonas (ish?)[/spoiler] and it looked OK to me... can be a bug or a mistake on my side... But I was super-sure the name was OK
[*]Unsure if can win the fight in the tutorial, but it's annoying there's no way to try again
[*]Would be fun to have character development / skills
[*]Daily summary's closing amount sometimes is covered by the 'Continue' button's background bar
[/list]

It hurts for me to put a thumbs down but here is why. While it is a fun game there is a lot that can be done to make this a 10/10 game. The checkpoint should be the focus of the game yet you are sent on too many side quests that involve very mediocre mechanics and horrible driving mechanics. The gunplay is not great at all and needs to be severely improved. While the addition of side quests such as helping local police in gun battles or responding to other crimes or contraband interceptions is fun at first, they get extremely repetitive yet you do them to be able to afford upgrades to the checkpoint. I love the fact how you can upgrade the checkpoint from better buildings to hiring and upgrading more guards and getting new cars but the concern is that the guards with the exception of gun fights are useless. I wish you can order the guards to perform more tasks such as transport prisoners (or at least accompany you for backup) and maybe even the ability to help with inspections (real world 1 guard doesnt run a border checkpoint). They need to add things to make the checkpoint gameplay more unique and be the focus of the game and cut back on the really small lackluster world quests. Add more passengers, add tow trucks to move cars instead of talking to a guard, add other events besides attacks on the outposts and maybe more customization to the outposts that matter. I know I am rambling and this game is fun but there is so much more that can be done to turn this game from a fun game to a spectacular work of art.

I have just finished Contraband Police. It's... a *very* Playway game. They tend to be... weird. Like, this is extremely influenced by Papers Please. But it's 3D. And you're also dealing with a vehicle and cargo.

And bandit raids. And revolutionaries. And smugglers. So there's some first-person shooting.

And there's an open world aspect. Sort of. It's not much of a world, but it is there. There's some hidden collectibles by the points of interest, which just give you $ and a sense of completion. And missions to go to these places for a variety of things. It's not always combat. One was a murder mystery.

None of it's done terribly *well*, of course. The enemies do take cover and pop up to shoot... but can also be seen reloading away from cover while standing upright. Your allies do lay down a lot of fire in a fight, but not all of them aim. NPCs get different looks, but it's like, 5 beards, a couple hats, and a couple glasses. All white guys. Though, at least they remembered women exist, as one voice on the phone is not a guy.

This is why Playway titles are always kind of fascinating. Not just for what goes in, but what corners get cut. Most are worthwhile, many certainly manage to be something Different.

So I do somewhat recommend this game. It runs, it's a bit janky, but rather bug-free. (The only thing I noticed was 1 vehicle on 1 day that consistently ding'd me on import restrictions, despite being under the limit.) It's not great, but it does get a (minimally) passing grade in the many areas it tries to provide you with an interesting experience.

The story itself isn't very intriguing, but everything else is super fun.

The only thing?  I wish they hadn't made up the language that they use in the game.
You hear NPCs talking all of the time but it's largely gibberish and to me sounds mixed in with Spanish and Russian??  It's weird.  I wish they just used Russian.
But I really enjoy upgrading things and the mix of having to chase criminals running the border checkpoint, avoiding or killing criminals trying to break prisoners free, checking all of the things at the checkpoint, etc.  It's a fun, unique game.
Like I said, it's addictive.

With most games, there are some gripes and some bugs. But there are always some positives as well so let's start with those.

The graphics are great, for what the game is. I've had no graphical bugs or errors, no prop or character bugs, nothing. I'm impressed.

There is a story to the game which I've not yet completed. I've only just begun but the game gives a very strong hint to its intentions from the start.

Money-making is pretty easy. There are a few ways to succeed here, however, they're not always easy. 

Driving controls with a k&m, considering I usually despise driving with k&m, this isn't too bad.

HOWEVER:

There is NO controller support. This is a HUGE gripe for me as I usually always play with controller due to disabilities... I can manage with K&M but it damages my joints after a while. It doesn't put me off playing but it does limit my play-time which is a shame.

The combat is... Pretty bad. Once you can get a rifle it's a little better but still not great.

If you can look passed these issues, I'd definitely recommend but the game does need a lot more attention

Contraband Police is its own worst enemy. 

Screening people entering the boarder, and checking for contraband is great fun. I wish I could do it all day. 

Then the game interrupts my daily checks because "the border station is under attack" so now I get to play a shooter. 

Is the shooting BAD? No. Is it as good as an actual dedicated shooter game? No. It's mediocre.

And this repeats over and over. Start actually playing the most polished and fun part of the game (the border screenings) and get interrupted to do a half-baked stealth mission. Then a half-baked investigation mission. Then a half-baked tail sequence.  Every single one I begrudgingly complete to get back to the border screenings.

I don't need this game to be CoD, LA Noire, and GTA. Some people with bad tastes or low budget might appreciate this "a bit of everything" approach.  But as an avid gamer I wish the game would've stuck to what its good at, and the part that is the most fun.

Papers Please is one of my favourite game, so a 3D Papers Please sounded awesome!
I have however a few problems with this game:
- the story is scripted and every person reaching the checkpoint is the same
- there is enough variety in cars but not in people; why are cars driven by a single man every time?
- the gameplay at the checkpoint is quite nice, but the driving and gunplay mechanics are too shallow to be enjoyable
- the stealth gameplay is abysmal (one step too distant and you lose but the guy you are trying to follow can see you inside the vegetation, what?)
- the stiff animations are really too much of an immersion breaker for me

Much respect for the developers, but I think all the effort on the gameplay outside the checkpoint really should have been dedicated to the core gameplay loop instead :(

I would recommend Contraband Police for its satisfying gameplay loop, which mixes driving, first person shooting, and moderately complex border guard/ bureaucratic roleplay and management. You can tell the game has been lovingly crafted by it’s small team, and was high quality at launch, with no bugs or persistent issues. 

Contraband police puts you in the shoes of a border post manager in the fictional communist/socialist state of Acaristan. During my roughly 15 hour playthrough, I upgraded and managed the staff and facilities of the post, performed inspections of travelers through the checkpoint, defended the post from attacks, ferried contraband and arrestees to their final destinations inside Acaristan, and managed stocks of tools and weapons. There were occasional missions and side quests to keep things interesting.

Each day, a handful of cars passed through the checkpoint and it was up to me to pass them in or deny their entry based on the legitimacy and correctness of their documents, or just how I felt about the traveler. Some with illegitimate papers begged to get inside, others tried to bribe, others just ran through the checkpoint.  This made the game fun. At one point, a man was begging to get inside, he was a refugee from a war and his kids were alone inside Acaristan. I let him in even though his papers were incorrect. I later received a letter from him thanking me, with a few children’s drawling’s inside. Little things like these were really neat. 

You also be a tough cop, break someone’s window and then deny them entry because of a broken window. You could choose to follow the increasingly strict rules of the state or make your own decisions based on circumstances. 

Some tried to smuggle contraband into the country, and it was fun inspecting their cars and cargo for the illicit goods. You could take bribes or sell the contraband on the side.

The FPS gameplay was good, and the action was satisfying. 

I would recommend Contraband Police because it is genuinely fun and entertaining. Its story is alright, but its fun and varied gameplay loop kept me coming back.

Contraband Police is very consistent with the type of games that the developer/publisher have released in the past. If you've found their other games boring then it'll be the same, but if you enjoy them then this should fit right in with you.

Spotting the errors in documents, and finding the hidden contraband was a challenge at the start but soon enough I managed to ace all the inspections without errors. It's rewarding to see how efficient you can become at the game.

As for the content, having a bit more side activities that you can engage on your own time would add a lot to the game. The game gives you several story missions which were surprisingly fun to do.

At the end, I had a bit too much money without much to spend it on. I managed to max upgrade the border quite quickly, so more weapons or gadgets would be fun.

Also, I believe a "New Game+" or some endless mode would be fun once you've finished the story. After the final mission your save file gets automatically deleted, which was bit of a bummer. If there are updates to the game, then not having to start from scratch would be a lot better.

I liked this game my first couple of hours. I kept seeing videos on youtube and tiktok about it, so I looked into it to try the demo. The demo was fun, they gave you just enough content to make you want to get the game (which worked really well), and I ended up buying it. 

I didn't really care for the story at all, it was kind of boring to be honest, it's a "important choices" game where you can choose which path you want to follow, but in the end your choices effect absolutely nothing aside from which story you see. Nothing changes gameplay wise so it feels like the story isn't important in anyway. 

I didn't buy the game for the story anyhow, I bought it for the gameplay, and the gameplay is really fun. I love taking down smugglers and arresting them then finding all of their hidden 'cargo', it was a blast until the last couple of hours of the story, because then the game just got really stale. There were new things you had to look out for, but it wasn't enough to keep me wanting to come back.

I finished the story after 10 hours of gameplay, and was upset to see how the game ended, and the fact that you couldn't keep playing. The game just automatically deleted your save and you couldn't go back and keep doing your job or anything which is a HUGE bummer for me. I really liked the gameplay, but finishing the story was really upsetting because I couldn't keep playing on my save post-story.

I would recommend this game if they didn't have such a bad story, and even if they did have a bad story, at least let us be able to play the game more, not just automatically kick us to the menu and force us to restart from day one. There isn't even a newgame+ or anything, so you have to redo the training and all that. 

Not to mention how boring the combat is, when you see the trailer the game looks cool because you get to shoot stuff, but every gun in the game has 0 recoil so it's like you're shooting a squirt gun at people. If you don't want challenging combat, then this is something you can look forward to, but if you do like a challenge look further because there isn't even a difficulty option. I died probably twice in my entire playthrough, once because I got stuck on a tree while being shot at, and another to a bug.

I will recommend this game in the future if they add an endless mode with more upgrades and such, but right now it's not worth the price in my opinion. 

4/10 story, 4/10 combat, 8/10 gameplay.

I remember playing Papers Please and that game was so much fun to play yet this game in my personal opinion is so much better. I had so much fun, I played the demo twice and I just had to buy the full game... I've played the game for around 4 hours now and I have no major complaints. The game runs smoothly even on ultra graphics. Whoever is thinking of trying out the game please do. I couldn't recommend it more. 

1 slight complaint that I could make is that getting out of the car can be a little annoying sometimes, like the player character won't go out every time, which has cost me some chase scenes... yet that could also just be because of my Bluetooth keyboard. I can also just restart the day so that kinda solves that "problem". But all in all i'd give it a solid 8.5/10. Maybe even higher.. Is it perfect? No, but is it fun? 100% Yes.

PS: 
The demo is pretty much the first 45 mins to 1hour-ish of the game. So, I would try half of the demo out first and if you like it just buy full game otherwise you'll have to experience the same thing again in the full game... I had to experience that 3 times but I didn't mind since I thoroughly enjoyed every second.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I've had this game on my wishlist for over a year as I've really liked the concept of going through the process that many border control officers have to go through on daily basis. I've played the prologue before I played Papers Please and I got hooked. The political circumstances help create interesting moral questions and decision makings, similarly to how this is done in Papers Please. In my review I will be comparing some core similarities these games have in common.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
Overall, the mechanics have been really well done. Shooting, quests, checking documents, ambushes, etc. are great.

The driving however is overly sensitive and it is very hard to get used to for a couple of chapters, but after a while it becomes somewhat easier. However driving the fastest car in the game (Zaved) can get you in weird losses of traction while going through turns where this wouldn't necessarily happen.

Also the ambushes are quite predictable, they seem to happen in about 3 - 5 places. A little bit of randomness and better timing would make it feel more like an ambush.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay overall has been great, the storyline is interesting and covers a lot of interesting choices of taking sides. You are faced with moral situations of letting someone pass who is in a hard situation. However, I didn't find most of these arguments to be as heart-feeling as in Papers Please, I couldn't quite connect to the characters' hardship and I felt more compelled to take a stance with the government.

I've felt the same way regarding the overall Government vs Rebels side, you are never given a strong enough reason to not necessarily take the side of the government unless you really really wanna take the Rebels' side. You are more than fairly compensated ([spoiler]Not like in Papers Please where you are paid like 5 credits per person and you barely make rent or enough money to pay for food.[/spoiler]), you do not have any moral obligations to someone([spoiler]Such as having to help out take care of your niece or to provide medication for your family.[/spoiler]), you also do not have a strong enough motivation to disobey or take bribes([spoiler]You receive about 611$ per bribe by a smuggler, and once you max out your level you get about 200$ per correct check, 160$ if you make a couple of mistakes. You also get 200$ for each prisoner and about 400$ for 25 contraband items. The bribe amount should be made higher to incentivize rebellious behavior.[/spoiler]), also being with the Rebels does not seem to give you any strong benefits like in Papers Please([spoiler]At least there EZIC seems to give you live-changing money for your family which to be fair is hard to reject, even as you are doing good things and obeying the government, you're still being screwed fueling anger against the regime. But in Contraband Police you are treated like a human being and any bad dictator-like behavior is not really shown.[/spoiler]). Ultimately if these things were slightly changed it would've made a significant and more balanced experience for the whole storyline.
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Personally, this is an amazing game, I would've just made a couple of the changes listed above to even further improve the game experience but otherwise I'd recommend it to anyone.

Contraband Police is so far the best game I have bought in 2023. Whilst it would be easy to call it open world or 3d papers please, the truth is that it's more than that, its one of the more compelling police simulators out there right now.

Game play wise, there is a central tasking mechanic of inspecting vehicles and ensuring people pass or don't based on the policy at the time. There's an interesting story line focused on the dying days of the Eastern Bloc which is interesting as well. But in addition to this, you do very much take on a wider role as a general police investigator and also the manager of the boarder crossing as well. You get to upgrade your base and team, which keeps things fresh as time goes by and gives you a sense that even if the rest of the world is declining, you're able to hold things together somewhat when its under your control.

Like a lot of other games published by payway, it's got a good game, but the quality is somewhat lacking. It's a great game for 2023, but stuck inside the graphics of the early 2010s. Going open world was a great idea and I think pays off, but at the same time the world itself is very basic, narrow roads and nowhere where the population is really living. I'd like to see a version of this game where there's more focus on the police aspect as well, and the story line focuses on a police officer struggling to do their job whilst the entire system is falling down around them. 

There are some errors and some immersion breaking parts of the game that come from the lack of quality and a dated system, but whilst that sounds bad, i think its good: Because for all the little things that might bug me, they just make me want to see a sequel be made that fixes them and builds out what I think is a fantastic concept.

Contraband Police - A Challenging and Intense Border Control Simulator!

Contraband Police is a unique and challenging game that puts you in the shoes of a young officer trainee working at a border post in the politically strict Acarist People's Republic in 1981. As you work to regulate entry into the country, you quickly realize that every move you make is closely monitored by the party, and the situation at the border becomes increasingly tense, especially after the tragic death of one of your comrades during an intervention.

One of the standout features of Contraband Police is its focus on document control. As an officer, you are responsible for checking the validity of every visitor's documents, and even the slightest discrepancy can result in refusal of entry. The game starts off relatively straightforward, but as time goes on, the number of documents to check increases, and the errors become more difficult to detect. This adds a layer of challenge to the gameplay, requiring keen attention to detail and careful decision-making.

The game's setting in the mountainous region of Karikatka is beautifully rendered, with detailed graphics that capture the atmosphere of the time period. The sense of tension and suspicion in the air is palpable, and the game does an excellent job of immersing you in the world of a border officer during a politically sensitive era.

The gameplay itself is intense and engaging. You'll need to carefully examine documents, cross-reference information, and make tough decisions on who to allow entry and who to turn away. The consequences of your choices can be far-reaching, affecting the story and the outcome of the game. The sense of responsibility and the weight of your decisions add to the game's overall immersion and replay value.

The story is intriguing, with the death of your comrade adding a layer of mystery and intrigue to the game. As you uncover more about the events at the border and the political situation in the Acarist People's Republic, the plot thickens, keeping you invested in the outcome.

One potential downside to the game is its level of difficulty. As the number of documents and errors increases, it can become quite challenging to keep up with the pace, and mistakes can have consequences. However, for players who enjoy a challenge and the thrill of high-stakes decision-making, this can be seen as a positive aspect of the game.

In conclusion, Contraband Police is a unique and immersive border control simulator that offers a challenging and intense gameplay experience. With its focus on document control, intriguing story, and immersive setting, it's a game that will keep you on your toes and test your skills as an officer. If you're up for the challenge, put on your uniform and get ready to uphold the party's regulations in this politically charged game!
