The year is 1981, and as a young officer trainee, you are assigned to work at a border post in the mountainous region of Karikatka. Entry into the Acarist People's Republic is strictly regulated by the party and your every move is monitored! The situation at the border escalates when your comrade is killed during one of the interventions...

 Document control
Every visitor must have a set of valid documents. Even the slightest discrepancy means refusal of entry. Over time, the number of documents will increase and errors will be more difficult to detect.

 Smuggling detection
Our intelligence regularly provides information about suspicious drivers. Search their vehicles using a UV flashlight and then use the appropriate tools to extract the smuggled goods. No amount of contraband should cross the border!

 Shootouts
In some situations you will be forced to use firearms. Your station is a constant target for Oberankov's gang attacks, and every away mission carries the risk of a clash with the enemy.

 Police chases
Desperate smugglers may attempt to escape from the control zone. It is your duty to stop and arrest them! Buy and upgrade police cars to improve the effectiveness of your pursuit.

 Post management
Upgrade your police station to increase its defenses and improve subsequent inspections. However, keep in mind the rising cost of maintaining your station. Successful inspections, foiled smuggling and successful interventions are a few ways to earn cash.

 Special assignments
Always be ready to intervene in an emergency. Solve crime puzzles, support your comrades and thwart the Blood Fist rebels. Make decisions that will determine the future of Acaristan.

My work day started like any other, dull and monotonous with me questioning my life choices. A cargo truck pulled up at the checkpoint disrupting my musing, I hate cargo trucks they take more time to inspect properly. The driver was a foreigner, which wasn't a problem as long as he was willing to respect the rules and laws our glorious party had outline for this great country of mine. As he handed me his papers I noticed he seemed tense, I wondered if I was coming off a bit hostile which would be bad since i pride myself as being a friendly welcoming person. So after I had got him to verify that everything on the cargo manifest was indeed what was in the back I decided to crack a joke the lighten the mood. So I did, the driver chuckled, a crate laughed, I arrested the driver, his smuggler buddy hiding inside and the contraband they were trying to sneak across the boarder. It was productive day.


Okay actual review time.
My sad attempt at wit aside (thanks for indulging me if you got this far), this is nice game, thats well crafted and really knows how to let you get into the swing of things. Especially its core mechanics by gradually introducing them at steady pace so you don't get overwhelmed by them. The plot isn't anything profound or ground breaking but its serviceable for the time and setting but you really should be playing this more for the inspection process which does get broken up sporadically with a little action and gunplay. Visually the game is surprisingly good for something that didn't have a triple A budget (can't say that about a lot of triple A games these days ironically). Anyway if you like analyzing things for inconsistencies and don't need to constantly be in high octane situation this game might just end up being your jam. While the asking price for it is with in reason in my opinion, if you're still on the fence add it to your list and wait for sale then try it.

Game Title: Contraband Police
User Opinion: I couldn't get past the first few minutes of gameplay without crashes.

Review:
Title: A Promising Concept Hindered by Technical Issues

System Specifications:

    OS: Microsoft Windows 11 Home, Version 10.0.22621 Build 22621
    CPU: AMD Ryzen 9 7950X 16-Core Processor, 4501 Mhz, 16 Core(s), 32 Logical Processor(s)
    GPU: NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090, 31.0.15.3141
    RAM: 32 GB
    Resolution: 3840 x 2160 x 59 hertz

Contraband Police has an engaging premise, putting players in the shoes of a border patrol officer tasked with inspecting vehicles for illegal items. However, the technical issues I encountered during my playthrough made it difficult to appreciate the game's potential fully.

From the onset, the game suffers from performance issues. On my system, with the aforementioned specifications, I experienced multiple crashes within the first few minutes of gameplay. This made it nearly impossible to progress in the game, which was disappointing, considering the unique concept and the potential for immersive gameplay.

When I was able to play for brief moments, I found the graphics and overall design to be satisfactory. The environment was detailed, and the interface was intuitive. However, the crashes overshadowed these positive aspects and made it difficult to enjoy the game.

It is worth noting that the developers may address these issues in future updates, but as of now, I cannot recommend Contraband Police to players with similar system specifications. The game has potential, but the current technical problems make it a frustrating experience.

FULL DISCLOSURE: I have not finished Contraband Police, but I've played this game for just under 12 hours so I feel my opinion is valid nonetheless.

Comparisons between this game and Papers, Please are inevitable, so I'm just going to use that as a point of reference since I'd assume most players interested in Contraband Police are at least aware of Papers, Please and generally know how it works.

The gameplay loop is inspecting both persons and vehicles that come through your border checkpoint, and while there is a certain amount of satisfaction in the daily grind and generally getting things right (Finding contraband, upholding regulations, performing perfect audits, etc.), I find the experience to be far more monotonous than Papers, Please. On top of there being much more to keep track of and potentially screw up (EVERY part of each car must be checked EVERY time in order to get the full payment for each audit), there's also no timer to keep the gameplay challenging and interesting. It's not BAD overall, but it is indeed *worse* than I was hoping for.

On top of the regular border checks. there's also the admin stuff, which I actually liked a bit more; You can upgrade your staff by hiring more guards and buying better equipment, you can upgrade the capacity for your prison cells and storage for confiscated contraband, and you can also buy and upgrade new police vehicles.

Yes, there are police vehicles, and this is where the game falls apart for me, as the driving is simply AWFUL to control, and the cars' speed ranges between a snail's pace and WHOOPS, I accelerated right into a tree. Aside from bringing your prisoners and contraband to the proper authorities, the vehicles ferry you across the very small and uninteresting region map for missions, and for the most part, these consist of shootouts with gangs of thugs. The shooting feels very unrefined, I didn't find the gunplay to be very challenging or interesting, and I got tired of it very quickly. It was at least tolerable until the point where I finally stopped playing; a mission where you're shooting out of the back of a police van while criminals attempt to run you off the road in what is effectively a *turret section*, which I feel I could probably beat given a few more attempts but I eventually realized after dying three times that I just didn't care.

Finally I'll touch briefly on the storytelling, and again I'll invoke the Papers, Please comparison, because that game was frankly excellent with its story as every ingame day brought a slew of new story elements affecting the world as a whole, relayed to the player by newspaper or dialogue, and you could always feel things changing around you even while stuck in a tiny booth, and at crucial points you even have a hand in what happens. Contraband Police clearly tries to emulate that system, but it doesn't do so very well in my opinion. The story only updates in chapters, as does the gameplay, and a chapter will last for a few days at a time. That means very little of consequence will actually happen in between moments where you're updated about world happenings via newspaper, and the effect you have on the story seems to be minimal. There's a rebel faction you can allegedly help in certain missions by choosing certain actions. but if my choices were making any impact on the world around me, it wasn't at all obvious that was the case. Presumably it will change the game's ending, but at this point I'm simply not interested enough to see either ending of this game.

Don't buy Contraband Police unless it's on sale, even then, maybe just watch a playthrough online.

This game is a fun simulator for people that are fans of inspections, investigations and immigration. If you found yourself enjoying Papers Please and coming back, chances are you’re going to love this game. 

This game is set in the 1980s in a “Soviet era” fictitious country that resembles Eastern Europe. You play as the commander of one of the posts responsible for admitting and refusing possible entrants. You will progress through different events that occur that take shape other priorities that you’ll be on the lookout for during your inspections. 

Let’s start with the good aspects of the game:

* The inspections you make are varied and fun. Again, if you’re a fan of Papers Please, you will find yourself inspecting documents and searching vehicles for contraband. 
* The setting and environment are nice. It gives you an open world feel without having too large of a world that makes it feel shallow. 

* The driving is fine. The pursuits you make of smugglers and escaped prisoners sometimes feel clunky but you will have three vehicles to choose from. I’ve seen complaints on the driving but it’s really not that much different than My Summer Car or The Long Drive. 

* The story is nice but short. You’ll be able to pick one of two paths with some smaller choices along the way. It’s nice that simulators like this are actually starting to include a narrative. 

Now for some of the negatives or things that could be improved:

* There is no new game + or endless mode after you complete the campaign. You will have to start a brand new save so if you’re working on finding collectibles or trying to get some achievements, better so that before the final mission. 

* The gunplay is stiff. It’s not necessarily awful since it’s not really a shooter but there’s not a lot of recoil on the guns and you’ll find yourself wondering sometimes why certain shots don’t register. 

* There are a few minor bugs. I’ve fallen through the map a couple of times but never really lost progress as a result of the bugs. 

Overall, this is a fun little game that I would absolutely recommend. I intend on replaying the game to do the other route so I believe that the full price is worth it for the hours I’ll get out of it. Definitely get it if you find it on sale.

I've played this for awhile, and it scratches this itch that Papers Please gave but a lot more.  I enjoy being rewarded for being extra vigilant and double-triple checking things.  The developers are active in fixing things and adding features, so I'm sure the game will only get better and better.  Some people may think the story doesn't happen quick enough, but if you had days where you're doing really well, all that money you are getting can get put back into bettering your home, supplies, prison, vehicles, weapons, and tools.  All crucial things you'll need for your everyday work days.  

If I had any complaints it might be this: When checking vehicles for window damage, sometimes it's incredibly difficult to figure out if a window you're looking at is broken or not. I usually get dinged for that and it just makes me roll my eyes when it happens.  Driving is a little drifty, but it's not awful.  

Recommendations for the game would be some aesthetic things you can do to your border crossing, like cleaning up all the weird junk that's piled everywhere.  I'd also think it'd be fantastic if we had some sort of twitch integration built into this so the viewers could be the ones trying to get into the country.  Maybe put that into Endless Mode or a special mode so it doesn't mess anything up.  Also maybe more variety of people who come through the border, currently it's all single men driving in.  I think it'd be nice if there was another NPC in the passenger seat, or if you had women driving in.  Just more variety so it doesn't feel so much like the same.  Weather effects would be rad, I'd love to see like a bunch of rain, snow, or fog.

The developers are feeling for the player base from their release state of Contraband Police. Over the following two months have been working so hard to meet player concerns and suggestions for improvement. AND ITS HAPPENING at such a GOOD PACE! Happy to say, endless mode is coming soon with some really nice QoL features for the community. IT will be interesting to see the revamp of this game once Endless mode is introduced! 

My initial review was negative on many aspects that conflicted my overall willingness to play 'as it was'. I was still playing several hours after leaving that negative review but stopped shortly after. 

That is no longer the story of Contraband Police and I feel the response once the devs have finished their timeline on features+fixes will be overwhelmingly positive! Thank you for reading and responding, adjusting and adapting - with all that was at your feet. You conscientiously made a list of player concerns, and delivered updates on a weekly basis for players to see your commitment to your audience. Much love <3

WORTH THE WAIT!!! WOW! Well done, Finally a well done game!! This was a breath of fresh air, the gameplay is fun, the world is interesting and out of the box, The missions were really cool, the gunfights were challenging and dynamic, the weapons were authentic and cool. The power you felt when you finally got a submachine gun from a pistol was satisfying. Searching for contraband was a blast, arresting smugglers, car chases, very good voice acting and plenty of lore. Upgrading your post was a really cool mechanic, new vehicles with their own advantages and disadvantages. I found it really cool that you could actually choose your loyalty and not get railroaded into being the "good" guy. My only complaint is that it ended, I would love to see new missions, a never ending sandbox mode or a DLC....if its not to much to hope for....a second installment? Thank you to the team that made this happen! I certainly appreciate it. worth every penny. 10/10 LONG LIVE THE PARTY!

You know, I really liked the concept and the first few hours, but the gameplay loop unfortunately gets boring quick. The driving isn't fun, the gunplay is horrible, and there isn't enough variety at the checkpoint.
This game should focus solely on the checkpoint. Why do I hire all these staff and I have to drive everywhere myself and chase everyone myself?
I think: focus on the checkpoint. Add women and children to these cars. Add several men to each car. Every car has only 1 guy. If there are more you have to manage them, where they stand, handcuff them to detain while searching, etc. Here I find cocaine and the guy is standing there like no big deal. Cmon.
We should have to see the markings for contraband but before grabbing it, make believe we don't see it and detain first. Call child services for the kids. Release cars to wives. Call towtrucks instead of just telling that guy (who sounds like a minion by the way) to clear it out. Such a missed opportunity. They tried to do too many things making all of it bland and boring rather than focus on the good part, the actual checkpoint, and really going with it.
Make all of those variety's, make it unlimited, just throw new rules every few days, and I'll play it. But the way it is? I think 12 hours is my max. I was done so fast, and i think its destroying the game. I hope you guys make the storyline way longer. I basically paid 20 bucks for 12 hours. 
I'll check back in a year to see if any of this is implemented, but as it stands now, I can't recommend. Unfortunate.

Altogether, would recommend for the price, especially if on sale! Hoping an endless mode is developed too!

Some breakdown of my opinion of the game:

Story: Good
Graphics: Kinda meh but good enough
Environment: Just fine for this game. The map isn't too small or too big.
Performance: Pretty bad but settings allow one to go down enough to make it run on slow machines as well
Gameplay: Pretty good
Gunplay: Nothing to write home about but there are a lot worse games out there
Input: OK. There seems to be some sort of mouse smoothing that you cannot turn off and that annoyed me to no end. EDIT: There is an option to turn off camera smoothing now!
Stability: Not a single crash or misbehavior in the 30 hours i played this game!

EDIT at 31 hours:
Most points still stand but i find it surprising that this game has replayability! I just finished the game 3rd time and i may still start it all over again soon. My reason for starting the game 2nd time was to play on the rebels side. 3rd one was all for achevements (i still did not get the one i was hoping for) I have started to appreciate this game more the more i play it. It's simple but effective!

It's pretty good.  I'm only a few chapters in, but Steam keeps asking me to review, so here we are.

The game rewards attention to detail, and so far has a pretty good variation in its gameplay.  Sometimes you're checking paperwork, sometimes you're arresting criminals... and sometimes it goes full FPS and you get to neutralize dozens of bad guys with the help of a border police team that you put together and outfitted, yourself.

One small knock against this game is the fact that ingame time moves a bit too quickly, causing you to have to rush certain things in order to complete your tasks before it gets too late in the evening.  If they could slow that down 20-30%, that would be nice.  They do compensate for this a bit though, by limiting the number of things you need to do/check on each day, giving you some options to have services brought to you at a price, and stopping time during a mandatory mission (outside of the border post) so you can take that at your leisure.  I'd still recommend this game to anyone despite the slightly rushed gameplay.

I thought this would be one of those shitty but fun playway sorta games, but nope. It's like papers please, but on steroids (and god damn do I love papers please). You're not just stuck looking at paperwork and whatnot, there's interventions, checkpoint upgrades, buying guns etc. It's pretty cool. 

Two things I'd love to see: 

The more upgrades you get for your checkpoint, the condition improves, like actual roofs, rubbish cleaned up etc. 

A longer story. While the story itself isn't bad, it definitely can feel a bit empty. There needs to be more to it imo This took me maybe 13 hours to complete, and for $30AUD that's pretty alright in my mind, but even story DLC, or a different story line or whatnot would slap, I'd buy it.

Overall though a solid game for the price - you generally don't find many new games around for $30 these days (as most are $100+ which is sorta rude) so it was nice to find a half decent game for a decent price. Met my fun/cost ratio.

This game is a lot of fun, Paper's Please but far more interactive and engaging with things to do outside the border inspections themselves. I finished this game with maxing everything out in 15 hours.  I think it is a good game for the money.  

It is a lot like Papers Please, except a bit deeper in the amount of things to check and immersive 3D world.  The pacing is good.  The build up of information and complicated nature of the game is well done.  The environment looks good.  I never came across any bugs really during my playthrough.  I think I did have to "unstick" my vehicle a single time, but a button popped up to allow me to do so at the one point I needed it, so that was a big win in my book.  

The story is sort of shallow but can be interesting if you can mentally separate everyone and everything in your head.  It should be known that the names of everything in this game has a strong Russian (?) influence with a lot of -rov's and -kov's.  So it can be sort of difficult for my plebian American brain to keep people and groups straight.  

I did really enjoy it, though.  I ventured into YouTube to make a series on it.  Same name as here.  So anyone that wanted to see some unfiltered gameplay can check that out.  I do recommend it, through and through.

This game is straight up amazing.
You may think this is just a boring copy of papers please but its way more then that!
It is worth every cent! For 19.50€ you get around 13h of playtime for one playtrough. There are two diffrent endings as well.
The overall playstyle is inspired by papers please, but you do way more than just checking papers. For example: You have to check the condition of a car, or even check if the owner is transporting illegal items. Sometimes you even have to chase people because they dont stop at the station. The gameplay doesnt get boring, mostly because there are really cool story missions you have to complete. I really like how you can upgrade the outpost as well but i have to say that there is a bit too less things that you can upgrade. I also like how you have to transport prisoners or illegal items to the local police station in order to get a bit extra money. All in all this game is really worth buying, especially if you liked papers please. The story is really great and keeps you interested. The ending I got was really cool and fits the story greatly.

TL;DR - 8.5/10 (let me explain) | Are the graphics on par with the latest AAA titles? No. Are the game mechanics on the same level as AAA titles? Also no. So why did I want to sit down for 8 hours on a weekend and play a game all day? |  In-depth where it counts: Yeah you can only get a few vehicles, and there's only a few levels per guard. But slicing open upholstery for drugs, finding hidden alcohol lodged between the engine, noting down flat tires or broken windows, checking vaccine paperwork and checking if the car registration matches... it's really oddly fun. |  Nostalgia: The game reminds me of an in-depth "papers, please" but it's more of an inspiration if anything, this game is a completely separate experience and I'm really enjoying the many things to do, I haven't beat the story yet.

In contraband police you take the role of a Border Patrol officer. The game takes place in a made-up country with some real life inspiration. On the surface you're going to be a Border Patrol agent allowing or denying visitors into your country.It is not as simple as saying yes or no though, you will be searching their vehicles, checking their paperwork and even chasing them down at times. With all this labor you will be making a paycheck every day. The money that you make is yours to choose with how you spend it in the world, I won't go into too much detail but there are a few choices on how you spend your money. Throughout your journey you will also be asked to participate in quest that will shape your country. How you decide to handle these quest will have a butterfly effect.The gameplay feels solid and there is a nice feel of progression throughout the story. Even though the gameplay from the surface level seems repetitive it is not what because of the elements are used to mix it up. Because of the political instability you never know what is gonna happen on any given day.Overall for $20 this is a very unique game that I would definitely recommend if you are on the fence about getting it.

[h1]Mixed bag or an indie gem?[/h1]Well, it's both. I really loved the demo, I loved the fact that there was a demo (and not some dumb EA kind of stuff), I really waited for this game. Yet, I can't bring myself to finish it. Contraband Police tries to distance itself from getting called "Papers, Please! 3D", and it tries really hard. But I'd say [b]too[/b] hard. There's nothing wrong about taking inspiration from another indie gem. And there's nothing wrong about trying to spice up the gameplay to make it your own.Problem is that it's done poorly. You have free roaming on Caucasus-looking mountainous map, but there isn't a single 50m stretch of straight road, turning everything into a weird slalom simulator. Slalom simulators are [u]annoying[/u]. I don't play video games to get annoyed. So what was the grand idea behind this terrible design? There's wild nature, but it's very clearly using exact same 6 or 7 foliage assets. There's ambushes, but enemy has no AI. There's missions - but they come off as poor clones of "missions" you get in every other game, sort of like random picks from Skyrim or GTA. Follow that dude at a distance, talk to people to solve murder, shoot some guys in the cemetery. Which is also fine, if it was done well. Skyrim had 270 well-crafted quests. This game barely manages to make 5 of them work. Everything just feels like a checklist - it's there, but not a dime more. Bare minimum to say "We have it" and not lie. You go looking for contraband in the cemetery, and every time your shovel touches the ground, 3 enemies spawn around you. It's so blatant, boring, visible and annoying sort of game design that it turns you off immediately. Add a random timer. Make a car stop nearby. Make them paradrop from the sky. Just add a sound of a helicopter to the game, suggesting they landed nearby. Just do [i]something[/i] to make me feel less like a clown in a game that has design complexity of wooden toy blocks. On the other hand, core idea is really cool. Everything seems to work, more or less. Everything looks like it should, more or less. While there's quite a bit of bad busywork crammed in (like those "quests" and raids that never seem to end nor pose any real challenge - you can just wait them out by hiding behind the corner of a garage), there's also quite enjoyable busywork to be had, here and there. So in conclusion, time not badly spent.Priced reasonably, and at least the effort and love of an indie developer being very clearly seen, I guess it's alright. I just wish game design was a bit better thought-out and more polished. Maybe we'll see it in next game?
This game is addicting in a good way. Such a simple concept done really well and with just enough mix up and periodic changes to keep it interesting. I'm hoping for a sequel or DLC's one day.

Great little game to scratch the "search and siezure" itch. This has the best police vehicle/document search type mechanic I've seen and would love to see it in a proper police-type game. It's really quite tricky to find everything wrong with a vehicle and get a perfect score. It's satisfying when I did, but not so frustrating when I didn't because I realised I somehow forgot to look somewhere.The weak areas of the game are definitely the driving around the map and the shooting. It's pretty much a headshot shooting gallery. Fortunately these parts of the game don't take too much time. The story was decent but I can't keep all the names straight so I really didn't know who anyone was even by the end.Again, I would love to see a proper police patrol game use these document/vehicle search mechanics; it's a lot of fun finding contraband.

I really enjoyed this game. It knew what it wanted to do, didn't overstay its welcome, and it never felt like the inspections were punishing you. A QoL feature that I really appreciated was that your inspection timer paused if you left on a mission. This didn't happen with supply runs (as expected), but when you accept a quest it pauses the time of day. By the end of the game I was so flush with cash that I never did my own transports. It was delivery for Vlad's Tools and my comrades would pick up my prisoners with a phone call. I would give it a solid 7/10, above average and worth the $20 USD.

I've waited years for this game, and I must say I was not disappointed. I finished the campaign, and it was amazing. If you enjoy papers, please you will definitely enjoy this, without a doubt. Very similiar to Papers Please setting/story wise. I haven't finished it yet, but so far I can say that it has a story in addition to the outpost management and border control routine. The shooting, driving and such is acceptable, not really much more to say about it.There are some random events that involve lots of shooting that break up the monotony, they never last longer than a minute or two though.You have to manage your funds and you get punished if you let a car through that shouldn't, you can upgrade your base and the crew of the base. You can buy and upgrade your cars, but don't expect anything more than old eastern european shitboxes. There's a shop where you buy tools that degrade, guns and ammo. Games like this, similiar would be games like Station Simulator really do have a place I think. Do you ever feel like playing a game but you don't want the intensity of Cod, CS or the intense management of an RTS, or the eternal grind of an MMO,- if you want to play a game, but not THAT game? Then I would dare say that this is for you, its a really nice break from everything else, and it has wonderful pacing.I'm 5 hours in now, I estimate around 10-15 hours total before it goes on the shelf, probably forever and I'm going to be happy I played it. Buy if you need a temporary break from your other games.

I have had this game on my wish list since it was first announced. My opinion is that overall it is an ok game with the potential to be a really good game but there are some incredibly frustrating mechanisms getting in the way, namely combat, AI, and tools. Combat is not so bad but most of the weapons feel under powered. Next is tools and oh good God are they something, the tools are so weak it really takes away from the fun of the game. You will constantly have to go to a tool shop that is very far away in order to buy more or call to have them delivered, however if you have the police truck at your checkpoint then the tool delivery can not come. Also some tools allow for alternatives but others do not which makes no sense. For example you can cut with either an axe or a knife but you can dig ONLY with the shovel: not the knife, not the pitchfork, not the axe, not even your own hands. Have a mission where you have to dig three holes? better bring like 2 or 3 shovels, and ONLY shovels. Also your fellow AI customs officers are pretty useless, you can upgrade them all you want but they don't contribute anything to the actual searches of vehicles, delivery of prisoners or contraband, or to stop fleeing suspects. Its really frustrating to watch a suspect announce "I'm gonna run away!" then slowly get in his car and start driving away just to watch all 8 of your fellow customs officers do nothing to stop him at all, just stand there like cows while you have to do all the work. the only good thing the AI is good for is during raids on the base but the thing with the raids is that they can just be disabled from the menu, thus making the AI officers EVEN MORE useless.

Very good game if you're looking for a more in depth 3D "Papers, Please". This game had a rough start at first, but after the 1.0 release, this was an incredible surprise of a game. The car mechanics felt a hint off but honestly I just put that off as "80's cars driving like boats" so that is a minimal issue. The only time I had any sort of instability was only once during a single mission where the game froze and crashed. Otherwise the only main complaint that I have is that I felt like the smuggling/contraband system held your hand a little too much. I don't mind the fact that nearly every contraband was given that snake mark, but I did mind that every smuggler in the game you got forewarning with on the notice board, so I actually took it upon myself just to not read the notice board's smuggler warnings as they made it too easy. Also I found it strange how the lowest number of contraband I had found in a single vehicle was at least 3, and I never had a moment where someone was trying to be cheeky and just smuggle one little item in, it was always a huge haul. Also why couldn't you sell your excess ammo or weapons somewhere? even for dirt cheap? I had purchased weapons only to be given that weapon a mission later or a couple missions later so I would have two of the same weapon which was not only useless but a little detrimental at the early game because inventory was a little tighter. I would just end up throwing ammo or repeat guns on the ground since I couldn't do anything with them. BTW this list is basically every complaint or nitpick that I ever had with the game, so considering that's literally all I can complain about? That's Pretty Good.

In terms of good things: the gun mechanics and sounds were incredible and I loved every shootout I got into as it always felt suitably epic. The variation of gameplay felt nearly perfect as it would give you anywhere from a day to 3 days in game of just checkpoint duty but then sprinkle in an intervention or a story mission seemingly right as I was about to feel repetitive. I liked the upgrades system and staff system decently, even if I wished that the staff had just a hint more life to them (maybe a convo between nearby staff every once in a while or something they comment on to you in passing? Idk) and almost always felt like I was at the correct difficulty in regards to money and getting equipment. Also the fact that if you accidentally went in debt it would give you to the next day's maintenence to fix it felt very nice. I felt like story missions/decisions didn't really need to be any more complex than they were and always clearly telegraphed what side you were picking with each decision, but I never felt like I knew enough about either the govt or the blood fist to really be compelled to pick a side beyond "Communism is bad m'kay?" or "Those are criminals and you should be loyal" but there was also a good amount of world building through the news/regulations system that I did at least feel like things were happening in the world (even if they were just a little quick to come and go)

I went in expecting an asset flip, but what I got was an excellent extension on the Papers Please detail checking formula combined with some enjoyable open world and combat that got a little repetitive by the end of the playthrough

This game is wicked good fun, the searching mechanic is fun and by the end of your playthrough there's a huge number of details you'll need to be considering if you want to get perfect scores.

There are two main storylines you can choose to follow, the open world has collectibles and secrets to find and the game has a fairly robust upgrade system where you can use your hard earned Acaristani dollars to upgrade your own statistics of those of your subordinates.

A recent patch did address the rate at which you get ambushed while outside of the checkpoint which was a pleasant change - in 1.0 it felt impossible to drive anywhere without getting shot at constantly, and most of the guns and all of the vehicles do feel satisfying to use

The open world does feel a little wasted at times in that there are a few points of interest however you don't generally have a reason to visit these outside of a few quests, and most of your time spent driving will be between your checkpoint and one of two other locations.

The game as a whole has an excellent sense of pacing, and will always seem to know when to offer a new combat encounter or event to keep things fresh as soon as the car checking and ferrying of prisoners and contraband starts to get stale.

There is music on the car radio, however this is limited to two songs. Would have been nice to have had some more variety on the radio given how much of your playthrough will be spent driving around outside of the checkpoint.

All in all a real hit in my opinion, absolutely a sleeper title in 2023 and well worth your time if you're prepared to pay for a game that's flawed but fun and interesting.

It's one of the few games i've looked forward to in recent years, and then playing the prologue prior to release increased the hype for me. On release it was everything I expected and then more. I will admit, the constant ambushes when driving did get a little cringe and annoying but the premise is there, but thankfully the developers addressed that in a previous review/changelog. I just wish the game was longer, if there's potential for DLC and enough interest please make some! Heck, if it needed a kickstarter I'd even donate. I like how the game gives the option to be a law abider or a filthy rebel, especially the financial implications of the choices too. 

One negative thing I will say though is the ending is a bit weird. It's not bad or anything, it's just anticlimactic, you can't sense the game will end and boom it's over. But nonetheless it's been great fun and i'll replay it to see how i'd fare if I make different choices at key points.

If you're wanting to play this game, it's for the border checking sections.  Which are very fun if you enjoy things like Papers, Please.  Sometimes it doesn't give you the best details on what counts against regulations, either that or it can be buggy with it's own checkings.  I'm still not sure if soap is counted as a chemical or not.  

The shooting sections that are sprinkled in are as generic as can be.  I think they are at their best when a raid happens on your checkpoint and you have to fight alongside the guards you've upgraded.  I would probably enjoy most of the shootings ections more if I could have a guard or three tag along with me to help in fights.  It'd at least make me slightly more satisfied.  

TLDR: Border checking is really fun, maybe slightly buggy or not clear sometimes.  Shooting sections are boring, but a necessary evil.  Oh and the story isn't too much to write home about either, about as generic as the shooting.

The game is good, I enjoyed playing it and searching for contraband and following the story. If you liked Papers Please I think you might like Contraband Police. I think this game had some love put into it by the developers and I really did enjoy playing it. That being said I have a few points of feedback.

The lack of explanation on "Cargo" types was tricky when regulations were increased.
Its hard to tell if side missions are important or not.
Putting the "Youre free to go" and "Transfer to X" buttons next to each other made a misclick easy with no verification for release of prisioners.
The repetition from the "Manger? Leader? Boss?" of the check point when finding contraband or waking up.
Why am I the only one doing all the work at this checkpoint? Mikel helps load cargo but never unload, everyone else just stands around until we are attacked.
The story was okay, felt lost at times, especially the ending I dont remember alot of these names at this point.
Driving in and out of the labor camp was annoying, need those laborers to widen the entrance.
No women or passengers pass through the checkpoint? I get that its a strict county but even in the soviet era women were had equal rights to men so not sure why I never saw one only heard them, bit of a sausage fest.

Wow. What a game. This game gets you immersed VERY easily. The story line for a SIM is Decent. The tasks you're required to do is not busy work nor fetch quests but rather you play the role of a detective, a defender and an auditor all at the same time. The detail involved for you to inspect areas of vehicles was really good, however, could be improved but considering this was released 12 days from this review, i can't complain. No complaints on the gun play honestly I enjoyed it. The driving can be a bit tedious at times since most times the places you need to go to are far from each other but the starter vehicle isn't half bad. However, I found that trading with the newcomers of the border to be pretty useless and quite unrealistic? (idk if IRL border officers trade items whilst on active duty with new comers only to arrest them for smuggling 5 seconds later xD). I managed to unlock and max out all weapons, vehicles, commodities and personnel without ever having to trade with any newcomer nor personally deliver the prisoners to the labor camp or contraband to the station. I always called vlad and prison transport to the border. Another thing that bothered me was the incoming Main quest calls and give you a timer to answer the phone calls forcing you to interrupt inspection, I think they should wait till all the cars are done clearance and then a phone call can happen cuz even then, I doubt a border control stops operating out of no where because an officer got a phone call about a murder that happened at a restaurant LOL. Also, the money you get to stop driving and eliminate the gang members shooting you isn't worth it AT All as you only get  $70 across all stages of the game. you can only buy 1 AK Mag with that. But I do very much believe the pros outweigh the cons by a mile. I think the price is somewhat justified if it continues to get updates and bug fixes and hopefully maybe a DLC expansion? Overall rating 8/10
Very fun and chill. This game is like a meal thats not too much and not too little its just the perfect amount to leave you satisfied

This is certainly a good game with interesting story mode but there has to be a mode where you can work as a border guard for unlimited amount of time. Maybe these random places like the hotel, bar and so on should have some content in there? For example once your shift is over you could just head to the bar for some vodka? With the "endless mode" you could really add so much content to make it more enjoyable. The story itself is rather short and since the game heavily introduces different kind of time limits on when you have to go to certain places you just can't really delay too much on completing the game, hence the endless mode is needed bad. I also think contraband should be in random cars and not only in those that have been flagged in advance. This would really force you to check every car to make sure nothing is hidden there. It's similar to real life when anyone can really be smuggling something and not only those that you've gotten advance notice of. I also think if you found contraband outside the vehicle and the driver was still inside, maybe at random times he would try to run away upon seeing you found illegal stuff? So you'd have to ask him to step out to prevent this from happening but even then at random times the person would get back inside his vehicle and run away. I know there are random people running away atm but it should be expanded further.  Maybe you also should be able to search the person for possible contraband? Upon searching you could find other lethal items like guns or knifes? Maybe sometimes they'd attack you with a knife or gun too to make it more interesting?


I think we should also be able to sell weapons and ammo at Vlad's store. I was able to collect so much shotgun ammo from all these ambushes that I really wish I could've sold it somewhere but it would only allow me to drop them. Overall it's pretty good game but it really needs more content and more importantly the endless mode. Once endless mode is in place, add more stuff to different places that you can visit off duty.
Welcome to Acaristan!

Ah, Contraband Police - the game that lets you live out your wildest dreams of being a customs commissioner and stopping all those pesky criminals from entering the beautiful land of Acaristan. It's a tough job, but somebody's got to do it!

But let's face it, with all the criminal activity these days, it's starting to feel like Acaristan is the only country left on Earth with any law and order. It's a good thing we have brave heroes like us customs comissioners to protect our borders and keep us safe from harm.

And speaking of harm, it's just tragic-comic that the government of Acaristan has started to see even the game "Contraband Police" as a threat to national security. I mean, come on - it's just a game, right? But I guess they're worried that we'll all become so addicted to it that we'll start smuggling contraband in real life!

But never fear, because us customs comissioners are here to save the day. We already confiscated 100.000 illegal copies of the game, just like a true customs commissioner should. And when those lonely nights at the border post start to get too much to bear, we can always sneak in a little game time on the old computer in the customs barrack. It's like you're living out your own little episode of Contraband Police in real life!

And let's not forget about those hardware donations - because hey, if someone's going to sneak into Acaristan, they might as well bring a little something to make our gaming experience a bit smoother, right?

May Acaristan remain the shining beacon of law and order in a world overrun with criminals. Long live Acaristan!

It's just fun. (8/10)

Pro -
- Whilst simple, it is easy to become complacent which in turn forces you to focus to get it right; and for me that's a great thing. So many games become to easier and than boring, whilst this will penalise you when you forget or overlook something in the inspections.
- I enjoy the ability to customise the base and than balance that against your income. You need to think, will this improvement be worth the cost of purchase and on-going costs to run. 
- I find comedy in the general interactions between my character and all the entrants or smugglers. 
- Their are good elements for morals/ethics decisions at play; do you accept a bribe to allow a man entry to save his family or enforce the law(s). The letters you receive later in the game give indications to how that worked out for those individuals.
- I like managing/deciding on whether I take the arrested to the camp, go buy supplies or hand in my contraband after full-filling my duties at the post.

Neg -
- There is much interaction between you and your hired help, additional dialogue or purpose to them would be good; other than that they help you repel attacks.
- Driving can be a bit clunky and whilst using your sirens whilst driving can occasionally cause accidents that hinder you, where you might fail in your task. Although it has made me laugh each time it has happened.  

Possible growth - 
- It would be interesting to see if in the future that their is a barracks for the guards, not just separate upgrades for them; but something that required both. Eg, Barracks level 1 allows for the additional recruitment, whilst level 2 would allow promotion of the guards themselves. The barracks might improve their health and give a fortified position to repel attacks, whilst the individual promotions gives the better gear.  
- Same as above, but improved cosmetics, better upgrades to the yard, no on-going costs, just up-front costs for fencing look, inspection areas etc.
- The upgrades are dependent on your promotion/rank.

Overall, its just fun and I look forward to how far I make it in the game.

Open World Paper Please game is the best way to describe this game. It is an open world simulator type game that basically works just like the title Papers Please where you check newcomers' documents to approve or deny entry into the country of Communist Acaristan (your homeland). While arresting criminals who try to smuggle anything from drugs, weapons, or other illegal contraband.

The game has multiple routes to take your story and more than one ending. As you progress inspections get more difficult as new mechanics and things to look out for are added. 

Very fun game highly recommend if you're bored and need to kill some time with something entertaining.

Charming and a tad janky in all the right ways, yet surprisingly deep. Brings out the corrupt commie in me. 10 soviet sickles out of 10. Quit Stalin and buy this, comrades!

A couple things I'd like to see as the devs put more work into this: more varied loot on dead bodies and clearer directions when you have something to do as part of a mission outside the checkpoint.

Probably one of my favorite games so far. I love the chases, the constant attacks, and throwing anyone that trys to smuggle items in jail. I could play this for hours and never get bored of it. If you want constant action, this is the game for you.

Original Review:

I love this game, but yet also hate it at the same time. I had a hard time deciding whether to give this a thumbs up or not, so I'm sure I will change my review in the future if there are any changes made to the game.

Pros:
I love the way the game plays as border patrol and the ongoing storyline with the country and tough decisions you have to make. Inspecting the vehicles while keeping certain regulations and wanted subjects in mind kept me wanting to play the game more and more. Some combat in this game does make sense. The game also seems very polished, and I rarely run into any bugs at all.

Cons (for me):
The ambushes & difficulty of the combat system is what made me give up playing this game. I am at a point in the story where I have to take a call that requires taking on a lot of enemies by yourself, or else you can't move on with the gameplay. I'm personally not very good at FPS games, and wasn't expecting so much of it out of this game. I understand some people enjoy games like that, but I would personally love to have a setting we can adjust for game difficulty. Maybe even the ability to turn off combat all together or at least minimize it significantly for those that want a bit more of a relaxed experience.

I know there will be updates in the future, and if the ability to change difficulty mode is included with that, I will definitely be changing my review.

Got it on pretty good sale. Would recommend it even at full price. There is a lot of game here. There is the basic Papers Please but 3D part, which imo is a bit too easy for example: they tell you what every smuggler will be and then there are no additional ones beyond that. They don't introduce counterfit documents until way late in the game. Then there is the "open world" bit with various missions and things to do. There are a suprisingly large number of side missions and the "campaign" is suprisingly long and well done. I The base attacks eventually do get fairly hard. but as a whole the enemy AI is pretty dumb but will occationally suprise you with bum rush tactics. 

the monetary system is probably too easy. it doesn't require you to make hard decsions. 

My biggest complaint is no endless mode. 

Overall I recomend it, its compelling and a good price point and leaves you wanting more.

Great game! I was quite surprised by how much I enjoyed this, and can happily recommend this to anyone.

A bit more depth would go a long way however, for example adding more upgrades (A better gate that stops smugglers from demolishing yours every time for example), more points of entry for attacks from the rebels (Having them attack you from the same choke point makes it a bit redundant after a while).

Also adding more checkpoints that the player can automate and manage remotely, with different commanders reporting to you would be great. This will allow you to assist a checkpoint that comes under attack from the rebels (Or perhaps even a foreign army).

That being said, the game is in a great state as it is as a standalone product and is a ton of fun to play. Great job devs!

For the most part the game is enjoyable\fun, but I can't really recommend it in it's current state.

So why I don't recommend it;

[h2]Time Management:[/h2]
While this isn't\wouldn't be an issue in and off itself, plenty of games have time management as an important gameplay mechanic, this game however does not. Time Management feels like it was put into the game, because Papers please had it. Currently, it serves to limit you from doing "too much" in a single day, while simultaniously expecting you to do "everything" in a single day.

Every few days you get further restrictions and complexity to the inspections (this is good, not a bad thing), that serves to take away your time more and more (inherently not necessarily a bad thing). Then, once you've finished the (increasingly complex) inspections, you have to transfer prisoners (with little\no time left), give contraband away, purchase new tools to find contrabands with, and\or get ammo.


[h2]Ambushes\Combat:[/h2]
It is far too frequent. It devalues the experience, ontop of serving as an infinite ammo-glitch (as you get more pistol ammo than you know what to do with). 

[h2]Missions:[/h2]
There's essentially 3 types. Story missions (unskippable), Side-phone missions (5 minutes to answer, then 5 minutes to do it), Side-mission events (F2 to answer, have about 1-2 minutes to press F2 or you lose it, so better not be doing anything else after an inspection! Like a prisoner transfer, or you'll lose out on cash!).

Time-limits, and\or the missions\events themselves are fine. The issue comes in how everything relies on "do it within this time-limit, within this time-limit!", while constantly drowning you in increasing amount of stuff.


[h2]Example of why these points are an issue[/h2]

A standard (later\mid-game) day:  You do a couple of inspections, double and tripple checking the paperwork (3+ different ones that has to be cross-checked, + the cargo lists). Maybe you even arrest a smuggler. Then you get a phone-call (5 min to answer, 5 min to do the mission, have to drop everything else), so you run up and do this. On the way you get an ambush that destroys all 4 wheels of your car (which bugs out the physics a bit and you now barely can drive forward). You do the mission, then try to get back. By the time you're back, it's late afternoon with another couple cars or so to go through. By the time you've gone through, your prison is full, your inventory is full of contraband, so you then starts to unload.

On the way to the prison camp, you get an ambush, totalling the car all over again (as you repaired it when you got back), wether you drive through or kill them make no difference to car totalling (except you'll recoup the repair cost if you kill them).

You get to the camp, unload prisoners, then drive towards the base. It's now the next day, and you also get another ambush. Then after this ambush, you unload the contraband, decide you need more tools (as you're out of tools for searches), drive over to vlad, get the tools, and on your way back, another ambush.



It's not difficult, it's not hard. It's just unenjoyable and serves no real purpose other than to drag out your time keeping you from the core loop of the game (inspections).  Doubly so as Ambushes give you the money to repair the car (once you get back), and recoup more than the ammo you spend (I use about 2-3 pistol magazines an ambush, and get about 6 back).

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Overall, I really enjoy the game. The core gameplay loop is great, and I definitely suggest getting the game, when\if these things gets addressed. As currently, these things just soils the experience (increasingly so).


The changes introduced by Week 2 patch is welcomed and can be used as a band-aid, but I don't feel it addresses the real issues pointed out in my review, and so I still can't recommend it in it's current state. Hopefully the 3rd or 4th week patch (assuming we get that) addresses this, and I can change this from a not recommended, to a recommended review, as I think it's a great game overall.

You know, I really liked the concept and the first few hours, but the gameplay loop unfortunately gets boring quick. The driving isn't fun, the gunplay is horrible, and there isn't enough variety at the checkpoint.
This game should focus solely on the checkpoint. Why do I hire all these staff and I have to drive everywhere myself and chase everyone myself?
I think: focus on the checkpoint. Add women and children to these cars. Add several men to each car. Every car has only 1 guy. If there are more you have to manage them, where they stand, handcuff them to detain while searching, etc. Here I find cocaine and the guy is standing there like no big deal. Cmon. 
We should have to see the markings for contraband but before grabbing it, make believe we don't see it and detain first. Call child services for the kids. Release cars to wives. Call towtrucks instead of just telling that guy (who sounds like a minion by the way) to clear it out. Such a missed opportunity. They tried to do too many things making all of it bland and boring rather than focus on the good part, the actual checkpoint, and really going with it.
Make all of those variety's, make it unlimited, just throw new rules every few days, I'll play it for 1000 hours. But the way it is? I think 9 hours is my max. 
I'll check back in a year to see if any of this is implemented, but as it stands now, I can't recommend. Unfortunate.

The advertising for this game belies it's lack of content and polish. It's more gimmick than game.
Don't pay any more than £5 for this.
This is more of a basic wave shooter than it is a papers please-like.
I appreciate the effort of the story but it's presented so badly; I tried more than once to wait out the telephone calls. 
I'm introduced to the idea that I'm a checkpoint police, let me just play that without the ridiculously tedious wave-attacks, constant ambushes and awful on-rails story missions. 

Sure you'll check some papers, but that becomes the background task that you have to give up in order to do other rubbish, and you'll do it alone. Even with a full stack of checkpoint police, and all upgrades you'll never actually be assisted with a vehicle check. Even in a shootout it becomes clear they don't actually target the enemy but shoot at a specific spot that the enemy are programmed to run through or stop in.
This needed to be a company-development game where you earn enough to be able to delegate some tasks to employees. Instead you're surrounded by husks that you cannot interact with. 

This could have been good but instead its 2010-esque bargain-bin bollocкs
A well put together game. Well worth it.
All hail Generali Acarov.

It's really good. It keeps you on your fuckin toes, I tell you what. That's the most fun part of it. It's like you'll be standing there verifying wannabe citizens' documents all day with your dick in your hand, but you HAVE to be careful because you can't trust a single one of these jackasses. They are unpredictable and they will get you killed doing some dumb shit if you give em half a chance. And it's the clean looking guys you never expect that will fuck you the hardest. Because 90% of the time, the clean shaven guy in a family SUV isn't smuggling AKs in his trunk and cocaine in the tires. Or is he? You just never know. 

I spend extra time inside every one of their vehicles, even if I have no reason to suspect them, because they are all lying pieces of shit. I was doing a routine inspection and this guy comes through the first gate and he's acting like he's my best friend. I ask him respectfully to step outside the vehicle, of course he's like "no problem commander." I open the tailgate to his truck to make sure he's got the 2 washing machines and 4 goats the ledger says he has. This dickhead motherfucker hops in the truck and drives off through the gate. Usually they just blow past it without stopping, whatever. I sense your urgency. 

But this guy, this guy thinks "oh, the border guy is a dumbass, he'll never look behind the obviously fake washing machine" (do people from Al'barakh even wash clothes), he talks to me like we're besties, then he runs like a pussy when my obviously excellent visual acuity catches him red handed. After the chase was over and he was in my cruiser, he started saying shit like "oooh my girlfriend is gonna be pissed when she finds out I got nabbed." lmao guy you are never leaving the labor camp. I have literally never seen someone come out of there, and I drop off a LOT of people. On the way there he ended up catching a bullet (not sure who fired it) from an ambush in the woods. I took cover behind the cruiser and under heavy fire I was able to pop all the attackers with headshots from my trusty Makarov. 

But it's people like that that made me into the skeptic I am today. "I'm not hiding anything." That's what they all say. No one gets a free lunch but I will personally see to it that every illegal immigrant gets a fair shake. The fair shake of my fist. Sometimes when people are impolite to me I pull my gun out and shoot near their feet, shouting "dance, monkey, dance!"

This game looks pretty good too. I'll update the review when I have time to try it out.

Ok i never write reviews but this game is amazing. I thought it was just going to be some Papers Please rip off but it truly surprised me. It has a lot of things similar to Papers Please in the aspect of checking their passports (making sure name, face, and id matches) but when you get further into the game it gets better and better. In Papers Please you'd have people run through the station and bomb it and you had nothing you could do, now if someone speeds through the stop you can run to your car and pit maneuver them off the road, check their car for contraband, arrest them, etc. There's fun little side tasks like murder mysteries, raiding a hotel, or secretly following someone to their house. I think this game has so much potential from what the base game is, you can see all of the passion and care that went into the game down to specific things like how you can flick switches in the car instead of just pressing buttons on your keyboard. There's so much empty space on the map between locations which is perfect if the developers want to make a DLC, maybe add more character interactions, possibly chat options to change how they respond. All in all, I love this game and the people who spent the time into making a game out of passion instead of money. I am so excited to see what happens in the future with this game. My only criticism would be that there's no English dub, I can read subtitles fine but I'll get so focused on reading the info for typos that I cant focus on the dialogue.

I got this game because it looked like 3D Papers, Please and other reviews basically said as much.

Pros:
- The inspection part of the game is really fleshed out and a lot of fun. It seems like it would get repetitive but hasn’t for me at all.
- There’s surprisingly a lot of story in the game, with missions outside of just inspection that change up the gameplay.
- I have been playing this solely on Steam Deck and other than a little bit of lag when driving, it runs great! (You’ll probably have to change up the controls, though)

Cons:
- I’m not a huge fan of the driving or shooting. Both feel unsatisfying and floaty to me, but I think they could be great with work.
- This seems to be common of a lot of simulator games, but why are there no women at all? I can understand maybe not in the actual police force, but it’s hard to believe women would never need to cross the border.

Other than the small cons, I am really enjoying the game so far and already know I will be doing more than one play through to see the other options.

[b]Have you ever felt like destroying someone’s car but never acted on it because, you know, laws and stuff? If so, hoo boy do I have good news for YOU![/b] Contraband police not only allows you to slash tires, rip seats and destroy cargo, but it actually demands you do so to obey the law! I mean yes I’m oversimplifying the game and its appeal but I feel I deserve a pass for being excited about legally wrecking stuff. Why are you saying I should find a therapist?

I might be joking but the game really does allow you to do all that I mentioned, and a lot more. [b]I’ve seen Contraband Police being described as a 3d Papers, Please[/b], and honestly, the titles do have similarities. In this one, you play as the leading officer in a border post. Your role is to allow, or not allow, vehicles into your country of Acaristan. Sounds simple enough, right? Well… it isn’t. Throughout [b]the game’s 11 or so hours[/b], the task gets progressively harder as you get more and more things to pay attention to.

[b]You’ll basically have, in your job, a list of things that you need to check to ensure that you can let them into the country.[/b] You need to check if their names are spelt correctly in all their documents, if their picture matches their face, if their documents are expired, amongst many other requirements you gradually unlock as you play. Furthermore, with each chapter you get some external government orders to take into account. One, for example, has you checking each person’s nationality and denying anyone under 30 years old from a certain country, regardless of whether or not all their other documents are correct. 

[b]You can also find smugglers trying to cross the border when you’re inspecting cars - this is where legally destroying a vehicle comes into play. It’s a super cool system![/b] You basically get tips on the right side of your board of instructions that tell you characteristics to watch for in cars that are coming in. If any meet the criteria laid upon one of the papers, you pull out your UV light and start inspecting the car. If it’s a smuggler’s car, you can find little snake icons in certain parts of the vehicle, which indicate to you that there’s something hidden there. All you have to do is then tear that bit up with tools like axes, knives and crowbars and bam, contraband is found. You can then arrest the driver and keep him in jail until you’re ready to transport him. The contraband should be dealt with by giving it to your superiors. Because you’re all honest cops. Right? Guys?

[b]It may sound a lot to keep track of, but honestly, you get used to it pretty fast.[/b] To help you check some of the trickier things, such as a person’s age (which you have to do by calculating via their date of birth and current date), you have a perception meter that allows you to automatically compare two fields and give you the answer of whether or not there is a irregularity at play. It even marks it in your file for you if there is! [b]Your job then is to check all these things and mark on a checklist every irregularity you can find on a person or their vehicle, and then ultimately deny or allow them access to the country.[/b]

Honestly, if being super thorough bores you, [b]all that really matters is choosing the right option and putting at least one correct reason down in case of a refusal.[/b] You get money from each vehicle you correctly handle, but all that the extra time inspecting the vehicle and documents to find all flaws does is give you more money. And while money does help, as you can get upgrades to help you defend your post, gain more perception, increase the size of your jail, amongst others, I had everything I could possibly buy by chapter 5 out of 7, so the money is really not a major issue. You can game over from running out of money, but it’s hard for that to happen. In fact, it’s hard for anything bad to happen, as [b]this game felt very easy to play through.[/b] The battles were easy, I had upgrades maxed out by chapter 5, etc.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2947904618

So how do you get money aside from inspecting cars, you ask? Well, remember those prisoners and contraband you intercept? They’re a major source of income! See, inspecting vehicles is maybe 60% of the game. [b]Your time is not entirely spent on your post, no. You can take a car and go explore the map, with plenty of locations to see and secrets to find.[/b] One of these locations is a labor camp in which you drop off prisoners for cash. Another is the police base in which you hand in contraband, again for cash. Then we have a shop in which we can buy tools and guns, and the rest are just random locations with no functionality aside from serving as mission spots.

And yes, I did say missions. This is the third major source of income. [b]Every once in a while, you’ll get intervention missions, which are simple assignments you can deny if you want, or story missions. These are the big ones.[/b] There’s one of them per chapter, and you basically get a time limit to accept a mission and get to your objective - usually one of those random locations I just mentioned. These often involve several steps, ending with a choice between two options which influence the end of your game, and the future of Acaristan itself. I’ll be honest: I was really pleased with the mission variety. [b]These were very different from each other, often involving some light investigation moments that I really appreciated.[/b] My favorite was literally a murder mystery, in which you had to find the culprit amongst six suspects.

But while the mission variety is strong, [b]I have to say that the story itself felt very lackluster to me, unfortunately.[/b] The story missions didn’t really relate to the world events that changed how you dealt with cars in each chapter, so it almost made no sense for the game to be divided by chapters. Furthermore, the ending came completely out of the blue for me. Aside from the morality choices at the end, the missions all felt disconnected from each other, and the ending was no different. I genuinely was wondering if it was the end or not until the credits rolled because while I was attacking a pretty massive location, there was no build up for it being the end.

By now, you might have noticed that I used the term “attack”. [b]Yes, the game is a first person shooter, and it does involve shooting a bunch of people at times.[/b] Your post may be attacked, your car may be ambushed, or you may encounter dozens of enemies in your missions. Whatever the case, you must always be prepared for a gunfight, so remember to carry a weapon and plenty of ammo with you at all times! [b]The shooting itself, along with the driving, is… acceptable. But if you’re just looking to inspect cars for mistakes, these will make you feel annoyed at the game.[/b] Also, glitches. I ran into one crash at some point, but luckily, the game autosaves after every time you sleep.

Overall, Contraband Police is a lot of fun, and there’s a demo called Contraband Police: Prologue if you want to check if it’ll be a lot of fun for you too. I had a good time with the game, but be warned that Papers, Please, this is not. It adds quite a bit of things, including a whole dimension, but it also lacks the emotional gut punch that Lucas Pope’s game gave us. I can see people who never managed to get into Papers please enjoying this more hands on experience of inspecting documents and vehicles, alongside the extra elements like shooting, but I can also see fans of Papers, Please not enjoying this as much. Regardless, if you do pick this up, I hope you enjoy it!

As a big Papers Please fan, this game really impressed me. I got more than what I expected.

Vehicle driving - the controls are so odd like if i turn a little too left or right, I feel like I'm gonna crash.
Weapon mechanics - aiming is kind of weird, the fact that you have to shoot multiple times in the body (except the head) sounds ridiculous to me.
Ambushes - the idea is interesting but I don't like the fact that it happens way too often, based on the ingame country population.

Overall this game is worth all my 10 bucks and I give it a solid 8/10.

Hello Comrade, you have been lucky enough to be assigned to a border crossing post. Serve and defend the motherland!

Comparison with "Papers Please":
 
 It does need to be said, this game and PP does share a very similar setting and job. Inspecting paperwork, looking for contraband, and allowing in those that pass the requirements. I will try not to state how I feel about each difference as opinionated answers may not reflect each individuals wants.

Time: In PP, each day lasted a specific amount of time which forced the player to accurately and quickly determine the validity of each entry. In CBP, I do not believe that there is a time limit, with more focus upon smaller details. As the world is 3D, and having to document errors with each vehicle a time limit may or may not frustrate players. 

Game Play Loop: In PP, the game play loop was go to work, perform duties, start the next day with small cut scenes that would occur at set times. In CBP there are additional activities that will spring up such as story missions, immediate alternate missions, base invasions, and free roam to explore the area under the government's control. Money also feels different in both games. In PP, money was generally a hard consumable to obtain on first play through and that is the lifeline between your families life or not. In CBP, as long as you are adequate at your job money will not be an object, with additional ways to earn money. Due to having money not being a true driving force, I just bought everything relatively quickly.   

Story: Although the story is certainly serviceable, and allows the player a branching system to stay true to the government or work with a rebel force to overthrow it, PP does it in a much more streamlined fashion. The rebels in CBP seem just rather inept, potentially because every couple of nights as you defend the base your team will kill dozens of them without a casualty. 

Music: Music was nice. Some of the music cues while working were rather relaxing. 

Graphics: I had no issues running above 60 fps. 

The bad: The main complaint I have is near the end of the game. The idea of this style of game is to start rather simple, and expand the demands of the player. At the beginning, you are asked to verify names, passport numbers, and expiration dates are valid. The end is demands much more, but without a time limit this really did not bother me. What did bother me was when forgeries become a possibility, and I could not get a good example of comparing the paper that was forged vs an authentic one. The only solution is to use the games compare system, where you click the item in question and compare it to what is in the book. No other time was this a requirement for any other system.

Side complaint is interaction with the other characters. You will not find a Jorji here, you will not get a compelling story of reuniting lovers and trying to save the guards life so his wife does not immediately become a widow. You get put in some situations where people will plead about there circumstances, but the writing does not make me care about pointing out their documentation flaws and sending them back into the wild. 

Side complaint two. At times your base will be attacked by a waves and waves of rebels. After the first one, this becomes a chore to content with as no matter how quickly and efficiently you kill enemies, it is timed for up to four minutes. There are multiple ways to exploit this mechanic, and as much as I think the developers wanted to capture the players attention it really just got boring. It is weird to say the game where you make sure Bob is in fact Bob and he can enter your country offers a massive shooting section, but it is just boring to me. 

Final: A play through with one path was around 11 hours. Is it good? Yeah, I think it is. 7/10.

This was a very entertaining game to play. If you've ever played "Papers, Please," you will love this game that takes that concept to another level. There are some rough spots here and there, but patches are already coming out not long after release, and the developers are evidently working on a "free mode" to play. Until free mode happens, the story mode is fun, but leaves you wanting for more high stakes inspections!

On top of free mode, some other future enhancements I'd like to see would be more base upgrades, and cosmetic improvement opportunities. It would be awesome if at the highest level, the border checkpoint was a reinforced concrete monolith with multiple guards, towers, spot lights, k-9's, etc. This could allow for enemy upgrades as well, such as having to deal with multiple passengers, who might wait before you begin searching for and/or finding contraband to try running or attacking you. Another enemy enhancement could be booby traps, or bombs (ala the k-9's as a way to stay one step ahead). Granted, I know that it took multiple years worth of effort to produce what they have so far. But free mode, with the above additions would be so fun, and so replayable. But even as is, this game is well worth it!

This game offers a thrilling experience for its price point. It provides a range of exciting challenges that keep players engaged throughout. The game is easily accessible to players and offers plenty of content to keep them coming back for more.

One of the game's features is the car damage recording mechanic. While it is an interesting concept, it can be quite boring, and some types of damage may not be immediately obvious to players, such as broken windows. This can be frustrating for players who want to fully immerse themselves in the game.

The game has five types of weapons, but players may find that only the SMG is necessary to complete the game. This can make the other weapons feel unnecessary and underutilized.

The property and employee upgrade mechanics in the game offer a way for players to customize their experience, but they are not necessary to finish the game. Some players may choose to focus solely on the core gameplay and ignore these upgrade mechanics entirely.

A surprisingly well made game and at a fair price. It is just as others say: Papers Please but 3D. The biggest difference being Contraband Police has a small open world that has you drive around to deliver all the criminals and contraband you’ve captured, plus they encourage exploration by having hidden collectibles which gives you a fair amount of money

Just like Papers Please, Contraband Police has a story where you choose the fate of entrants, but the ending seems mostly affected by accepting calls for missions and regular police work, and the choices you make at the end of those missions.

The main gameplay adds something to what Papers Please offers: vehicle inspections. Besides document checks (which I personally think Papers Please did a bit better), you also check cargo and vehicle condition and if a smuggler is suspected, you can tear their vehicle apart with your melee weapons to find contraband and make an arrest. Your inspections are evaluated by every single detail of the entrant and vehicle, even if they are supposed to be denied of entry

Another big part of the game is shooting and driving mechanics. Papers Please had limited shooting, but Contraband Police introduces ambushes and shootouts, which you can fend off with a variety of weapons. Sometimes an entrant may smash through the gates which then enters a chase sequence. You can even drive their vehicle once you arrest them!

As for money management, Papers Please has a limited amount of things you spend money on, but in Contraband Police, you can spend your earnings to upgrade the border post, vehicles, hire guards, and buying weapons from the tool shop. Melee durability is kind of pathetic though, even if you have the most expensive tool. But if you make perfect inspection and participate in outside missions, money won’t be an issue

If you loved Papers Please, definitely give Contraband Police a try!
