** Edited review.

Fantastic game. It's everything it claims to be, it's a simulator game where you work as a captain at a border post in a 1981 Communist country. It has choices to side between factions (the people vs government) but ultimately is just a very fun, day by day Border patrol simulator. The game also has way better gunplay than it needs. It surprises me how fun the shooting is in a game that would be fun with no combat at all. The meat and potatoes of the game comes down to the vehicle inspections. Building up your post, upgrading your team and their equipment, and finding drugs or weapons by cutting open a car seat is consistently fun and engaging. Additionally there is a storyline going on, random events like gangs ambushing your base or a car driving right through with no inspection, and random in the village policing scenarios. I made an initial review very frustrated by a mechanic... the developer responded immediately and has worked on it. Even with this issue it was still fantastic, the developer response, and immediate fix to an already great game... Buy this. You'll like it, and they deserve it.

OK. I've been waiting for this one for a long time. As die-hard fan of Pope's masterpiece Papers Please, after playing the demo of Contraband Police it got into my wishlist quickly. When I saw the release was pushed I started to question if it would be good but as it came out the 8th I bought it directly and started to play and didn't want to write something about it without finishing one playthrough.

This game is amazing! Papers Please already set the tone for this kind of sim games but Contraband takes it a step further and brings some action in it. Yes the driving isn't the best around. Aren't there things to better like the economy or the difficulty level? Yes there are. But I am sure this legendary small team will fix and add the necessary things, some of which they are already planning for, as soon as possible, and make this to an even shinier 20€ gem.

I absolutely love this game. I replayed papers please right before buying this, to see if it would hold a candle to it, and I have to say, it's a near perfect spiritual sequel. It does have some annoying problems, but the pros outweigh the cons ten times over.

You run a checkpoint, much like in papers please, but you get a ton more interactivity. Finding contraband in PP is a pretty quick and easy process, but figuring out someone is smuggling alcohol inside their seats and then getting to tear them out with your knife is SO satisfying. I absolutely love the core gameplay.

I'll talk about the few cons I have, because the developers seem pretty receptive to feedback, and because I think they're worth mentioning, but keep in mind that although I might sound harsh, my list of pros is "pretty much everything else"

The cons:
There are collectibles, which give a decent amount of money, so they're great to find, especially early on. There are some that are common sense to find, funny ones, like the one hidden in the bathroom right next to your house, and then ones that are absolutely impossible to find without a guide. Driving can be really slow, especially in the beginning (when you'd be looking for the collectibles), and these files and buried chest can be in absolutely random spots that the game will never take you near without you exploring there for yourself. If you'd like to randomly scour across an almost completely empty open world, be my guest, but otherwise I'd ignore them or use a guide. Some off these hiding spots are actually f*cked and I NEVER would have found them in a million years.

The clunky driving from Thief Simulator is back, and it is in rare form. This can be annoying in its own way while you get used to it, (or re-get used to it if you love Thief Simulator like I do), but there are two major problems

1. There are car chases. The way the trees and roads are designed, it is absolutely impossible to offroad and try to cut someone off, so you're stuck driving behind them and slowly gaining on them unless you invest thousands of dollars into buying and upgrading the fast car.

2. You can put a siren on, which is great and convenient because most people will get out of your way, except for the walking people in the police station who have absolutely no issue with walking right in front of your car. You really never drive without the siren on, it's just so useful. Except some drivers bug out and seem magnetically attracted to your car. I swear, some of these drivers are paid off by the rebels, they seem legitimately out for your blood. If you get caught in a random encounter, bullets do a ton of damage to your car, so any car crash can be fatal. I remember one time, I was very far from the checkpoint, and some guy tboned me, kept going, and pushed me directly into a tree. My car exploded, killing him and stranding me all the way across the map. I'm now out $250 for the car, $500 for a "fatal accident" and have to either spend the next 5-10 minutes holding shift and w, or reload a save and start the WHOLE day over. It really sucked.

However, if you can deal with that and minor bugs, like things phasing into each other, and the car radio audio doubling and turning into a very unpleasant listening experience, this is a wonderful game with a lot to love in it. I can definitely see myself putting 100 hours into it. It's genuinely so much fun.

Surprisingly, the gun fights, although pretty simplistic, is pretty satisfying! (Hot tip, upgrade your house early on, it upgrades your max health, which is a must have). In Papers Please, there was a beauty in its simplicity, but in Contraband Police, there is so much more depth that I found really rewarding and enjoyable.

In my opinion, a must buy for anyone who enjoyed Papers Please. 8/10
IT IS GOOD, AND FRESH!! 11 hours in 1 play, replay value, HIGH. it is a bargain.

This is THE GAME I was waiting for after finishing Papers, please!
I have not find anything I would describe as cons, so here are just few mehs:
- it is produced by PlayWay so expect it to look like a PlayWay game
- the driving and shooting is kind of a wierd but it works just fine
- the border station management is basic but satisfying

Now the pros:
- the border control part of the game is just GREAT. There is everything you know from Papers, please! and more. It is not just about checking the paperwork. You have to keep on mind event restrictions. For example, there are Olympic games and cars with more than 3 defects cannot enter the country. Every 5 or so days there is a new event. You are also given few clues about smugglers. Some of the contrabanf is hidden really well.
- there is a decent story with two possible endings. I have not finished the game yet but I will definetly play it again for second ending.

Conclusion: RECOMMENDED

Pros:
-Game is fun, the inspection sequences are not that challenging if you pay attention but don't get too cocky 'cause you might miss some details.
-The idea of the story overall is thought out nicely.  
-The city is nice and beautiful
-The information board is a good idea!

Cons:
-Enemies bodies and death animations look like they come from a Android game.
-Guns are the same
-Driving is slow and unsafe between the country roads
-When you wanna get out of a car during third person view you have to change it to first person just to do it. 
-The guy helping you with the cleaning and getting back the merchandise that you got to inspect turns around everytime you talk to him and requires a fade to black to make it work. Wish it could be fluid and you would see him clean up the place.
-The map always get in the middle of the screen when you're driving. Just make a minimap please.

I just completed this game. Not gonna lie, it's really good. The creativity they've put in, it's not just about being a border cop. I like how the developers mixed and balanced two different things at the same time. Since it's an early-release, the game has certain bugs. For instance, even after using the in-built tool for checking certain documents, in the end the audit report would mark the investigation as incorrect. The driving physics are crazy. I felt like a slav driving a Lada and drifting all the way through some thick forests without drinking any vodka. Apart from this, if there were more customization options and a bigger map size, the game would've been more interesting and engaging. Nevertheless, I'd definitely recommend to play this once. It'll take around 20-25 hours or maybe less, depending on your progress and gameplay.

Worth it on sale, super fun for the first 20 in game days after that you've pretty much unlocked everything and gets super repetitive almost like a chore. The side missions are good and keeps you engaged. The driving is also pretty good in a nice curvy road map.

Game is fun and definitely worth maybe more than the price they're selling at. Its easy to start overlooking small things in the late game, and worth being meticulous about your checklist. There seems to be multiple endings, I did all I could for Mother Acaristan on my first go around.

There's only 2 downsides to this game. The first, is there is no variation to the day. An example: The first car that approaches is good, has everything is a perfect entrant. Second car, whoops, turns out his papers were garbage and you messed up and sent him through. You restart the day, The two cars you did are exactly the same. It makes it easier the second time you mess up.

The second isnt really a downside, more of a hopes and dreams thing. But this game would be super mega freakin' awesomer if it had a Infinite mode. I love the gameplay at the border crossing and I feel that a mode where you did just that, ad inifitum, would be awesome. Randomized crossings, no attacks, 1/100 (or less) chance of a guy just breaking through the gates and needing pursuit. Devs, hook a brother up, please.

Get's quickly boring, not worth that amount of money.

This game is definitely worth the money and the Dev should be proud of themselves.

This game really surprised me. I was expecting to patrol the boarder, stop contraband from entering, turning away people that don't meet the requirements and maybe get into a firefight if a traveller didn't like the outcome of their attempt at crossing the boarder. But I was heavily mistaken; There is so much more to this game than meets the eye. Open world, Resource manager, being a detective of sorts, a story with choice & good conflict, and the list continues. 
  
  My only gripes is that sometimes there will be contraband in the engine bay, however there isn't actually an there. Just a bug i'm sure. Another is the abundance of ambushes; Its very obnoxious repairing your vehicle only for it to be shot up about 30 seconds after leaving the boarder camp. If they were tuned down a little to be more rare, but made a little more difficult with more risk/reward. Would make them feel exhilarating & refreshing.  
  Overall I REALLY enjoy this game, I 100% recommend giving it a try.
 
 [UPDATE] I have now finished the game, and would like to update this review;
  My previous feelings and thoughts still stands however, upon finishing the game I was sadden to see the lack of any continuation or endless mode for the game. After you finish the final mission your whole save gets nuked. No way to continue playing on the save, no new mode unlocked, etc. I hope this is a feature coming in the future just because how great this game plays even without the story missions. You could still work the boarder, encounter ambushes of fellow gang members trying to break their comrades out of prison, do intervention missions, etc. 
 Still a great game, and I look forward to doing more playthroughs to chose the other choices.

This game is a noteworthy successor to Papers Please. The mechanics are interesting and add a lot of variety into the gameplay. You aren't just sitting at the border all day checking documents and can engage in other activities which helps prevent burnout. The shootouts/ambush randomness are a nice break from the routine. I feel like the game has a lot of potential in terms of future development. Adding more ranks which can be grinded would promote longer playtime (ex staff/chief inspector), endless/inspector mode which ik is in the works, being able to have one of your border guards accompany you when you leave the outpost as an escort. Lots of potential. 

Some issues I had with the game: When I try to slash tires, it always hits the top part of the car unless I'm positioned a certain way, hard to find ALL contraband esp if its in obscure places, and story felt disconnected from the main gameplay. My choices in story missions don't seem to affect the gameplay. Like if I join the rebellion, maybe they would send me messages to let a certain person through or kill someone etc. 

Overall great game! Looking forward to future updates.

Additional info in response to the developer request.

1. Dialogues
First thing that starts to irritate a player right from the start is a decision to use fictional language voice audio for dialogues. While it could be (and possibly was planned as) an atmospheric feature it is implemented very poorly and without regard to gameplay. Here's why.
It requires a player to listen for the familiar words and at the same time he has to read a subtitle. While playing a game in a real time. Dialogues do not pause the game. It distracts a player and requires him to make himself concentrate on audio AND text at the same time. There are no controls for dialogue (i.e. click to continue, logs). So basically paying attention to dialogues wastes your precious time you could spend on some other game activity. It is obviously a bad design because you even had to stop the time (disable this game mechanic) for the detective mission.
There are no textbox background which makes text hard to read over a motley game background.

2. Graphics
It looks cheap. It's the second thing that irritates a player. I think it's because it is very very motley. There is a lot of high contrast in very small and insignificant (gamewise) details. Textures are way too motley, so you can barely recognize an object outline. It is a strain for an eye. Color coding and highlighting is just useless in such a mess of art spray. And it looks cheap and outdated. Overall visual design is subpar.

3. Art
Third thing which is very irritating. The place looks like a dump. There is absolutely no art style designed to characterize the game. It looks like an asset flip. There are no flags, no streamers and no posters which are designed in a single decoration style. There is no visual flavor in any object. Everything is a simple generic asset with no style.

4. Document checking gameplay
I have to admit that document checking UI is well designed. I liked it. Yet document checking gameplay has flaws. First is an awareness meter. It's just useless. It doesn't help at all. It reuires you to click datafields which you have to compare. So basically it still requires a player to look for a field in the UI. While a player looking for a proper field to click he's perfectly able to compare data himself. So basically auto-check does nothing. The only exception is an age calculation.
In addition awareness meter is not used at all in cargo checking, vehicle condition checking.
There is no progress or development in this mechanic while the difficulty and variety of checks increases with progress. It is a design flaw. The mini-game becomes harder and more time consuming without any mechanics introduced to spare the player of repeating any of lots of monotonous actions.
For me the game became unbearable on vehicle condition checks introduced. 

5. Time
It is a bad design decision to implement a real time mechanics in the game. The game is about monotonous and tedious every day work of a border customs officer. Limiting a time by introducing a real time breaks the idea (IMO) and imposes a needless strain on a player to rush him to do the constantly increasing number of checks. If you will add here the need to deliver prisoners and contraband and buying/selling tools and goods, and managing a base, and defending a base - it's just too much for a tranquil chores of a customs officer.

6. Too many variations in the gameplay
It is really a bit too much. You had to concentrate your development on base gameplay cycle and perfect it rather than implement lots of badly designed gameplay variations which ruin the main gameplay.
For example attacks on a base should be only at night. It shouldn't interfere with main gameplay. Minigames of driving aroung shouldn't waste time.
Ambushes are really very badly designed minigame. Me as a player I just do not understand what do you expect me to do? Stop in the middle of the narrow road (all roads are narrow) and do what? Hide behing my own truck? And all I got is $70 and free ammo (if i'm fast enough too loot disappearing corpses)? What is the point of introducing such mechanics? Why wast resources on this?
Stalking mechanic is just stupid. The difference between target suspecting a pursuit and losing a target is just a couple of meters.
Detective mechanics look artificial and alien (why customs officer conducts a detective work?) and implemented badly and very cheap.
All these mini-games just dillute a fun of a main gameplay with unwanted and unpleasant actions.

7. Level design
The map (level) is awful. Long narrow roads. No minimap. Opening a map doesn't pause the game. There is no fun or challenge in travercing the map in your vehicle. It's just a tedious time consuming activity.

8. Controls.
Why I can stop engine by pressing G but can't start it by pressing G?

It's a First-Person Papers, Please mixed with some janky driving and shooting.
A full playthrough with some side exploration took me ~9 hours. 

Let's start with the positives:
- the inspection parts are done well, mechanically they work and rules occasionally get mixed up
- the upgrading aspect of your border outpost is done well, you can upgrade several parts of the outpost which I enjoyed.
- the shooting itself works reasonably well
- performance was good, barely encountered bugs or fps drops.

Now for the negatives:
- even at current patch, ambushes are far too frequent and far too pointless. It just spawns 4-5 enemies that have some ammo as loot and that's it. I encountered 1-3 ambushes on every trip and loathed each one. Completely pointless.
- money was too easy to acquire, I never had issues with money and upgraded everything fairly quickly
- the characters are literally copy-pasted, I can't remember a single one. Unlike Papers 
Please which had very memorable characters in here they are bland copies of each other. I got several letters where someone complained that their wife/daughter/mother/job died and I had zero clue who they even were. Bad boring characters don't make lasting impressions.
- the story also falls kinda flat, in big parts because of the above mentioned lack of characters. You can choose to do your job correctly (siding with the government) or joining the Rebels, which is essentially just a group of violent criminals. Didn't care for that aspect whatsoever.

Overall, I had fun but also loathed other parts. It's a 6/10 that's worth a look if you enjoyed the document controlling gameplay of Papers, Please.

I love that the developers are actually listening to feedback and improving the game and happy they'll add a endless mode.

Contraband Police was a very pleasant surprise. I think most of us expected a quaint "euro-jank" sim along the lines of Hobo Simulator or My Summer Car, but this game surprised me in many ways. 

First of all, the production quality is really good for such a small indie game. The looks, the graphics, the sound/music - while obviously not triple-A quality - are all quite good. The gameplay is interesting and engaging, both the "Papers, Please" style document and vehicle inspection part, the gunplay and even the story and side missions. While it's not Witcher 3, but everything is well written and the voice acting is great.

However, what totally sold me about the game was the style. The 80's Eastern Bloc feel brought back vivid memories of my own childhood, growing up in barely-post-soviet Hungary, I've seen these cars and trucks (even driven/owned some of them), the architecture, the government propaganda, I drove through such border checkpoints, handing over your passport with mandatory bribe money folded inside (even if you didn't have anything illegal) so they don't take your car apart just for fun. Heard all the stories back in the day about the weird ways people were trying to smuggle stuff back home from "The West", cigarettes, booze, cassettes, VHS tapes, kitchen appliances, jeans and clothes, etc. The border guards, the police, everyone knew people were doing it, yet also everyone coveted the shiny new western stuff, so blind eyes were turned in return for a few "gifts" left at the crossing, the cost of doing business. It was a "live and let live" type of deal.

Contraband Police captures this era of Eastern Bloc weirdness very well, just like "Papers, Please" did, albeit not as depressing. While "Papers, Please" showed the bleak, hopeless, harsh realities of trying to survive under such oppressive regime, Contraband Police is a lot less heavy-handed and brings some much needed levity and fun into the mix, not to mention a complete story with actual characters and multiple endings based on your choices.

While the game is obviously not without faults, some bugs, glitches, imbalance and missing features, the devs seem to be actively working on fixes and additions (like the Endless Mode a lot of people have been requesting) so there seems to be some mileage in this game yet.

In closing, Contraband Police is a very nice surprise. Instead of the run of the mill "eurojank" we got a very well made, fun and engaging sim that brings a huge load of nostalgia for those who lived these times and quaint enough to entertain those who didn't. Well done!

Thanks for reading!

Okay, so I've spent a little over 3 hours on the game and I want to help you now, is it worth it for you to buy it?!

I'll start with the worst problem, which I hope will be solved with a bugfix:
Falseflag..
It happened 3 times in my almost 4 hours of playing that I scanned everything thoroughly, but still the scan was not perfect. For example a broken lamp that wasn't broken.

Poor humor:
There were so many things I wanted to do in this game that I shouldn't do in "Real Life", like accepting a bribe from a smuggler, but then I'd just as soon arrest him, which the game doesn't give me the chance to do.
Or just wrecking the other guy's car for disrespecting me and not being able to let him in. Or just killing people in different ways, which not only can't be done, but also gets a $500 deduction. You also can't take weapons away from attackers,very little money making opportunities in the game. Why shouldn't I be able to sneak the drugs to someone else, rather than deliver them to the police for a small amount of money?! And similar questions came to me while I was playing. After the 3rd hour, it got pretty monotonous.

Is this game worth it?
For this price it's definitely NOT, maybe if there is a -50% for it, it will be worth buying.
I would also point out the poor sound quality,which is repetitive silly NPC voices,(from everyone in particular)... Now this can strongly discourage you from playing the game.
Why no more conversation options? Why can't you ask back?! Anyway, I'll play the game for a few more hours, because I didn't buy it for decoration, but I don't think my opinion will change.

[h1] Dear Developer, [/h1]
   I first played the prologue to this game quite a while ago. I enjoyed it quite a bit, so when the full game was released I couldn't help but buy it within the first 2-3 days. And, I saw you were streaming it quite a lot. I never actually watched any of the streams, but I saw you ([i]or one of you[/i]) with your hat and I thought it was so wholesome! I played it whenever I could for about 3-4 days before I was able to complete the game, playing for 19 hrs. I have suggestions and criticisms!

[h1] Bug Fixes [/h1]

1. The Micros 260 has what I'd guess to either be a decal or texture issue. On the rear of the vehicle, the driver's side light is correctly shown as red, whereas the passenger-side light is white. I wasn't sure if this qualified as a "broken light" the first time I noticed it.

2. When raiders attacked the checkpoint, the last raider must've glitched underneath the map because my team would continuously shoot at a spot, and I was never able to locate the last raider. I had to quit and load back in, which didn't hurt much because it was right before the raid began. I had no issues with the re-do of the raid.

[h1] Suggestions & Criticisms [/h1]
[b][i]Spoiler Alert[/i][/b]
[i]Also, apologies as I may be going too in-depth, but I hope it helps![/i]

[b] World-Building [/b]
[b][i]Spoiler Alert[/i][/b]
[i]Also, apologies as I may be going too in-depth, but I hope it helps![/i]

   When you find the police traitor's hideout, he tries to convince you to join the rebellion. He says that the political opposition leader was poisoned by the Gov't, and that the state tries to put down anyone fighting for, I believe, "[i]democracy[/i]" and "[i]freedom[/i]". We're just kind of forced to take this at face value, because there is nothing leading up to the event that would make me believe that this state is necessarily any more tyrannical than any other. We're just kinda forced to accept the incorrect or disingenuous notion that Communism is always, inherently dictatorial ([i]Marxist-Leninist vs Stalinist, etc.[/i]). Noting that those buzzwords have been historically used to slander nations as authoritarian, citing "[i]free speech[/i]" when what they mean is corporate-sponsored speech, and lack of "[i]economic freedom[/i]" when a planned economy is required to ensure everyone is fed.

   When considering joining the [i]Blood Fist Revolt[/i], the world building didn't really fill much in for me. So, I resorted to my knowledge of historical rebellions in Communist or Socialist countries. They were usually a minority, funded or lead by ousted bourgeois, and principally funded by foreign Capitalist powers out of their own economic interests, disregarding whatever was best for the people. Presuming this was true, and considering the aforementioned buzzwords, the rebellion would've probably been fighting for a [i]Liberal Democracy[/i]. Which is concerning for me because the end-result of a Liberal Democracy can very easily be Fascism, which would most certainly be a far worse evil than whatever is alleged of Communist Acaristan. But, I would've still chosen the rebellion if the majority of people wanted this to be so. So, I listened to the civilians that passed my gate. All of the Acaristani people passing the gate had nothing intentionally ill to say of the Gov't, except on occasion such as when the government got rid of artists, teachers, and journalists ([i]which I would say is tyrannical[/i]). Rather, I would often hear Acaristani newcomers speak positively of the state, once even hearing about how the new restrictions kept him employed. This doesn't feel like a conscious world-building choice, and I feel a small handful of lore leading up to finding the traitor could've better informed the decision!

[b] Free Play After Completion[/b]

   It feels kinda sad to have invested that time with updating my officers, facilities, vehicles, and just not being able to play anymore afterwards without starting a new game. Each newcomer felt intentional, so I presume you must've crafted every encounter. But, if you could only make a randomizer script of some sort, you could very easily allow for continuous play post-credits! I would definitely want to play the game more post-credits, and was sad to find out that I would have to start all over.

Let me say it a bit louder...

[h1]Please allow free-play post-credits![/h1]

I have to say this game is surprisingly good, i can tell the company was working with limited resources but they did their absolute best with what they had and it's a very playable, fun, and entertaining game. It also has replay-ability to a degree between the two factions in game. I fully recommend this if you liked "Papers, please"(Which funny enough, i did not), but the games are very similar to a degree. 

I enjoyed hunting down contraband and the little story missions you get along the way are serviceable. 

I would absolutely love to see a sequel one day, and in that i'd love them to improve upon the world setting. You absolutely get the feeling of being in a place like poland or a soviet bloc country in the 80s, but there is no dialogue from any of the people you work and fight alongside and i think it would be very enjoyable to have cut scenes and dialogue when you promote one of your men and conversations between them giving them responsibilities would be welcomed. (Seargent Maksimox should move the prisoners to the labor camp every other day for example)

Overall, i would give this game a sold 7.9 out of 10. It's a great game, if you see it on sale you'd be dumb not to pick it up and give it a chance. The game play does get a little repetitive but it's a fun experience and i recommend it fully.

It is quite rare to see a polished, non-early access game these days. Imagine my surprise when I found this gem. Think of Papers Please, but with a far more hands on approach, you need to check seat linings, unpack and inspect cargo among others, all the while (obviously) ensuring all the paperwork is in order. There are also some FPS elements, the amount of which surprised me, a good deal more than I anticipated, which I enjoyed. The game is crammed full of content, and the primary issue that I had (the somewhat too-frequent ambushes) has already been addressed and resolved by the developer(s). A bloody good game, and well worth a buy. Glory to Acaristan.

Insanely well-made game for an indie project. If you enjoyed Papers please it is simply a must-play. Gameplay is good in all aspects. Inspections are very similar to Papers please, but adding "physical" interaction with people their cars, and goods really pushed it to another level. But what surprised me the most, are mechanics completely unrelated to the inspection process. When I saw gameplay screenshots I expected clunky shooting and car driving. But the truth is, they are both really well made. Shooting is quite fun and has a nice feel to it. When driving the car you really feel its "weight". Hell, you even feel the difference between RWD and AWD cars. On top of all previously said, the game also offers a good enough story with some degree of player choices that impact how the whole thing plays out. 
Of course, this game is not without issues. Typical performance issues, and some minor bugs but nothing game-breaking really. Yes, some animations are very simple and feel unrealistic, and the graphics also are not top-notch. But in this time and age when 90% of all games are some AAA nonsense, this is the real diamond in the rough. 
Straight 10/10.

Excellent indie game, in a sea of bad, slapped together "simulators" This one is worth every penny. You play as a border agent, checking documents, busting smugglers and defending your post. Its like Papers, Please in 3D.

When I saw the demo of this game I thought it was going to be like Papers Please, but in the style of a simulator game. I loved Papers Please, so I was excited to see a 3D version of that. Turns out that this game is way bigger than I ever would have expected. 

The map is surprisingly large, and the story missions are a nice break from the repetitive nature of border entry inspections. While the missions aren't very long or in-depth, they are something that I didn't really expect to be part of the game and are a nice touch.

Full disclosure, I have not yet completed the story or finished the game. So my opinion may well change. However, I can say that the portion of the game I've played feels pretty well polished. I have not yet experienced a bug that prevented me from proceeding with the level, or caused any game crashes. You can't take that sort of thing for granted anymore, especially for a newly released game.

Contraband Police is the game where you get to be a corrupt cop without any real-life consequences! You play as a border patrol officer who confiscates illegal goods and pockets them for yourself. It's like playing Robin Hood, but instead of giving to the poor, you're giving to yourself.

The graphics are intentionally retro, adding to the charm of this hilarious and satirical game. The cheesy dialogue will have you chuckling as you work your way through each level, trying to avoid getting caught by the real cops.

Overall, Contraband Police is a fun and addictive game that lets you indulge in your inner criminal. Just don't let the power of corruption go to your head! 6\10

Don't write reviews but for this game I will! Found it on the Steam Recommended Games and was interested in it immediately. I feel like its hard to talk about this game without comparing it to Papers, Please. If you loved Papers Please and the type of  analysis of specific items you're gonna love this game. It's really fun in the sense that you aren't just stating at an outpost all day, you're given full access to the full map and allowed to wander around once the day is complete. The game is amazingly well detailed and has an interesting story in the game that makes you wanna continue. My favorite part I found while playing was the base upgrades, it gave you an incentive to keep wanting to get more money for making sure that you and your border guards have the equipment necessary to fight in raids. 

However there is a main downside I found with the game, it was with the Blood Fist. They're an interesting faction and seem cool, but I found no real reason to join their side not unless you don't want the government to succeed. I feel in Papers, Please they gave you a reason to support the rebels in that you had a family to support and you really felt the cruelty of the government. In this game? Not so much, I felt no reason to join them. But hey, I'll probably do another play through and see if its worth it.

I liked the 3d take on 'papers please', and the action sequences (while janky) are fun. I like searching the nooks and crannies of a vehicle for contraband, and I seemingly missed 10 - 20% most of the time. I like the base management system input, where you can upgrade buildings personnel and hire new guards. The driving sections are less fun, and it has the worst tailing mission i have seen in a game (The difference between too close and losing your target is like 8 steps)

Unlike papers please, it does not really require any thought or attention to detail, nor is time management any concern. Look for typos, remember to check the license plates that the KGB knows are smugglers, and then use your UV lamp to check for the super secret contraband mark all criminals keep on their hidden compartments. But ok, a more easy laid-back approach is not necessarily a bad thing -- some folks like that, and papers please could be overbearingly stressful. 

The real killer to me is that the story elements are unearned, and the easy difficulty is the main driver of that. In papers please, the difficulty reinforced the evil nature of the totalitarian government. If you don't work hard enough, your family might die. This causes you to participate in the evil -- doing the right thing and letting someone across the border despite a minor typo in their documents to avoid being murdered at home is a *lot* harder decision to make when that good deed could mean your family goes hungry. 

In this game, I was rolling in dough and buying upgrades because, well, why not? A few of the civilians meekly asked to be let across the border -- you know, because it would be a nice thing to do, not because of any real reason. I always finished the arrival queue with plenty of daylight to spare, which mean I was making the big bucks and could buy anything i really needed. I never got the opportunity, but i assume you could possibly sell contraband to the black market for a higher risk/reward, but the economy of the game is so permissive i don't know why you would want to (other than RP i suppose). 

Then out of nowhere, some guy asks me to join the rebellion against the evil government. Why? I've been on the job for less than a week and I've already upgraded my house twice. Life's pretty good -- think i'm sticking with big brother, thank you very much, and not because I want to see what the 'bad' ending looks like.

Fantastic game, worth the money!

Graphics - Good, not super-fancy, but more than enough to allow you to get immersed in the game.

Audio - Good

Music - Good, but a little repetitive, not too many tracks.  Competent music, but nothing that will win an award.

Gameplay- WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER.  The gameplay will suck you in.

Value and Replayability - My goal when buying a game is to get a minimum of an hour for every dollar spent.  This game delivers at the price I purchased it at.  In my first run-through of the game it took me about 25-30 hours of play time.  When I finished my first run-through I immediately started my second run-through.  I anticipate that I'll stop playing when the second run-through is complete.  This will be the type of game that you'll dust off every 12-18 months and do a run-through.  It's not a game like Factorio or Minecraft where you'll put thousands of hours in.

(Light spoilers below)

The GOOD:  Checking people's documents is fun and the process slowly gets more complicated and morphs as the game progresses.  The core game mechanic doesn't get easy, doesn't get old, allows you to mess up a little bit without being too severely punished, and rewards attention to detail and immersion.

Other than document\contraband checking, there are two other major mechanics; driving and shooting.  This game isn't as competent at driving and shooting as the game "Mafia" is, but it's still good enough.  Driving and shooting missions help break up the core document/contraband mechanic.  I never found myself bored during my first play through.

You can also upgrade/purchase/hire as the game progresses.  This helps make the game rewarding and allows you to more efficiently do grind-tasks or to avoid them all together.

Also, the story is fun too.  I had a hard time following it completely, as a lot of the Russian names just started to blur together in my head, but perhaps I'll catch more on my second time through.

The BAD - The driving mechanic is good enough, but it is the weakest point of the game.  The good news is my car never really got stuck.  The bad news is that driving just seems a little bit off.  The other frustrating part of the game was the "ambush" events.  The developers are addressing this.  Basically the ambushes happen WAY TOO FREQUENTLY and don't offer enough reward.

Ambushes:

For those of you that are worried about the "ambush" issue, don't.  I had about a 90% success rate just driving right through them.  That's right, just ignore them and keep driving.  You'll take insignificant damage in most cases and continue on.  Don't attempt to take on the ambushes until you have better weapons and more experience using them.

Developers, if you're listening, this is how I would fix ambushes:
1)  Limit Ambushes to 1 per day
2)  Let players know (perhaps in the tutorial) that they can flee if they're not prepared
3)  The $70 reward for winning the ambush is too small.  Increase the reward to something like $500
4)  Make it possible to reduce the chance of an ambush by turning off sirens or taking certain routes, train the player how to avoid them/lessen their chances.

Also to the Devs:  Bravo, well done.  This game is fun, surprising, addictive, suspenseful, and does a good job at a variety of gameplay mechanics.  You've created joy in this world.

I really wanted to like this game, but the vehicle issues make me loathe certain aspects. So as most have already stated, a few bullets can make your car explode.. so you have to restart the day, and more than likely you will be driving at the end of the day to transport prisoners and contraband.
That isn't the worst part though, the worst part is the "Stop the intruder" stuff. So... you have a vehicle that is almost exactly the same speed at the guy who ran your gate right?
So you have to cut every corner without messing up to FINALLY catch up to the runner. Well you also need to remember that the runner goes through your gate at full speed and you still have to get into your vehicle, turn it on, and then chase him, so he has a pretty good head start. 
If you hit any trees, or anything really, you will easily lose 1 minute of your time catching up. I have slammed the runners car into trees/mountains/etc, and I didn't get out quick enough - he would just keep going and I would have to get back into my vehicle to continue the chase of two cars with the same speed. :( Sometimes I can get lucky and end it soon, like the first runner. I just got 2 of them today and I shit you not, 15-20 minutes to complete the damn runner and arrest him.
Oh, and you can't go through his vehicle for contraband because you have a timer now to get back to your post because people are waiting to come in. So then you get penalized for not finding all the contraband in the car... It's just, such a bad mechanic and really needs to get overhauled - easily the biggest disdain I have with the game.

Sometimes you will get missions randomly, I just did the graveyard mission. Few issues, not a huge fan of the enemy appearing out of thin air every time I start to dig in spots, just never been a huge fan of the magical enemies appearing from thin air.
Secondly, and more importantly, the game tells you to bring a shovel. You should probably bring a couple... maybe the dev can put a shovel in the van for this mission as well, OR have a few shovels laying around in the graveyard during this mission. If you are unlocky with your dig spots, you will break your shovel before you can beat it, if you leave hte area than you lose it. :(

Also, there are some annoying bugs, on the micros 260, you can't pop the tires, so all contraband in the tires you can't get to for your money and you are also penalized for it as well. :(

I would describe Contraband Police as being quite similar to Papers, Please. In both games, you work at a border crossing of a fictional eastern European country in the 1980s, and are tasked with deciding whether people enter or not based on the rules. In some ways this game is simpler than Papers, Please, but in most other ways, it is much more complex. In Papers, Please, the challenge came from trying to process people as quickly as possible without making mistakes in order to earn more money, with the challenge coming from more advanced paperwork as the game progressed, along with some moral dilemmas.

In Contraband Police, time isn't so much an issue, and instead the challenge comes from making sure your report for each entrant is as accurate as possible, making sure each individual document is accurate and if not, why it's not. You get paid more the more accurate your report is, and that money goes towards making your outpost better. And there are more systems than just checking the paperwork. There's searching for contraband, capturing fugitives, transporting prisoners and contraband, a black market system. There are also some first person shooting segments that handle decently, and can happen suddenly, which can keep you on your toes.

I do have some issues. For one, the labor camp where you deliver prisoners and the police headquarters where you deliver contraband are on opposite ends of the map, so driving to both can get a bit tedious at times. The shootouts are a bit easy too. I found that early on I was able to pull off headshots pretty easily with my pistol just popping out from behind a tree and lining up my sights. The enemies only become especially challenging if you encounter a lot of them and they all get real close to you. That or you're in a car and can't get out quickly enough before they shoot your car into a fireball. They can still kill you if you aren't paying attention in a scripted firefight so it's not totally mindless, but it could be better. When it comes to each inspection, the order of the vehicles and each one's specific problems aren't randomized like in Papers, Please, so there's no reason not to refresh the day if you feel like you've messed up, since you'll know what to expect. While the overall themes of the story are clear, no one character is given enough screen time or development to stand out or be memorable.

Still though, Contraband Police is a good time for those who like going over details and making sure everything is in order. The FPS segments could be improved but they're still fun to me. Running the outpost and watching it get better over time felt good. And I think aping Papers, Please really helped it in a way. I recommend giving it a chance if you feel like this kind of title would interest you. At least, play the demo first and decide if it's for you. I know I did.

This game is a wonderful reminder that there are still a lot of game devs out there that actually care about releasing a quality game. I had played this demo a while back which made this a must have for me when it released, and here we are. The game runs great.

The developers seems to be pretty active and has plans for the future of the game. And so far when they mention things are going to get fixed, they get fixed. Main issue I had (and many others feedback) was way too many ambushes on the road, so that got patched within a couple days of release. 

The game is exactly how it states on the store page. This feels like a much needed expansion to "Papers, Please", turning it into a 3D first person game with police chases, shoot outs, ambushes, and of course: Checking travelers papers before they can cross the border. You will also have to check cargo, taking out a paper to check how much of each cargo the driver has and then comparing it to the drivers manifest. You also need to do upkeep on your police station including hiring new officers to help out, expanding the jail (you will be arresting and transporting the bad guys), the warehouse (where all the contraband is stored until you take it to the police base), your residence and more. Lots of progression within the game.

This is a must have if you enjoy police simulators or games like "Papers, Please". I would have easily paid more than the asking price, and looking forward to future additions to this!

The game and all seems a bit unfinished, as expected with new games like these. Graphics wise, it's mediocre, could be better but it fits the game very well. AI passive/aggressive animations are great, guards exiting their posts to walk around for a bit, rushing to cover points when under attack, really nice touch. The gun system is okay, not very realistic, damage can be a bit more buffed, and the AI should play a bigger part in gunfights, right now they barely get a single kill, while you're fending off the checkpoint against 10-15 gang members.
Overall I'd say this game is a 6.5/10, it has a lot of potential and I enjoy it. I did not expect a whole checkpoint upgrading system, and it was a big surprise to me when I found out I had the ability to fortify my checkpoint with more guards, upgrade them, buy and upgrade vehicles. Expect multiple choice scenarios, and a semi-difficult border experience.

I love this game. I definitely recommend the game because aside from small glitches (I got stuck in the hood of a car when I closed it as I was apparently standing too close...) here and there this game is very enjoyable.

It's probably the best Papers Please type of the game now (except the original). Game is not in early access and looks quite polished (did not see any game breaking bugs yet). Performance wise also a solid title. Surprisingly this game reminds me of Xenus series, made by the developers of Stalker in 2000s. Check it out and you probably will get the same feeling about Contraband Police. 

Gameplay is engaging enough, mixing the documents stuff with occasional missions or firefights (which are rather easy). You can earn money by doing work, taking bribes etc.  Earned money are spent for upgrades. These upgrades feel not important and look like just an element for its own sake rather than balanced game mechanic. Still nice feature though. Also you have a basic story line which is surprising for such type of game. 

Gameplay features that would be nice to be added (or I have absolutely no idea that they are in the game):
1. ability to sell contraband items at better prices at fences
2. buying cosmetic items for your border point
3. More interactions with items and NPCs
4. Side-missions and random stuff besides ambushes

For its price it is a quite good indie-game that is not making you regret buying it after first hour.

Very similar play style to Papers, Please, yet it seems much more forgiving (time isn't as important of a factor in my opinion), there is more to do, and you can take your time and explore the map if you wish. The option to upgrade your officers and utilities is cool. Having a great time so far. Would recommend.

you don't necessarily go into playway sa titles expecting the highest quality, but this one holds up. sure, it looks like a mod for far cry 2, but the gameplay is excellent. there's nothing like the feeling of getting a perfect inspection.

on the other hand, both this and papers please have the very video-gamey mechanic where your inspections are checked and graded. is there a second border patrol person who is Perfect and double-checks your inspections? how do they know how much to pay you? i know it's ostensibly necessary for the game to have any type of challenge to it, but it's a bit of cognitive dissonance that's bothered me in both these games.

my other gripe is that the UI, while mostly great, falls apart for marking down vehicle conditions. vehicle condition should really be another list like the Cargo List instead of a manual ticking of tiny boxes. it doesn't make sense that the cargo list lets you count/unpack items with ease while the same quality of life doesnt apply to vehicle condition. if you have to, make it cost perception to check tires and body condition! it's often hard to discern what's a body condition problem and what's just mud.

I absolutely recommend the game. As I said in my review of the prologue, it's a 3D Papers Please, with the main gameplay being dare I say a copy, but it adds a lot of its own flair to set it apart. You want drug running? We got it. Want FPS gameplay? We got it. Want to defy the government at every turn by murdering state officials and allowing terrorists to run free? We got it. I've played "Papers, Please" and I loved it, so I was really really looking forward to the release of this game. After playing the main storyline through once (planning on doing it again the rebel way), here is my thoughts:

Spoilers ahead!

The game delivers really really well, and even exceeded my expectations in some parts. I enjoyed playing it to the point where I wasn't willing to stop playing. You guys at Crazy Rocks really did a very good job with this game! As with any game, there are pros and cons, so I'll list them here:

Pros:
- Actual stuff to do outside the border station, missions, transport prisoners and contrabands and missions. The map is also larger than I expected. 
- Upgradable border station.
- Get to actually interact with searching vehicles and actually putting in the effort to find inconsistencies in documents, smuggled items etc.
- The overall environment looks beautiful!
- Main storyline missions have variety. Sidequests are also fun to do.
- AI during Border Station attacks actually knows to take cover and use grenades, and just doesn't run up to us like headless chickens.
- Interaction with the vehicles! You get to even turn on and off the siren, load up stuff into the vehicle and such.
- I love when newcomers have a chance of just trying to escape from the station as well. We get to actually chase people.
- The game runs REALLY well as well.

As for the cons:
- The amount of ambushes feels a bit too much from time to time. I would get up to like 6 ambushes in one trip, delivering prisoners and contraband. Maybe have the amount tuned down, but make the ambushes more intense.
- I feel that the AI during ambushes and sidequests aren't bad, but I feel like it could be better. Sometimes, although not annoyingly large amount of times, they would rush you like headless chickens. Maybe have them take more cover and use more tactics and such.
- Cars sometimes feel like they are weak in terms of durability, and would start breaking apart and combust into flames quite quickly, specially after a small ambush. I would add some durability to them.
- Interacting with your police comrades and NPCs outside the border station is out of the question in this game, unfortunately. Unless it's during a mission which has dialogue.
- While the sidequests are interesting, there could have been a bit more variety and amount to them.
- There is no endless -mode. This would have been a good addition to the game as well.

Along with pros and cons I have some suggestions:

- I think there should be a chance for a smuggler to appear at the border, which doesn't have any of the smuggler marks, or appear on the board under the "smugglers" -note. Basically, they would be carrying some amount of the contraband inside the vehicle in hiding spots which don't have the mark (like under the seats, dashboard etc etc.), but is visible if paying attention. It would keep us on our toes and pay attention if we see anything inside, for example while unloading the cargo.
- During the war episode, I was expecting vehicles rigged with explosives to come to the border, which there were none. I would have added the chance for rigged vehicles to come to the border, and we would have to be careful with opening doors and such, otherwise the explosives would go off. And then have us go through a procedure of how to handle such situations, like having us make them safe to handle and such.
- Never during the game would I have been required to check under the vehicle themselves, which can be used as a hiding spot for contraband and such. Usually during vehicle inspections on checkpoints and such they would have mirrors on a stick which they could use to peek under the vehicle and see if there is anything there.

But overall, I love playing this game. It's super fun! Keep it up devs,
9/10.

I'm having a lot of fun playing this, its got RPG & sim elements combined, FPS shooting thrown in and some base expanding. you have to manage your border post as the commander there and hire guards. buy new vehicles, upgrade your outpost & living areas then also upgrade you existing personal etc. you get attacked by groups at times or when transporting prisoners or confiscated contraband which is actually quite fun. you earn money & promotions through doing your normal work tasks, transporting contraband confiscated at the check point to the police station, prisoners  can also can be transported to the prison which all create revenue for you. There are also side quests and story quests which involve choices that impact the game, also action & stealth quests which are quite cool. you can also do side hustles trading or be corrupt and sell contraband if you like.

Have not had any bugs yet in 24 hrs of playing & the game does have a decent story going with cool quests.
pros - good solid game with no bugs
          lots to do and keep you entertained
          FPS combat inst bad reminds of stalker.
Cons - not really bad cons tbh
           Graphics are fair not horrible at all, on par with garage sim perhaps a bit better.
           No save function the game auto saves only at the end of the day when you go to sleep or you can 
           restart the day

Games worth the money, if i had to make a suggestion it would be allowing to save so if you need to quit the game you don't lose progress if you haven't finished the day yet. 
Perhaps slow the day duration a bit or let us have an option to slow it a touch, its not bad just would be nice to have an option to do that on the days you want to do more. hope this helps everyone :)

I would recommend this game with some notes. There are some things that I would like to see improved.
First the game should allow more control on how to do things. If there are notices about somebody probably fleeing, you should be able to stop them preemptively by breaking their car. I smashed the car battery and destroyed all the wheels of a such car and still they were able to run the checkpoint because apparently you cannot avoid the chases.
Also if you try outsmart and run ahead of the smuggler on foot, the game will reset your character near your car because you are not allowed to do such a thing.  You can't do prisoner / smuggled items transports when you're on gate duty either, you have to do them after the gate shift which is sort of understandable but I think there should be an option to spend a day doing transport like there is in the tutorial phase.. 
When driving around the map, you get ambushed way too often. The frequency of the ambushes should be reduced it just gets tedious when  every time you drive on the paved road there's an ambush. Ain't nobody got time for it and it's hardly an element of surprise either by your 5th ambush.
Driving is a little bit laggy still. especially with several cars oncoming traffic the game has performance issues. Not as bad as in the demo but still not exactly smooth either. 
In general the basic game part of checking the vehicles and papers does get a bit repetitive after a while. It's nice that they have created the side missions and other distractions. 
But as it stands this is definitely a release quality game unlike some of these indie games I've played recently. I think the price is fair and execution is pretty good.

This is an immersive (dont take it too seriously) work simulator where you take the role of a border patrol agent . Others have compared this game to being a 3D "Papers Please" . While that is true in many respects, there is so much more added to this game that mixes up the "Papers Please" Formula. The addition of managing a border patrol base, transporting prisoners , and more really keep the game engaging and fun.  The graphics are not the best but if you like games that make you pay attention to detail while you take the role of a law enforcement type of character, this is the game for you. I highly recommend this.

Not quite on the level of papers please sadly...

Now don't get me wrong this is a pretty good game, and if you liked the bureaucratic gameplay of that game then this will scratch that itch... To an extent. However its completely bogged down by superflous and completely mediocre gameplay elements that just have no real reason to be in the game. I'm a border control officer so why would I be driving around doing bloody tailing missions? I mean it doesn't make sense from a gameplay or logical standpoint. The constant phonecalls to go do some other random thing that has nothing to do with the border control is honestly annoying although mostly ignorable. I haven't completed the game so I've no idea if ignoring them has an effect though.

It's just not necessary. In fact none of the "open world" elements are necessary or even fun at all. It just detracts from the main gameplay and lets face facts this isn't a triple AAA game, the shooting and driving mechanics are severely lacklustre at best. So why they decided to force you to drive around (being ambushed constantly) and do these really out of place missions and busy work is beyond me.

It also detracts from the relatively rare moments that made papers please special. Like a dude begging to be let in to help his family but with a minor problem in his paperwork. This game does have that but so far I've had a lot more "chase this guy" "go follow that guy" "go here and do this" missions which, as I said, just feel out of place here.

I'm also REALLY not a fan of the vehicle inspection elements. For some reason I just can't seem to ever get them right. Finding broken parts of vehicles sounds easy but almost all the vehicles are rusted piles of crap anyway and its super annoying to have a perfect score ruined by a missing bumper that you had no idea was supposed to be there in the first place.

Now you're probably wondering why I'm recommending this game when I have quite a lot of problems with it? Well the fact is it is a pretty good game and doesnt deserve a negative review. It was released in better state than most AAA games and the devs seem active in the forums and are addressing at least the most egregious issues people have with the game. Namely the bad ambush system. So while I'm giving it a postive review I'm not gonna sugarcoat it. Basically i recommend it but don't expect it to become your most favourite game of all time.

It's like the opposite feeling I had from papers please. Where I expected to hate that game and ended up absolutely adoring it. I expected to love this game and found myself thinking it was "just okay"

Like others say, it feels kinda like "papers please" (which should be taken as a compliment), but it actually has a bunch of other stuff to do too, and feels surprisingly deep in many of its gameplay mechanics. Therefore, it shouldn't be seen as simply being a "papers please" copy, as it differs from that game in many interesting ways. 

I haven't played it that much yet, so i don't know how many hours of gameplay the game has, but for its price of about 20 euros i do think i would recommend this game, as it actually seems to provide lots of gameplay elements that justify the price, and isn't just a cash grab.

This is my first review for a game and I want to honest since I've completed it. 

The game still have some bugs in it of course, it just came out. Even with the bugs though, even the annoying one where you deny someone, which is right, and still get counted wrong for it, I say its playable. I did not run into any issues with driving the car or interacting with any of NPCs. Missions can be a little confusing because it does not directly tell you where to look for some items, had to search on YT to find an item in one mission that I thought was apart of the background. Nevertheless I do want to warn people though, this is a story based game, not a endless mode game with a story. 

I wish it was like Papers, Please; it is well polished for it's official release. Again, this is a story based game, so if you restart the day, the same cars with different information/character will come up but most of the time, it will be the same deny/entry, and this happens out the tutorial. The gun fights are a bit here and there, a shotgun can shoot across the field and some NPC can take three point blank shots to the chest before dying. I used the sniper at the very end of my game play but somehow, it seemed to have worst range than the shotgun and worst fire power. 

Leveling up in this game is not that important. I got through the game fine with only level II items for my warehouse, jail, and housing. Max for my border guards and did not buy the last unlockable car, because truly you did not need it. You seem to lose a lot of money for simple mistakes which can cost you to not to be able to afford upgrades the next day, because it only spawns a few amount of cars each day. 

I say I recommend this game because while it was short, it was fun. I would play it again, this time for the opposite story line. It's a bit sad knowing I know what comes next and not much will change next time, but not too disheartening.

Contraband Police is an exciting and engaging game that puts you in the shoes of a border guard tasked with detecting and intercepting contraband items entering your country. With its immersive gameplay, and challenging levels, Contraband Police offers a thrilling and addictive experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end.

One of the things that sets Contraband Police apart from other games is its attention to detail. The game accurately simulates the procedures and protocols that border guards follow when inspecting vehicles and passengers, adding a level of realism that makes the experience all the more immersive.

But what really makes Contraband Police shine is its gameplay. Each level presents you with a new challenge, from inspecting suspicious vehicles to questioning nervous passengers, and you'll need to use all of your skills and intuition to succeed. As you progress through the game, you'll unlock new tools and equipment that will help you in your quest to catch smugglers and contraband items, adding an element of progression and reward that keeps you motivated and engaged.

Overall, I highly recommend Contraband Police to anyone looking for a fun and challenging game that offers a unique and immersive experience. Whether you're a fan of simulation games, strategy games, or just looking for something new and exciting to play, Contraband Police is sure to provide hours of entertainment and enjoyment.

Nearly 18 hours for me to complete the first story arc to end credits completion. Restarted a few days, rejected a few mission invites a couple times, otherwise mostly forward progress. The game makes me feel like there are definitely 2 story arcs to try, possibly a 3rd. Good price point, and fun game!

Replayability is definitely a thing, however, having to progress through the intro tutorial each time to get to the meatier mid-game or end-game inspections takes time. Also, entirely possible to finish the game without even finishing your upgrades or using all the weapons, etc. The end creeps up faster than you think.

Looking forward to the endless mode. Also, judging by the artwork for the game I'd say they might have plans for DLCs in different country border areas for the future.
i sleep at border, i work at border, i protect border

Addictive game. Can be polished in some aspects like: combat mechanics and object interaction.

Plus points:
For the price is a good amount of fun.
AI is smarter that StarCitizen AI after 7+ years of development.

This is a 3d version Papers Please, but also includes some FPS and driving elements. Overall its well done, and is surprisingly polished for a new indy release.

It took me 11 hours to complete the story, and as of now there isn't a "continuous" mode, which is the biggest drawback. Devs have said they'll be implementing that, and I hope they do soon. You do have some options during the story, and it seems you can get different endingsw based on some of your choices, but I haven't tried that yet. 

I ran into a handful of minor bugs, but nothing gamebreaking.

Quick run down of my rants and praises. 9/10
Pros
- Shoot rebels and steal their contraband.
- Make money from arrested and dead rebels.
- Fun game for the price, I got more than I expected.
- Defiantly worth a second play through, more than one ending.
- Can become pretty challenging with the border checks, especially at the end with everything tied together and if you're trying to get perfect inspections. 
- Pretty interesting story and how fate is determined/events.
- AI has ammo... not just 3-7 rounds when looted.
- A studio that finally releases a finished product instead of a beta type release. 
- Profit

Cons(Minuscule)
-  AK has like zero recoil. Like a little tiny bit more would be welcoming... At least it's not ridiculously unusable in a sense where I can't hit a barn door 10m away. But I don't feel like I should be full auto hitting a watermelon sized target from 100m away.
- AI bodies disappearing during or after gunfights really quickly, I want that ammo >:)
- How tf does the commissar know who the smugglers are? If you already know just point them out homie, who's side are you on? Are you omnipresent? If I missed him I don't think it should fine you... just keep the chapter going until he tries to pass again.
- Siren on loop. A very obvious start and stop. Idk if that's how it's suppose to be but it's annoying after about 2 minutes. 
- 5 minute time goals to be at an objective no matter where at on the map or what condition your in. 

Cons
- Ambush mechanic. I feel like I'm constantly being attacked by rebels while on the roads.... And I mean like 2-4 times when I'm just driving a half loop around the small map. Also pretty much occurs after every incident. Main reason I didn't enjoy going out or exploring. I did notice it dropped a little towards the late game although I was making less frequent trips out. 
- THE FREAKING WHEELS ON THE SD2 whatever Geo Metro looking thing. If there's smuggled contraband in the tires goodluck trying to get to it. The wheel is so small you're practically never going to hit... you'll either hit the fender, the rim, or the ground. I've gone through so many types of tools trying to crack them open and nothing works. Also I've let so many go by with flat tires it's insane. Geo Metro OP. 
- Game is finished when storyline is finished. It would be nice to at least to get a warning that your gameplay is going to entirely be done for. 
- Shotguns have zero range. Pretty much useless unless right on top of someone. Save your money for a SMG or AK. 


I'd highly recommend this game. My biggest complaint is the ambush mechanic and how many there are. Like isn't this a totalitarian regime... where are all these rebels getting these weapons? Am I not doing my job at the border by catching all these vigilantes smuggling in weapons? Is Vlad behind this? Where is the Commissar and his all seeing eye watching me search these vehicles?

I enjoyed the storyline and being able to pick a side to support although I wish the gameplay didn't end so abruptly. I had one more baddie on my list to catch but I suddenly got a call and took it and finished the game without even realizing it. Idk if I can sleep knowing there is still one smuggler out there that I didn't catch... Another annoying con was the siren on a loop... like it was obviously a loop and had a blatant start and stop. Also AK is extremely OP due to the recoil... like don't make it Tarkov level recoil where it's ridiculous but I feel like it's peashooter recoil level. Like just a smidge higher wouldn't hurt. Shotgun has no range also so, it's a no from me. Also I found the dead disappearing really quickly during a gun fight, kinda annoying when I'm low on ammo and I need those sweet sweet rounds (really nice on how the AI carries a decent amount of ammo though!).  Overall I'd highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a nice change of pace... One minute you're checking paperwork and letting cars through the toll, the next you're in a high speed chase or shootout with multiple baddies. Then right back to border checking papers and cargo. 9/10.

i wished for a game like this when i was playing papers please, im not into shooting and stuff like that but papers control, damn its good, i hope dev will add option to move papers in notebook when ur checking someone, its little uncomfortable to click checkbook and close checkbook to look at papers again, would be so much better if you could adjust and move every paper in your notebook, make this game phenomen and show everyone that those type of games could be a thing, also contraband police 2 pls :P

The best way to describe Contraband Police is a dash of Paper's Please mixed with plenty of action and a bit of sim/management thrown in to give you something to do with your downtime. 

Contraband Police caught me completely off guard; there is way more game here than I was expecting for my ~$20. 

Is it perfect? No. Is there jank? Of course.  However, the quality of this game and the passion and hard work that the Dev put into it shines through, and really makes this something unique and fun. 


The story and side-missions so far are quite good and they are paced well. Just when you start to feel the monotony start to set in from the daily grind of checking paperwork, catching smugglers, turning in prisoners and contraband, you get a call telling you that there has been a murder at a local establishment and you --as the closest thing to proper law enforcement-- are being called in to investigate.

Another thing that really stands out is how much this game actually makes me care about my actions. I was expecting to just fall into the role of the compassionless guard "just doing his job". But, somehow, even with the fairly sparse dialogue and only having short summary of my subordinates backgrounds I found myself actually caring about how I went about my job. 

The system I serve my be rotten and the rules I enforce sometimes arbitrary and pointless, but the job I am doing is important and has an affect on the people I interact with every day. 
I quickly found myself happy to accept the fine for not turning someone away in order to help them. I even ended up foregoing an upgrade to my living conditions to ensure I had the cash reserve to let asylum seekers through who would have otherwise  been turned away because they had a spelling mistake on their paperwork. 


The only real complaint I have about Contraband Police is the roadside ambushes when you are out driving around, they are far to frequent and only really serve as an annoyance when you are trying to get some of your busy-work done. I think they would be much better if they were tweaked to be much less common but far more dangerous, make them something that can actually surprise you rather than something you expect.

If anything about Contraband Police seems like something you might be interested in, don't hesitate, it will at the very least meet your expectations. But, it is far more likely it will surpass those expectations just like it did with me.
3D papers please is very good
Neat Papers Please like game and its more polished than all most AAA games.
Great game a lot of fun to play absolutely worth the waiting for I do hope it get more content in the future.

Contraband Police: Prologue is the ultimate border guard simulator! As a communist inspector in the 80s, you'll face the usual suspects - smuggling, corruption, and forgery. But there's more! You'll also trade with the people you're searching and check their vaccine cards. What a gig!

The graphics are good for what it is (aka not Crysis-level). And as you earn the respect of your bosses, you'll climb the ranks faster than a monkey up a tree.

But the real fun comes from the ridiculous situations you'll find yourself in. From accidentally frisking goats to chasing smugglers like it's the Olympics, you won't stop laughing. So if you're up for some communist comedy, Contraband Police: Prologue is definitely worth the price!

What a great game. Took me 14 hours in total to play through.
This game is not endless (yet?), so once you complete all chapters, your save game is over.

This is essentially a combination between thief simulator and paper please. 
Gameplay 10/10
Graphics 8/10
Bugfree 5/10
Music 9/10
Story 5/10

Spoilers from here:
The story is fairly short and consists of single intermissions between your normal day job essentially finding things or killing people.
The gameplay is increadible. Each new chapter introduces new mechanics, new things to remember and check and just makes you exited for the next chapter.
Although it can be frustrating, often times having not a perfect score means you messed up somehow, not the game. The discussion threads are filled with "this is a bug, I checked everything" and later on it turns out, they missed something.
The difficulty is great, you are not heavily punished for messing up a bit, but getting perfect scores is still hard.

Small details I want to be changed:
Car windows are really hard to see. Checking them is more of a "how do I angle my camera" rather than "did I remember to do this". Sometimes quite frustrating.

Document backgrounds are not intuitive explained. It is not clear, what a correct or wrong document background is. I had to rely on the auto compare every time here.

The Special Rule for Chapter "War" is not explained clearly. Do you allow al'barakh if they have not asyl? Do you ignore missmatches if they have asyl? That rule should be rewritten to be clearer.

Give me more ranks. I reached top rank after 4 chapters. The rank mechanic was pretty useless for the rest.

Cargo Cheatsheets should not be tied to the document section, when I have the cargo cheatsheet equipped. Unequipping the cheat sheet brings up the cheatsheet in the document section again. This was annoying.

Nation and Car selection should be the first page in the information book. Clicking the "next" button every time was annoying.

Car maximum weights on the driver license should be tied to the car that is actually on the driver license. This increases the difficulty. Otherwise I don't need to look at the car at all, I just compare the written maximum weight with the information book.

I would love to have a more intuitive, or more detailed view of black markets. It is not clear if the price given by a person is way to high compared to the average or not. If players want to get into this, why not add a whole new section with graphs (maybe everytime the player buys an item, the buy graph gets extended - as in the ingame officer draws them by hand).

Great game, fun to play, lots to explore, a lot of secrets and the selling point is the gameplay - if you like papers please ofc.

Overall 8/10
